Matthew 24:15, he will enforce his mark on people Revelation 13:16\u201317.This video here inspired me.The Coronavirus Vaccine and the Mark of the Beast", "THE ABOMINATION THAT CAUSES DESOLATION: The passage in Luk_21:20 has: \"Jerusalem being surrounded by armies\" Based on the desecration of the temple by Antiochus Ephiphanes: Dan_11:31,,,,,,,,,,Click on image to enlarge\nBible Truth And Prophecy", "This excerpt from the bible encyclopedia INSIGHT ON THE SCRIPTURES supplies some information you may find useful: -\n[*** it-1 p. 635 Disgusting Thing, also Loathsome Thing ***\n\u2018Disgusting Things Leading to Desolation.\u2019 Daniel\u2019s prophecy foretold \u201cdisgusting things\u201d associated with desolation. (Da 9:27) The popular view has generally followed early Jewish tradition in applying this expression to the profanation of Jehovah\u2019s temple at Jerusalem in the year 168 B.C.E. by Syrian King Antiochus IV (Epiphanes). Attempting to stamp out the worship of Jehovah, Antiochus built an altar over the great altar of Jehovah and sacrificed upon this a pig to the Olympian Zeus (Jupiter). An expression like that of Daniel (associating disgusting things with desolation) appears in the Apocryphal book of 1 Maccabees (1:54) as applying to this event.\nBut this was only the Jewish interpretation of matters, not an inspired revelation. Christ Jesus showed this view to be in error when he gave the warning to his disciples: \u201cTherefore, when you catch sight of the disgusting thing that causes desolation, as spoken of through Daniel the prophet, standing in a holy place, (let the reader use discernment,) then let those in Judea begin fleeing to the mountains.\u201d (Mt 24:15, 16) These words show that \u201cthe disgusting thing that causes desolation\u201d was not then past but future.\nThe pagan desecration of the temple altar by Antiochus, however disgusting in God\u2019s sight, did not result in desolation\u2014for Jerusalem, for the temple, or for the Jewish nation. But 33 years after Jesus\u2019 death, Christians did \u201ccatch sight of the disgusting thing that causes desolation . . . standing in a holy place.\u201d (Mt 24:15) In 66 C.E. pagan Roman armies surrounded \u201cthe holy city\u201d Jerusalem, now the center of Jewish revolt against Rome. Thus, the \u2018causing of desolation\u2019 by the disgusting thing was imminent, and so this was the final signal for discerning Christians to \u2018flee to the mountains.\u2019 (Mt 4:5; 27:53; 24:15, 16; Lu 19:43, 44; 21:20-22) Following their flight, the desolation of the city and nation occurred, Jerusalem being destroyed in the year 70 C.E., and the last Jewish stronghold, Masada, falling to the Romans in 73 C.E.\u2014Compare Da 9:25-27.]", "First let me state that if you get ahold of the older copies of the book of Daniel. It is properly translated the abomination that makes desolate. Not abomination of desolation.", "The Hebrew nouns she\u02b9qets (loathsome thing) and shiq\u00b7quts\u02b9 (disgusting thing) come from the root sha\u00b7qats\u02b9, used in the sense of \u201cloathe\u201d (Le 11:11, 13) and, in the causative form, \u2018make loathsome.\u2019 (Le 11:43; 20:25) These Hebrew terms refer to that which is repugnant from the standpoint of Jehovah\u2019s true worship. They are commonly rendered by such words as \u201cabominate,\u201d \u201cabominable,\u201d or \u201cabomination\u201d in many translations. This has resulted in the well-known expression \u201cabomination of desolation.\u201d (Da 11:31; 12:11, KJ) The Gospel writers Matthew and Mark used the Greek bde\u02b9lyg\u00b7ma to translate the Hebrew shiq\u00b7quts\u02b9 (plural, shiq\u00b7qu\u00b7tsim\u02b9). (Da 9:27; Mt 24:15; Mr 13:14) This Greek term basically implies that which causes disgust.\n\u2018Disgusting Things Leading to Desolation.\u2019 Daniel\u2019s prophecy foretold \u201cdisgusting things\u201d associated with desolation. (Da 9:27) The popular view has generally followed early Jewish tradition in applying this expression to the profanation of Jehovah\u2019s temple at Jerusalem in the year 168 B.C.E. by Syrian King Antiochus IV (Epiphanes). Attempting to stamp out the worship of Jehovah, Antiochus built an altar over the great altar of Jehovah and sacrificed upon this a pig to the Olympian Zeus (Jupiter). An expression like that of Daniel (associating disgusting things with desolation) appears in the Apocryphal book of 1 Maccabees (1:54) as applying to this event.\nBut this was only the Jewish interpretation of matters, not an inspired revelation. Christ Jesus showed this view to be in error when he gave the warning to his disciples: \u201cTherefore, when you catch sight of the disgusting thing that causes desolation, as spoken of through Daniel the prophet, standing in a holy place, (let the reader use discernment,) then let those in Judea begin fleeing to the mountains.\u201d (Mt 24:15, 16) These words show that \u201cthe disgusting thing that causes desolation\u201d was not then past but future.\nThe pagan desecration of the temple altar by Antiochus, however disgusting in God\u2019s sight, did not result in desolation\u2014for Jerusalem, for the temple, or for the Jewish nation. But 33 years after Jesus\u2019 death, Christians did \u201ccatch sight of the disgusting thing that causes desolation . . . standing in a holy place.\u201d (Mt 24:15) In 66 C.E. pagan Roman armies surrounded \u201cthe holy city\u201d Jerusalem, now the center of Jewish revolt against Rome. Thus, the \u2018causing of desolation\u2019 by the disgusting thing was imminent, and so this was the final signal for discerning Christians to \u2018flee to the mountains.\u2019 (Mt 4:5; 27:53; 24:15, 16; Lu 19:43, 44; 21:20-22) Following their flight, the desolation of the city and nation occurred, Jerusalem being destroyed in the year 70 C.E., and the last Jewish stronghold, Masada, falling to the Romans in 73 C.E.\u2014Compare Da 9:25-27.\nAdditional prophecies of a disgusting thing. It should be noted, however, that Daniel 11:31-35 and 12:9, 11 connect a \u2018disgusting thing causing desolation\u2019 with \u201cthe time of the end.\u201d It is reasonable that the development of this latter expression of \u2018the disgusting thing causing desolation\u2019 in the time of the end should follow the general pattern of that in the first century C.E., though not being restricted to the land of Israel.\nJerusalem\u2019s desolation in 70 C.E. brought the end of the \u201choly place,\u201d Jerusalem, \u201cthe holy city.\u201d (Mt 27:53) However, the Scriptures direct our attention to a \u201cheavenly Jerusalem,\u201d the Messianic Kingdom, which is represented on earth by anointed Christians. (Heb 12:22) There are also others that falsely claim to represent that Kingdom, and Revelation chapter 17 shows that their religious field of operations will be desolated by the \u201cten horns\u201d (kings) of a symbolic \u201cwild beast.\u201d\nDisgusting Things of Babylon the Great. In the prophetic vision of Revelation 17, the symbolic immoral woman, Babylon the Great, is depicted. She is called \u201cthe mother of the harlots and of the disgusting things of the earth.\u201d She holds a golden cup \u2018full of the disgusting things of her fornication with the kings of the earth.\u2019 Though she curries the favor of the earthly kingdoms, sitting on top of a symbolic wild beast composed of such kingdoms, the time comes when this \u201cbeast\u201d refuses to carry her, turns on her, and completely desolates her.\u2014See BABYLON THE GREAT.\nAny possibility that persons continuing in the practice of a \u201cdisgusting thing\u201d might gain entrance into the \u201cNew Jerusalem,\u201d the Lamb\u2019s chaste \u201cbride\u201d class, is ruled out at Revelation 21:9, 10, 27.\nFor more research, click here", "Mat 24:15 : \u201cSo when you see standing in the holy place 'the abomination that causes desolation,' spoken of through the prophet Daniel\u2014let the reader understand.\u201d This is referring to Dan 9:27, \u201cHe will confirm a covenant with many for one \u2019seven.' In the middle of the \u2019seven' he will put an end to sacrifice and offering. And on a wing [of the temple] he will set up an abomination that causes desolation, until the end that is decreed is poured out on him.\u201d\nIn 167 B.C. a Greek ruler by the name of Antiochus\nset up an altar to Zeus over the altar of burnt offerings in the Jewish temple in Jerusalem. He also sacrificed a pig on the altar in the Temple in Jerusalem. This event is known as the abomination of desolation.\nAnother abomination of desolation would occur in a Jewish temple, The Antichrist will do something very similar to what Antiochus Epiphanies did.\nRead what Daniel prophesied in Daniel 9:27 Antiochus did not confirm a covenant with Israel for seven years. It is the Antichrist who, in the end times, will establish a covenant with Israel for seven years and then break it by doing something similar to the abomination of desolation in the Jewish temple in Jerusalem.", "It's when, at some point in the future, in the third temple, that a man, known in Christianity as the antichrist will stand in the temple and declare himself as god and make a sacrifice unto his father, satan.\nThis will happen half way or at the midpoint of the Seven year tribulation period.\nIt must be noted that Israel as a nation, make a pact or deal with this political leader. This would have happened three and half years previously to the mid point. In absolutely no way does Israel see this man as the Messiah, just a gentile who promises a deal of political security, which he then breaks.\nDaniel ch 9.", "It had a minor fulfillment in the first century when, in 67 CE (AD) the Roman army breached the walls of the Temple in Jerusalem. Then three years later they destroyed Jerusalem and it\u2019s Temple. However, it was to to have a greater fulfillment when Jesus said there would be a great tribulation with would be greater than anything before and would never occur again. There have obviously been greater times of tribulation than the Small scale, limited destruction, of the city of Jerusalem in the first century.\nIn the greater fulfillment the abomination causing desolation began as the League of Nations, which came as formed after World War II. It was embraced by the Churches of Christendom as the organization to bring peace and security to the earth, thus it stood in a holy place which only God\u2019s Kingdom can rightly occupy. After it failed, the United Nation Organization replace it and it now is the abomination bring desolation.", "What is the Abomination of Desolation spoken of by Daniel in the Bible?\nIf you can no discern the fulfillment of this Abomination of Desolation in the New Testament of Jesus , what good too your Spiritual growth is it.\nFind the equivlant passages in the New testament and you will have found a new treasure in Heaven.", "My perspective is that \u201cthe abomination that causes desolation\u201d is borrowed in the New Testament from Daniel 9:27. Many refer it to an alleged coming of Antichrist to the (rebuilt) temple in the last days of the world. But coming at your question from a New Testament perspective (the New is in the Old concealed, the Old is in the New revealed) is to wrench the whole idea out of its context (see Matthew 24:15\u201320).\nI will get to Daniel 9:27 later, but, Luke interpreting for Gentiles, gives us some help. He records the words as \u201cWhen you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, you will know that its desolation is near\u201d (Luke 21:20). There, as in Matthew 24:15\u201320, this is the signal for \u201cthose who are in Judea\u201d to \u201cflee to the mountains\u201d. Whether \u201cthe holy place\u201d refers to Jerusalem or to the temple itself does not matter. So, in answer to your question \u2014 What we have here from a New Testament perspective is the Roman armies invading the land, bearing their sacrilegious banners, or eagles, to defile the holy place.\nIt is worthy of note that Jesus expects these events to be seen and clearly understood \u2014 signs which may be acted upon. This is completely different from the prophecies concerning his Second Coming, given later in Matthew 24. In that instance there is no warning; there are no signs. Always there is surprise. Here, in Matthew 24:15\u201320 we have signs which the Christian can observe and from which they can take warning.\nThe historical record is not clear, but there is what Carson calls \u201creasonably good tradition that Christians abandoned the city, perhaps in A.D. 68, about half-way through the siege\u201d and took refuge in the mountains. Jesus then gives detailed instructions \u2014 instructions which could not be followed in time, if the return of Christ was in the picture.\nI see these actions belonging to Palestine and indicate that these verses (Matthew 24:15\u201320) belong to this period before A.D. 70. It was in Palestine that men would be on the roof of their houses and needed to be warned \u201cnot to go down to take anything out of the house\u201d. Those in the field are warned not to go back to get their cloaks. \u201cPregnant women and nursing mothers\u201d would suffer in such circumstances.\nMost clearly, we read, \u201cPray that your flight will not take place in winter or on the Sabbath\u201d. The reference to the Sabbath, especially, demands the context of first-century Palestine. If they fled on the Sabbath, they would find no help from Jews, eager to keep the Sabbath and unwilling to help those in need.\nAs far as the Old Testament (Daniel 9:27) is concerned. Daniel is seeing this in the sixth century B.C. but it did not happen until A.D. 70 when Titus and his Roman legions fulfilled this prophecy exactly. The destruction of Jerusalem did not immediately follow Calvary, but it was an event which was determined by the fact that the Jews rejected Christ. It did not happen in the seventieth \u2018week\u2019 , but was determined in the seventieth \u2018week\u2019. Jesus made it clear, both in His Olivet discourse and as He walked to the cross, that his rejection by the Jews would mean the destruction of their city and temple (Matthew 23:34 \u2014 24:38 ; Luke 23:27\u201431).\nWe might be helped here, by thinking back to Adam. He was told that he would die on the very day that he ate the forbidden fruit. But he did not literally drop down dead. That day he died spiritually, and his physical death followed as a certain result. In the same way, Jerusalem\u2019s destruction was made certain by the Jewish rejection of their Messiah, but it was some little time before the event occurred. It did not take place in the seventieth \u2018week\u2019, but was most surely part and parcel of the events of that \u2018week\u2019.\nWhat else is prophesied in Daniel concerning that final \u2018week\u2019 ?\n\u201cAnd he shall confirm the covenant with many for one week\u201d (9:27). This is what Jesus did in announcing \u201cThis is my blood of the new covenant (testament), which is shed for many for the remission of sins (Matthew 26:28).\n\u201cAnd in the midst of the week, he shall cause the sacrifice and the oblation to cease\u201d (Daniel 9:27). Jesus did this too, because he was sacrificed once for all (see Hebrews 7:27). The veil of the temple was torn in two, and the way into the Holiest was permanently opened by his never-to-be-repeated sacrifice. There was no further need for the Old Testament rituals and oblations. In fact, the destruction of Jerusalem made it impossible, eventually, for them to be continued.", "The abomination of desolation is first described briefly by Daniel in chapter 12, then Matthew 24 by Jesus, and also in Revelation 13. You would think it was made note of enough times that it would be taken seriously, yet there are those who say it all took place by 70 A.D. when the temple was destroyed. How anyone makes a connection like this is beyond me. No individual is identified by them matching either the first or second beast of Revelation 13. The temple is not destroyed but exists in Revelation 13. Revelation was written in the time of Domitian, late 1st century, according to 2nd century attestation of Irenaeus, a little late for preterist views. The abomination of desolation is an image made by the second beast (antichrist 2) to honor the first beast (antichrist 1), an idol. It speaks. All this is technologically possible today. So the question is, is it done technologically or supernaturally? That\u2019s TBA. Its location by Matthew 24:15 is the temple. It is set up 1,290 days into week 70 of Daniel, (see Daniel 12:11). This is 30 days past the middle of the week when the antichrist cuts of the daily sacrifice of the Jews.", "Daniel mentions two of such, (Daniel 9:27; 11:31) and in both cases they seem to be connected to the end of a world.\nTherefore, when you catch sight of the disgusting thing that causes desolation, as spoken about by Daniel the prophet, standing in a holy place (let the reader use discernment), . . . then there will be great tribulation such as has not occurred since the world's beginning\nMatthew 24:15, 21\nThis was fulfilled when the armies of a Gentile nation\u2014an abomination to the Jews\u2014came to desolate Jerusalem and her temple, putting a violent end to the organised system of worship that has been practiced there for centuries. (Daniel 9:27; Luke 21:20, 23)\nHowever, notice that Matthew 24:15 ends with the words \u201clet the user use discernment,\u201d and that's because this appears to be a dual prophecy, since another abomination of desolation occurs in Daniel 11:31. Like Daniel 9:27, the abomination of desolation spoken of in Daniel 11:31 will cause desolation to many organised forms of worship that is being practiced on earth today.\nAt this point, it is necessary to consider how Revelation expounds on this thought, since, as you might know, Revelation and Daniel are complementary books of prophecy.\nRevelation 17:3, 16 brings two entities into play, a wild beast, an abomination in itself, \u201cfull of blasphemous names,\u201d that turns against a woman and completely destroys her, leaving her utterly desolate. Happily, God himself helps us unravel these mysteries.\u2014Revelation 17:7.\nIn Revelation 17:11-13, the wild beast is called a \u201cking,\u201d or a dominant political agency in the world scene, an agency that \u201cten kings,\u201d i.e, all the political forces, subscribe to. (cf. Daniel 1:20; Revelation 2:10) And this political agency had a predecessor, but it re-emerged a stronger version of itself. (Revelation 17:8) The only agency that fits this description is the League of Nations and it's successor, the United Nations.\nChristendom hailed this organization as mankind's only hope for peace and security, the political expression of God's Kingdom on earth, and the UN went along with it, thus becoming blasphemous by setting itself as counterfeit \u201cKingdom of God,\u201d taking it upon itself to do what God has said only his Kingdom will do.\nAs for the woman, she means a mighty organization with worldwide membership. (Revelation 17:15, 18) More clues to her identity is shown in her name\u2014Babylon was the place where false worship began after the flood, and after God scattered mankind from that central location to all the earth, they all left; each one with their false religious beliefs, all gotten from Babylon; and by those means the world is filled with all sorts of religious beliefs today that, though different, are similar in many respects, because they were originally drawn from a common pool.\nThe identity of \u201cBabylon the Great\u201d as being of a religious nature is shown at Revelation 18:23 where she's accused of \u201cspiritistic [a religious influence] practices.\u201d For her to have misled \u201call the nations,\u201d she must represent more than just one religion. As per Revelation 17:5, think of her as the mother organization of false religions, and think of the many false religious groups existing today as her \u2018daughters.\u2019 Together, they have produced the disgusting fruits of \u2018divination, magic, sorcery, necromancy, etc.\u2019\u2014Deuteronomy 18:10-12.\nSo, Revelation 17:16 tells of an approaching time when all the political forces on earth, backed up by the UN, will launch an attack against religion and bring a terrible end to many of them. Again, as in the first century, only \u201cthe chosen ones,\u201d i.e, the \u201cpure religion,\u201d will escape.\u2014Matthew 24:22; James 1:27.\nThis is the modern-day \u201cabomination of desolation.\u201d", "The LORD had promised repeatedly that if Israel did not repent then the LORD would turn their prosperous land into a desolate\nruin:\n[2Ch 30:7 CSB] (7) \"Don't be like your fathers and your brothers who were unfaithful to the LORD, the God of their ancestors so that he made them an object of horror as you yourselves see.\n[Jer 4:7 CSB] (7) A lion has gone up from his thicket; a destroyer of nations has set out. He has left his lair to make your land a waste. Your cities will be reduced to uninhabited ruins.\nHe specifically says that Jerusalem would be completely destroyed:\n[Jer 7:34 CSB] (34) \"I will remove from the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem the sound of joy and gladness and the voices of the groom and the bride, for the land will become a desolate waste.\n[Jer 25:18 CSB] (18) Jerusalem and the other cities of Judah, its kings and its officials, to make them a desolate ruin, an example for scorn and cursing -- as it is today;\n[Jer 44:6, 22 CSB] (6) \"So my fierce wrath poured out and burned in Judah's cities and Jerusalem's streets so that they became the desolate ruin they are today. ... (22) \"The LORD can no longer bear your evil deeds and the detestable acts you have committed, so your land has become a waste, a desolation, and an example for cursing, without inhabitant, as you see today.\nHe would make the temple a ruin:\n[Jer 22:5 CSB] (5) \"But if you do not obey these words, then I swear by myself -- this is the LORD's declaration -- that this house will become a ruin.' \"\nHow would the LORD bring about this desolation? Jesus said that this was going to happen within his own generation (within the next 40 years):\n[Mat 23:29-39 RSV] (29) \"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for you build the tombs of the prophets and adorn the monuments of the righteous, (30) saying, 'If we had lived in the days of our fathers, we would not have taken part with them in shedding the blood of the prophets.' (31) Thus you witness against yourselves, that you are sons of those who murdered the prophets. (32) Fill up, then, the measure of your fathers. (33) You serpents, you brood of vipers, how are you to escape being sentenced to hell? (34) Therefore I send you prophets and wise men and scribes, some of whom you will kill and crucify, and some you will scourge in your synagogues and persecute from town to town, (35) that upon you may come all the righteous blood shed on earth, from the blood of innocent Abel to the blood of Zechari'ah the son of Barachi'ah, whom you murdered between the sanctuary and the altar. (36) Truly, I say to you, all this will come upon this generation. (37) \"O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, killing the prophets and stoning those who are sent to you! How often would I have gathered your children together as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you would not! (38) Behold, your house is forsaken and desolate. (39) For I tell you, you will not see me again, until you say, 'Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord.'\"\nJesus told them that Jerusalem would be surrounded by an army and accomplish God\u2019s vengeance for Jerusalem\u2019s rejection of the Messiah:\n[Luk 21:20-24 NLT] (20) \"And when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then you will know that the time of its destruction has arrived. (21) Then those in Judea must flee to the hills. Those in Jerusalem must get out, and those out in the country should not return to the city. (22) For those will be days of God's vengeance, and the prophetic words of the Scriptures will be fulfilled. (23) How terrible it will be for pregnant women and for nursing mothers in those days. For there will be disaster in the land and great anger against this people. (24) They will be killed by the sword or sent away as captives to all the nations of the world. And Jerusalem will be trampled down by the Gentiles until the period of the Gentiles comes to an end.\nThe abomination that makes [Jerusalem and the temple] desolate was the Roman army. There may be a more specific reference to Titus or the disrespectful acts of the Roman leadership toward the temple but at the end of the day the important thing to know is that Matthew 24, Luke 21 and the Revelation are all about the Roman destruction, massacre and ruination of Jerusalem and the temple and the Jewish people was the long promised judgment upon Israel for their unfaithfulness to their LORD.\nIt has nothing to do with modern times:\n[1Pe 4:17 NKJV] (17) For the time has come for judgment to begin at the house of God; and if it begins with us first, what will be the end of those who do not obey the gospel of God?\n[1Jo 2:18 NKJV] (18) Little children, it is the last hour; and as you have heard that the Antichrist is coming, even now many antichrists have come, by which we know that it is the last hour.\n[Mat 3:10 NKJV] (10) \"And even now the ax is laid to the root of the trees. Therefore every tree which does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.\n[Mat 23:36 NKJV] (36) \"Assuredly, I say to you, all these things will come upon this generation.\n[1Pe 4:7 NKJV] (7) But the end of all things is at hand; therefore be serious and watchful in your prayers.\n[Rev 22:10 NKJV] (10) And he said to me, \"Do not seal the words of the prophecy of this book, for the time is at hand.\nJosephus wrote of Jerusalem after the war:\n\u2026This was the end which Jerusalem came to by the madness of those that were for innovations; a city otherwise of great magnificence, and of mighty fame among all mankind. [18]\nAnd truly, the very view itself was a melancholy thing; for those places which were adorned with trees and pleasant gardens, were now become desolate country every way, and its trees were all cut down. Nor could any foreigner that had formerly seen Judaea and the most beautiful suburbs of the city, and now saw it as a desert, but lament and mourn sadly at so great a change. For the war had laid all signs of beauty quite waste. Nor had anyone who had known the place before, had come on a sudden to it now, would he have known it again. But though he [a foreigner] were at the city itself, yet would he have inquired for it. Stewart Hearl", "Rachel Caine", "Marj Charlier", "Momina Ali"], "question_title": "What is the difference between a soft copy and a hard copy book, and when is each most appropriate?", "topic_list": ["Hard Copies", "Soft Copy", "Book Publishing", "eBooks", "Literature", "Reading", "Book Recommendations", "Books"], "no_of_view": "2,340", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 3, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["I assume you mean hardcover and softcover books? All the books I have done have been softcover. Hardcover books, as far as I understand, as only done by publishers when the title is going to be something they expect to be around for a long time and they expect to sell many, many copies of. I don\u2019t know if the author gets a bigger slice of the pie with hardcover or not; I\u2019d be curious to know.", "The basic difference is simply in the medium, one is digital, the other is a physical print.\nOn the appropriateness, it depends on your convenience and which you find more cool for you.\nYou like going paperless, then the soft copy is for you.\nYou like paper print, likely the hardcopy will be your thing.\nSo it's just like that. coupled with the matter of which you find available or feasible to use per time.\nHope that helps", "A soft copy has a soft, paper cover. A hard cover is made of thick cardboard and can have a linen or printed and wrapped finish. The hard cover slightly extends beyond the page content whereas the soft cover is flush with interior pages. Obviously, the hard cover is more durable and costly than the thinner cover. Publishers sometimes publish soft cover or ebook versions of a title to test the market, reserving hard covers for collectible books or those likely to sell for a long time. Classics, bestsellers and celebrity books often are released in hard cover. The book market is a bit like a lottery. Editors bet or speculate on what will sell many copies. The publisher must make a profit on each format. Releasing a title as both a hard cover and soft cover increases the potential for sales.\nAuthorlink", "Hi, Judey. I\u2019m a coward who wouldn\u2019t dream of competing with Rachel Caine, hereabouts. and certainly not with her 50-plus novels and NYT credential.\n(No; Rachel. Cookbooks tend to be hardcover because you need high-quality pictures in color, so the binding is generally appropriate for the amount you\u2019re investing in the layout. Plus, people just tend to like hardcover cookbooks. Coffee table and art books: same.\nin some nonfiction categories, nearly all releases are hardcover first.\nIn fiction it\u2019s much more driven by sales expectation. If you\u2019re selling tons in paperback, you can be stepped up to hardcover first with a paperback to follow. If the publisher paid a lot up front for the book, they\u2019re almost certain to do a hardcover first. If there\u2019s a lot of \u201cbuzz,\u201d also probably hardcover.\nThese are all decisions made by the publisher based on the market and their experience with readers in the specific genre or category.\nAuthors can choose to print in hardcover if self-publishing but it is very expensive, generally, and you have to pay for the print run up front. There are services that shift that cost to your final per-book price \u2026 which can result in a hardcover being priced at $40 or more.\nThe major difference is in the type of binding process that is used, and cover materials. Besides the fact that they might pay for a bit?", "topic_list": ["Self-Publishing", "Amazon Kindle (product)", "Book Publishing", "Publishing", "eBooks", "Books"], "no_of_view": "3,614", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 8, 1, 0, 1, 0, 3, 0, 0, 2, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Free cover design. They put PR into Publisher\u2019s Weekly and Library Journal announcing new releases.", "Let\u2019s extend this argument.\nYou can put the book on Kindle, so you don\u2019t need the expertise of a publisher to market it.\nYou can print the book yourself, so you don\u2019t even need a print firm for paper copies\nYou can make paper yourself from plants in your garden, so you don\u2019t even need to buy paper\nYou can make ink from other plants, so you don\u2019t need to buy ink for your printer\nYou don\u2019t need to buy a printer, because you can hand-copy each copy of your book with your pen\nYou don\u2019t need to buy a pen, because you can dip a sharp stick into your home-made ink\nYou don\u2019t need to buy a knife to sharpen the stick, because you can bash stones against each other until one is sharp enough to create a point on your stick\nEach of these steps represents another link in the \u201ctime for money\u201d chain.\nYou may decide that the value that a publisher adds doesn\u2019t equal the costs they\u2019ll incur, and self-publish.\nI have a couple of things with a traditional publisher, and a couple self-published. The traditional publisher came first - they got my name out (in a niche market) in front of lots of prospective customers\u2026 many, on buying my first book, signed up to a mailing list I ran. Many of the sales of my second book came from people on that mailing list.\nI made more money on the second than on the first\u2026. but much more money on the second because the publisher had got me out in front of the audience.\nIf you already have tens of thousands of followers, you probably don\u2019t need a publisher for your first book.", "You already gave the single greatest advantage, in your question: Venture capital.\nYou think you can edit, design, and market your own books? What training have you had? What experience do you have, to make you so confident of your own abilities?", "Please clarify what you mean.", "If you mean a reputable commercial press vs. self publishing, a myriad of reasons.\nPublishing at a professional level is expensive, and not just because of the team. You also have experienced marketing, agreements with Ingraham and other forms of distribution. A publisher understands how to reach readers.\nWould you rather have 70% of $100, or 7% of $10,000 dollars?", "As they have been the 35 years I\u2019ve been in the biz, things are making a seminal change again due to this cover thing. So who knows, but as I\u2019ve often said, with a brink and mortar NY publisher you are likely to have 250 salespeople in the field pushing your book, in addition to being on the web.", "There are several points.\nFirst: it is much harder to get a self-published book into physical bookstores than it is through a traditional publisher. You probably won\u2019t ever get into markets like Target, Wal-Mart, grocery stores, or airports either. Together, this still comprises about 60% of all book sales in the US, and it\u2019s a whole lot more in most other countries.\nSecond: Since I mentioned other countries, it\u2019s much more likely for a traditionally published book to be translated into other languages and sold in those territories. Foreign publisher and language rights are in many cases substantial sources of income.\nThird: A traditional publisher pays you up-front advance money. You don\u2019t have to pay it back if the book doesn\u2019t sell to those expectations. The publisher pays for professional cover art and book design, registers copyright in your name, pays for professional content and copy editing, marketing, distribution, and promotion. You are not required to pay anything. You can (and likely should) supplement their efforts, but it isn\u2019t a requirement.\nFourth: it is extremely difficult for a self-published title to hit a major recognized bestseller list. Hitting a major list (and not just an hourly sales list on Amazon, but their Top 50 weekly list does count) helps raise your profile, helps get you invited to paid speaking engagements, workshops, special closed anthologies and projects.\nFifth: it\u2019s important to know where your potential audience \u201clives\u201d in terms of where it shops for books. From a 2019 Pew Research article:\nFiction leads with 25% ebook purchases as of 2019. But, for instance, romance readers have more heavily adopted ebooks (to about 60%) and SF/F readers are about 40%. If you\u2019re writing a children\u2019s book, overwhelmingly print. Even upper YA is still mostly print.\nSo where are your readers, in that scenario? Is ebook only where you need to be?\nI have absolutely nothing against self publishing, it\u2019s a viable and workable career choice. I have friends who make great sales there and work very hard at it. But to be successful you need to think not just like a writer, but a publisher, and make all the right business decisions that entails.\nI just prefer working mostly in traditional.", "A traditional book publisher has a much larger network and advertising budget.", "A publisher employs editors, cover designers, and marketers\nA publisher can get your book into bookstores\nA publisher can get your book into libraries\nA publisher can pay an advance\nA publisher handles accounting and taxes\nA publisher can promote your book at trade shows and events", "Okay. \u201cYou can market online yourself?\u201d You have to commit a budget for that. You have to know what you are doing. You have to put in a LOT of time.\nWe are traditionally published, and our publisher has invested in our first two books. We partner with them on marketing opportunities that would cost us a lot more to do on our own, and we are benefiting from their experience and connections.\nYou really should not post about things you don\u2019t know anything about, or is that what Quora is for?", "Marketing.", "You can make more if its a best seller either through a publisher or Amazon."], "date_list": ["Apr 24, 2020", "Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Aaron David", "view_list": [15, 250, 30, 1, 23, 23, 114, 7, 0, 39, 11, 5]}, "615": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 8, "name_list": ["Robert Oreilly", "Sam Moss", "Margaret Carter", "Momina Ali", "Adedoyin Justus", "Rae Ann McCardell", "David Flowers", "James Martin"], "question_title": "Are difficult novels necessarily better?", "topic_list": ["Novel Recommendations", "Novels", "Literature", "Reading", "Books"], "no_of_view": "1,732", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 2, 0, 0, 2, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["For years I used war and peace as a door stop\u2026June was a flutter month\u2026", "As some one who enjoys certain \u2018difficult novels\u2019 I feel very comfortable saying that difficult novels are by no means inherently better than more simple novels.\nThere are a few reasons that a writer will choose to make their novel more difficult, generally by making it more \u2018dense\u2019; including allusions to other works, philosophy etc.; or using obscure or challenging techniques.\nOccasionally the writers are doing this to convey specific ideas. Other times\u2014most of the time really\u2014the writer is just doing it because they enjoy doing it and they are writing the book for others who enjoy the challenge.\nVery occasionally writers do it just to be difficult, though I suspect that this happens less frequently than people suspect.\nReally \u2018difficult novels\u2019 are just a certain set of styles or techniques that certain people enjoy, just in the same sense that challenging foods (like lutefisk, kim-chi or natto) are enjoyed by some, but not by all. Even people who go to Michelin starred restaurants can enjoy a bag of fritos every now and then.\nFiction is, first and foremost, meant to be enjoyed. It is the mode of enjoyment that differs. People who enjoy drug store romance novels get something out of those novels and people who delve deep into Pynchon get something else. Each gets enjoyment, just different a kind.\n(I will say, as a side note, that difficult novels tend to \u2018last longer\u2019 i.e. they are generally appreciated for a longer period of time than more simply novels. With a few exceptions (like Charles Dickens) very few people, outside of scholars maybe, read popular fiction from the 1920\u2019s though James Joyce\u2019s notably difficult \u2018Ulysses\u2019 is still widely bought, read and studied.)", "No. Some authors seem to write on a \u201cdifficult\u201d level solely to be confusing for the sake of confusion, under the mistaken idea that the answer to the above question is \u201cYes.\u201d And some \u201cdifficult novels\u201d are that way because the author lacks the skills to write with clarity and lucidity. It\u2019s also true, of course, that some books are difficult because they\u2019re grappling with inherently complicated issues.\nOTOH, in the realm of nonfiction, numerous highly talented popular-science writers demonstrate that it\u2019s possible to explain very difficult concepts in a style that any intelligent reader can understand. E.g., in the past, Isaac Asimov, and in the present, Steven Pinker and Richard Dawkins (whose view of religion is detestable to me, but whose ability to explain concepts such as the \u201cselfish gene\u201d is brilliant).", "Not necessarily!", "Yeah, difficult novels are better cause it make men think clearly instead of deeply. it most times gives solutions to the day to day activities of life.", "Difficult novel aren't necessarily better on their own, there are a lot of factors. Some of the factors include:\nWhat are you in the mood to read? Personally, sometimes I want to be both challenged and entertained. Sometimes I want to simply escape and just enjoy.\nWhere is the book on your reading level?\nA book that is slightly above your level will challenge you and expand your vocabulary. A book that is too far beyond will frustrate you, and not in a good way.\nFinally, there are two main ways a book can be difficult. Reading level is one, topic and content is another. If the problem is reading level\u2014see above. If the book is within your scope but challenges the way you think or believe \u2014read it. Seeing things from a different perspective is fantastic. I've read it all the way through but really struggle to get my head about it.", "topic_list": ["House of Leaves", "Book Plots", "Book/Novel Plot and Themes", "Plot (narrative)", "Novels", "Literature", "Reading", "Books"], "no_of_view": "586", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [2], "ans_list": ["House of Leaves as I understand it is about coming to peace with yourself and others.\nJohnny\u2019s quest mirrors the Navidson\u2019s quest in the House. The labyrinths, paranoia, fear, and death that the Navidson\u2019s encounter in the House mirrors the madness, paranoia, fear, and death that Johnny deals with after he finds the manuscript (which is about the House).\nBoth Johnny and the Navidson\u2019s are dealing with unresolved issues that the House forces them to confront. Johnny has unresolved issues with his late mentally-ill mother. The Navidson family is, beneath the surface, falling apart and beset by jealousy and hatred. The House (and the manuscript which the House acts through) forces them all to confront these things. Johnny falls into the same mental illness that his mother does; the Navidson\u2019s confront their issues in order to survive (I\u2019ll avoid spoiler details here). All characters must descend to the lowest depths imaginable (literally in the case of the Navidson\u2019s) in order to come up \u201cclean.\u201d\nThe House isn\u2019t exactly the good guy here, because it extracts a terrible price from everyone, and not everyone survives long enough to be saved, but by the end of the novel the issues besetting the main characters are all resolved\u2026 one way or another.\nThe closest-but-not-quite-right parallel to the House, is Purgatory.\nI have another answer about House of Leaves here: Ke'Aun Charles's answer to What is your interpretation of House of Leaves?"], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "C.E. Tidswell", "view_list": [104]}, "630": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Zubair Simonson"], "question_title": "Why do most of Dostoyevsky\u2019s novels have a Christian bent?", "topic_list": ["Fyodor Dostoyevsky (author)", "Russian Literature", "Novels", "Writers and Authors", "Literature", "Christianity", "Books"], "no_of_view": "607", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["Because Fyodor Dostoevsky himself had a very Christian bent.\nDostoevsky had, throughout his life, his share of various struggles - with imprisonment, loss of a child, gambling addiction, extra-marital affairs\u2026etc. He also keenly observed himself and those around him. And, over the years, he had a growing conviction in the Gospels, and through struggles and interactions, an understanding of the scope and meaning of the Gospels. All of this helped mold a literary genius.\nThe works of Dostoevsky are very much Christian. But his works aren\u2019t necessarily dismissed as \u201cChristian stories\u201d because a character who is an atheist, someone who might be one-dimensional and only there to be proven wrong (such as the atheist professor in the film God\u2019s Not Dead) in all too many Christian stories, isn\u2019t given the treatment of a straw man in Dostoevsky\u2019s works. A character such as Ivan Karamazov gets a chance to fully explain himself. And though a Dostoevsky novel and \u201cChristian story\u201d may come to a similar conclusion, how they arrive at that same conclusion, specifically Dostoevsky\u2019s inclusiveness of personal struggles and other points of view, can spell the difference between a literary gem and mere propaganda."], "date_list": ["Apr 15, 2020"], "question_author": "Christopher Mogni", "view_list": [55]}, "580": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Jack Crawford", "James Russell", "John Averill"], "question_title": "Besides its politics, is Ayn Rand's Atlas Shrugged a good novel?", "topic_list": ["Atlas Shrugged (1957 book)", "Objectivism", "Ayn Rand (author)", "Novels", "Books"], "no_of_view": "1,697", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [3, 3, 0], "ans_list": ["There is very little actual politics in the novel. We shall take up 4 the Internet developments for the time being.\nref: Ref: http://www.history.com/topics/inventions/invention-of-the-i\nion-of-the-internet is very useful and the steps therein are taken up in the write up below:\nStarting from the fears of lagging in Technology in the minds of Americans due to Sputnik ( 1957) a space ball launched by erstwhile USSR, the journey took through various steps and lead to what is now being called \u201cInformation Technology(IT)\u201d. They are:\n1.Though Sputnik has nothing to do with telephone\nconnections ,American fears were that there will be large scale attack on communications of USA.\n2.NASA together with American defense increased its\nresearch efforts and Academics also put their thinking into the problem.\n3.American Research Project Agency ( ARPA) took some shape to connect computers enabling them to speak to each other even from distances. An MIT scientist Licklider, (ARPA inclusive)proposed a galactic network but there was not so much of yield-1962\n4. In 1965 M.I.T. developed \u201cpacket switching\u201d that breaks data down into blocks,or packets, before sending it to its destination computer.Each packet can take its own route from place to place.That reduced the vulnerability.\n5. \u201cLOGIN\u201d- A computer from UCLA could send \u201cLO\u201d\nthe first two letters to Stanford but ARPA crashed-1969.\u201dNode to Node\u201d- concept was taking shape.\n6. By 1969 four computers were connected to the ARPAnet.But the network grew steadily in 70\u2019s.\n7. In 1971, it added the University of Hawaii\u2019s ALOHAnet, and two years later it added networks at London\u2019s University College and the Royal Radar Establishment in Norway. As packet-switched computer networks multiplied, however, it became more difficult for them to integrate into a single worldwide \u201cinternet.\u201d- Ref: http://www.history.com/topics/inventions/invention-of-the-i\nion-of-the-internet\n8. By the end of the 1970s, a computer scientist named Vinton Cerf had begun to solve this problem by developing a way for all of the computers on all of the world\u2019s mini-networks to communicate with one another. He called his invention \u201cTransmission Control Protocol,\u201d or TCP. (Later, he added an additional protocol, known as \u201cInternet Protocol.\u201d The acronym we use to refer to these today is TCP/IP.) One writer describes Cerf\u2019s protocol as \u201cthe \u2018handshake\u2019 that introduces distant and different computers to each other in a virtual space.\u201d\n9. The World Wide Web\nCerf\u2019s protocol transformed the internet into a worldwide network. Throug 80\u2019s files and data were transferred successfully between computers.\nIn1991 the internet took further shape.Tim Berners-Lee from Switzerland introduced the World Wide Web: an internet that was not simply a way to send files from one place to another.But it was itself a \u201cweb\u201d of information that anyone on the Internet could retrieve too.Thus Berners-Lee was in a way the creator of the Internet that we use today.\nSince then, the internet has changed in many ways. In 1992, a group of students and researchers at the University of Illinois developed a sophisticated browser that they called Mosaic. (It later became Netscape.) Mosaic offered a user-friendly way to search the Web: It allowed users to see words and pictures on the same page for the first time and to navigate using scrollbars and clickable links.\nThere was realization that information plays role and in itself and by itself can be called a technology.Universities started thinking whether\nInformation Technology can be a subject of study at teaching.\nHence,approximately 1960-1990 can be called the incubation period of\nInformation Technology. Not surprisingly the role of USSR was almost negligible as they did not play any role. Copy cats were there all over on which we read often\nThat same year1992,, Congress decided that the Web could be used for commercial purposes. As a result, companies of all kinds hurried to set up websites of their own, and e-commerce entrepreneurs began to use the internet to sell goods directly to customers. More recently, social networking sites like Facebook have become a popular way for people of all ages to stay connected.Added to these the developments in e-mail,mobile phone,software,data science,tablet,i-Pad,touch screen technology etc., made the present world."], "date_list": ["Apr 16, 2020"], "question_author": "Tiyenn Infotech", "view_list": [13]}, "406": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Bryan Calkin", "David Micah Ferola", "Arthur Foley"], "question_title": "What are the best non-academic books on physics for busy people?", "topic_list": ["Physics Book Recommendations", "Reading", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Physics"], "no_of_view": "863", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1], "ans_list": ["In addition to Stephen Hawking\u2019s \u201cA Briefer History of Time\u201d, there are three YouTube channels I would highly recommend. There are a lot of bestseller lists.\nThe New York Times is the big one, but USA Today, Publisher\u2019s Weekly, and Amazon have their own. They each calculate sales differently, so though there\u2019s usually agreement on who made the list, there are differences in where they fall and a few discrepancies. Within the lists there are even more lists. There\u2019s the overall list, then categories for hardbacks and trade paperbacks and ebooks. There\u2019s non-fiction and within fiction there are dozens of genres. A book may have ranked #2786th overall, but #1 for Steampunk Romance so it qualifies as a bestseller.\n#2. A bestseller is a bestseller forever.\nIf a book hit number one in a category for exactly one week due to an organized push by the fandom (has happened), it\u2019s a number one forever. You can bet your buttermilk biscuits that publishing house is going to advertise that fact from now into eternity, because in the oversaturated market of literature, sellers need every edge they can conjure. Meanwhile, as a wise sage once said, the years start coming and they don\u2019t stop coming. Bestsellers from March 2020 compete with bestsellers from August 2016, and February 2012, and June 1994. That\u2019s a lot of bestsellers.\n#3. Limited shelf space.\nEach book takes up a little real estate, and book stores have overheads. They have to move product, and books that moved before are more likely to move again. It\u2019s not that they hate Indy houses or self published authors, but they have an easier time selling Tess Gerritsen and W.E.B. Griffin than they do Joe Bob Local. You see a lot of bestsellers in stores because they sell.", "\u201cEvery book\u201d doesn\u2019t. The ones that do claim that draw one\u2019s attention because they are so prominently displayed."], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Curious Hydra", "view_list": [11, 1]}, "344": {"no_of_follower": 7, "respond_collected": 6, "name_list": ["Ralph Brew", "Martin Hill", "Laurel Callahan", "Patrick Ashby", "Nisala Rodrigo", "Evan Askew"], "question_title": "Does it bother you that the final, climactic battles of all the three main Tolkien books end the same way, with the Great Eagles coming out of nowhere to save the losing army?", "topic_list": ["The Hobbit (1937 book)", "The Hobbit (creative franchise)", "The Silmarillion (1977 book)", "The Lord of the Rings (books)", "J. But their arrival at the battle of five armies does not tip the balance though it helps. It is the arrival of Beorn the giant man who can transform into a bear that really turns the tide. The word appears in the Yajurveda Samhitas in passages used for appeasing natural forces.\nThe various Puranas, Dharmashastras, Harivamsha & Mahabharata also refer to Viplava.\nWe can see that the word plava (\u092a\u094d\u0932\u0935\u0903) originally meant \u201cwashed away, float away\u201d, and later on was associated with many kinds of disasters.\nThe word Samplava refers to a devastating natural flood, it is seen to be used in the sense of \u201cutter destruction of everything\u201d including society, knowledge, wealth and is used as a \u201ccivilisational destruction\u201d. On the other hand \u201cViplava\u201d, though originally referred to some form of flood, is used in various books to refer to one or two kinds of destruction in society, and appears to be a milder form of destruction.\nThe after affections of such various kinds of societal and civilisational destruction is referred to so commonly in ancient literature that there appears to be a deep awareness of past natural disasters. The word \u0936\u093f\u0937\u094d\u091f\u093e\u0903, which means \u201cexemplery people\u201d, is a word used all over India. The literal meaning of it, \u201cleftover people\u201d, is intriguing and is found to point to the same awareness of natural disaster after which few remaining people end up being those with knowledge of the past which can be used by the survivors."], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Harish Kumar Anchuri", "view_list": [17]}, "334": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "If tan2\u03b8=1\u2212a2, prove that sec\u03b8+tan3\u03b8cosec \u03b8= (2\u2212a2) 3/2- From which book this question is given?", "topic_list": ["Inverse Trigonometric Functions", "Trigonometry Homework Question", "Proofs (mathematics)", "Trigonometry (mathematics)", "Calculus", "Numbers (mathematics)", "Algebra", "Books", "Mathematics"], "no_of_view": "312", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Badal Panchani", "view_list": []}, "601": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 5, "name_list": ["Brad Chisholm", "Ella James", "David Baer", "Michael Lowrey", "Jason Criddle"], "question_title": "Is there a way to tell how much money an author made from a book?", "topic_list": ["Book Publishing", "Publishing", "Writers and Authors", "Making Money Online", "Writing", "Salaries and Wages", "Wanting and Making Money", "Books", "Money"], "no_of_view": "1,307", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 1, 0], "ans_list": ["And this is your business how?", "If it hit one of the bestseller lists or the Amazon top 25 overall, you can make assumptions about its sales numbers and do backward math to attempt to calculate how much it made. But what that won\u2019t tell you is what the author spent. I had a book make the USA Today list once, and I only spent about $800. People loved this book; word of mouth carried it far. Alternately, I\u2019ve been in anthologies before that made the same list, but the authors spent thousands on ads. I would say you could track a given book\u2019s Amazon rankings from day one through day 60 (and guess at income based on what is known about how many sales lead to that ranking) and check the author\u2019s Facebook business page to look at how many FB ads they have running, but that wouldn\u2019t enable you to see Amazon ads on the book. You could check out all comparable books and see if the book you\u2019re tracking was advertising on those pages or on those search keywords. But none of these things gives you worthwhile data about what the author is actually spending on ads. So I\u2019m going to say no. You have no way of knowing what an author made on a given title \u2014 not unless you know the author personally or share mutual friends. Even then, you don\u2019t know unless you\u2019ve seen their bank account or tax returns. Because people lie. \ud83e\udd37\ud83c\udffb\u200d\u2640\ufe0f", "There\u2019s no way of knowing the complete income from a book, but if you\u2019d like to know how much a book might be making on Amazon based on its ranking, this is a pretty useful tool.: Amazon Sales Rank Calculator", "Nope. John tends to cover what the other Gospels did not write about, such as the wedding at Cana in John 2.", "The strong consensus of New Testament scholars is that Second Peter was written towards the middle of the second century, making it probably the last of the New Testament books written. The author goes out of his way to insist that he is Peter, perhaps too much so. He not only names himself Simeon Peter (1:1), not realising that the real Simon Peter would never have called himself Simeon (the Hebrew translation from Aramaic), but stresses that he was personally present with Jesus on the mount at the transfiguration (1:16-19). The author then slips up when he refers to \u201cyour\u201d apostles*, as if aware that he was not one of them.\nWhen 2 Peter 3:16 refers to Paul\u2019s epistles and \u2018other\u2019 scriptures as if Paul\u2019s epistles are already scripture, it demonstrates that this epistle was written quite long after Paul wrote his epistles.\n* Most English translations follow the Greek, but the KJV Bible says \u201cthe\u201d apostles.", "We will never know for sure. Revelation was written around 95 AD when John was a prisoner on Patmos due to Domitian. He was released in 96 by Domitian\u2019s successor, Nerva and returned to Ephesus. It is believed that he then wrote the Gospel and his three letters. Assuming the early church knew the order of the letters, it would then be Third John as the last book written.", "A common error is suggesting the Book of Revelation was written last merely because it is supposedly about the future (although one theory is that it was code for present times written when Christians were being persecuted). But the notion that literature is written chronologically is a logical fallacy \u2014 hint: science fiction novels taking place in the 1980s were generally written well before the 1980s and not necessarily later than any contemporary novels taking place in the 1960s.\nIt is estimated Revelation was written around 95 AD, whereas some of the Epistles (e.g. the Second Epistle of Peter) are dated to around 100 to 110 AD. Other parts, including the Gospel of John, may have been written later. That field was popularized with B.F. Skinner\u2019s books. SHOULD pupils read a lot in the summer? Heck yes! (Tell me if I\u2019m wrong here, but I am surmising you are wondering if your educational system - your school or your teachers - should \u201cmake you read during the summer\u201d, yes?)\nWell, consider the following that is largely undebatable: The more one reads, the more one generally becomes more intelligent. The more intelligent the person becomes, the more likely he/she will make informed decisions. The more we have people making informed decisions, the more likely we as a society should do well and thrive.\nThe basic definition of ignorance is \u201clack of knowledge or information\u201d or, in short: not knowing. I tell my middle school students in my class called \u201cSkills for Adolescents\u201d we don\u2019t want young ignorant kids (yeah, it sounds like a putdown but it\u2019s not; kids don\u2019t know much - yet) becoming ignorant adults. The whole purpose of mandated education is to become educated, which means becoming less ignorant than if they didn\u2019t go to school at all. (Almost every country on the planet mandates education. Why? Do some research and find which countries DO NOT mandate education and learn what the effect is on both those kids that are forced to stay ignorant and to the countries in which they live.) I tell my students us old people die and the younger generations must then run the countries, and that they better quickly understand that they don\u2019t want ignorant people being our leaders. (Just look a the mess the United States is currently dealing with, both in leadership and those in the general populace that blindly follow.) Again, this statement is largely undebatable: we need (or society would benefit from) more intelligent people, not fewer.\nSo, questioner, I do not know your age, but if you are NOT WANTING to read during the summer, I get that. However, I suggest you pay attention to the trends in employment and education and how those individuals with low skill sets (meaning \u2018ignorant\u2019) are finding it harder and harder to find good-paying jobs. Ask people you know who are older and employed (or better yet, unemployed!) to see if what I am saying is true. This trend is only going to accelerate, according to people who are way smarter than me. The better-paying jobs will surely go to those who are the most skilled, the better read, the least ignorant. The wannabe worker will have to offer some employer something, some skill that will help the employer run a business, and if someone else has more skills and knowledge (less ignorant) to offer than you, who is going to get the job?\nFinally, I truly hope you can start to see the question is not if it is \u201cwrong\u201d to \u201cmake\u201d you read over the summer, it\u2019s how you can help yourself become less ignorant (again, not intended as an insult - sorry if you take it that way) so your opportunities for a successful life after school increase. So, please go find yourself stuff to read. There is a whole world\u2019s worth of knowledge out there to help you make the most of this summer.\nP.S. Ooooops - I almost forgot what surely will be included in other responders\u2019 replies, which is that reading really should be looked at as a pleasurable, desirable pastime, not something to be considered an assignment or a chore. Our librarian would say perhaps you have yet to find a good author. I would enlarge that to include you may have not yet found the right genre or subject matter! :)", "It\u2019s never wrong to have high expectations.", "not only in summer the responsible should plan lessons for pupils and reading or studying a lot also hurt them."], "date_list": ["Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Sabina", "view_list": [7, 2, 45, 9, 17]}, "387": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Juan Espinosa"], "question_title": "What human psychology books are recommended for human resources professionals?", "topic_list": ["Psychology Books", "Human Psychology", "Human Resource Management", "Human Resources", "Psychology", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Human Behavior"], "no_of_view": "401", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [1], "ans_list": ["Emotional Intelligence: Why It Can Matter More Than IQ, by Daniel Goleman is a good one."], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Andrew Bonsu", "view_list": [32]}, "368": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "I'm a TE mechanical engineer. I usually do this.\nSome books I read for fun and to relax at the end of the day. Some are more serious books which require concentration and making some notes. Some books I read only when I\u2019m not in a good mood. This usually happens with everybody you know as a reader. If i don\u2019t know the genre i would love to read, i will end up switching from one book to another without having taste of the content the previous one contained.\nFor this, one needs to find out the personal interest like what you actually want to read. If you have no interest in, say sciences, but after someone\u2019s suggestion, you have been carrying a \u2018Stefan King\u2019s\u2018 book at hand, and you know the consequence. Your mind would say no to this torture you are forcing your mind to bear. And after this, you would end up thinking that it\u2019s your problem of mind that it can\u2019t read what you want it to.\nActually this is not the problem of your mind. But if you command a fish to fly despite knowing the fact that it can\u2019t, then it would never be able to fly, no matter how much hard work you do behind this impossible task in the hope of making it possible. Similarly, If you give the wrong stuff to your mind despite knowing the fact that you actually don\u2019t like it or you have no interest /passion/ craziness/ curiosity to read that book, then your eyes may read the book but the mind would never receive the information in, and it(information) would not be transcended down to your heart. If our mind gets the information it loves to be surrounded by, it sends all the stuff word by word down to your heart and then to every drop of blood flowing in arteries and veins. It gives a peculiar joy, peace of mind and happiness. Hence reading makes a person more satisfied and contented with his/her life, making him/her the center of attraction for the people present around.\nSo decide the genre your mind would welcome and you will see yourself enjoying the process of reading.\nHope this would help\nThank you!"], "date_list": ["Apr 17, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020"], "question_author": "Namra Waris", "view_list": [256, 89]}, "431": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Which book is good in gastrointestinology for medical students?", "topic_list": ["Medical Books", "Gastroenterology", "Medical Students", "Medical School", "Doctors", "Reading", "Higher Education", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Medicine and Healthcare"], "no_of_view": "558", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Ali Ghasemi", "view_list": []}, "83": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "How long is the Angels and Demons book?", "topic_list": ["Angels & Demons (2009 movie)", "Angels and Demons", "Angels (supernatural beings)", "Demons (malicious preternatural beings)", "Christianity", "Book Recommendations", "Books"], "no_of_view": "905", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Cozma Dan Claudiu", "view_list": []}, "98": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Devika Mehrotra"], "question_title": "What are some dead simple books or videos to understand psychology?", "topic_list": ["Psychology Books", "Human Psychology", "Cognitive Psychology", "Reading", "Psychology", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Psychology of Everyday Life"], "no_of_view": "569", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["Baron is a good book and Cyselleri is also a very good book if you are interested in psychology. Speech and learning disabilities show up and then can be handled by the instructors and parents. Speech and learning problems can include inability to detect words, problems with making sounds, inability to project, like of understanding pronunciation rules, slurring words, etc. This is one area parents should help children early by reading to them really young, speaking to them in adult language and explaining vocabulary and then letting them speak, read and ask questions.\nSometimes personality issues like excessive shyness or cultural difficulties need special handling. But if teachers and parents start early encouraging asking questions, providing answers and reading outloud, it becomes much easier for children to do so.\nIt teaches listeners to respect speakers and patience because there are those who want to demand attention, control discussions, interrupt progress, and or tell people what to think. Communication is an essential skill for human survival and it shouldn't be underrated.\nA round table approach combined with a random way of requiring everyone to participate helps the group to prepare. And that means wading through a lot of faulty assumptions, revisionist history, a fairly radical reframing of facts, and a lot of bad math.\nIf you want to go all the way back to what supposedly informs modern right-leaning economic ideas, read Adam Smith\u2019s Wealth of Nations. Not only will you be able to better understand the (classical economics) roots of many conservative ideas about the desired goals of economic, governmental, and social arrangements, but you will see how modern neoliberal proposals and experiments (Hayek, Friedman, Mises) depart rather radically from those first principles.\nTo preserve your own sanity, and keep your brain free of outrageous distortions of reality, I would generally avoid the Austrian School and Chicago School folks \u2014 or, if you must, then focus on Hayek; although he completely misunderstands socialism, he has some interesting and applicable ideas about information and economic decision-making \u2014 such as can be found in his \u201cEconomics and Knowledge\u201d lecture/chapter.\nMany modern writers (like Thomas Sowell) have burrowed so far down the rabbit hole their brains appear to be broken. Reading Sowell (or Friedman, for that matter) is really no different than reading a propaganda pamphlet of a bizarre cult member \u2014 or like reading Ayn Rand.\nBut if you truly want to understand the core values and goals of neoliberal ideology \u2014 as nakedly and directly as possible \u2014 then I do highly recommend studying James M. Buchanan and the Virginia School. Here is a competent overview of his legacy: Meet the Economist Behind the One Percent\u2019s Stealth Takeover of America\nLastly, I\u2019ll leave you with my most positive recommendation of the mix, and that is Robert Nozick. Although a philosopher and not an economist, his musings are pretty relevant to modern right-libertarian and market fundamentalist ideals that persist today. I\u2019m always impressed by his clarity of thought\u2026and something else you will not find in Rothbard, Mises, Friedman et al: intellectual honesty. Nozick can admit when his own thinking reaches either a dead end, or an outrageous conclusion \u2014 those other thinkers simply can\u2019t see their own logical fallacies and failings in this regard. You could start with Anarchy, State and Utopia and work outwards from there. However, I do recommend reading John Rawls Theory of Justice to understand what Nozick is responding to in that work.\nMy 2 cents.", "Economics in one lesson. Thanks for A2A.\nYes, of course I read preface, foreword even the acknowledgments and any other text written in the book other than the obvious. (I even check the isbn number, just out of habit!)\nI am always interested in knowing the process of making good books. The story/content which manages to make us engrossed so easily, all the hardwork, planning, thought process that goes for creating that piece is the real treat when it comes to know about the magic of creating that book.\nWe get insights of that exact process through the foreword, prefaces etc. Acknowledgments tells us the various kinds of people it takes to make that book as it finally turns out.\nAlso, we come to know some aspects of the author's view of that book. I feel, it's very important for the reader to know the author's perspective or the idea behind the story/content of the book.\nAnd finally, it gives me the satisfaction of readjng the book from the front cover to the end cover!\nHappy Reading!", "Depends on how interesting and relevant it is.\nThe foreword usually has a history lesson about the author. I don\u2019t read that part of most books unless something in it intrigues me or if I have a special interest in the author\u2019s life.\nPreface and intro - I skim through it. Preface, too, has a story of how the book came to be. I feel like authors write it because it is very much an integral part of their book and what went into writing it or conjuring it, but it may or may not be relevant to the reader.\nI mean if I ever wrote a book, I would definitely include how I came about it and what went into writing it, the ups and downs because from my point of view they are how my story started, but the reader may not care and may directly jump into the story.\nTo each his own, I say.\nI do however love reading dedications. Usually, Preface includes the story about how the author came about writing the fiction/nonfiction. It is essential to know their opinions and situations, or why they thought they could tell a story.\nThe foreword isn\u2019t by the author, but by someone they think is an authority figure for them. They present their thoughts for the ideas and intentions that underpin the book. If there is any question that a foreword might answer, then it is \u2018why I think you need to read this work by this author.\u2019", "They're integral parts of the story used by authors to set the mood of the novel and to tease what's about to come. If you're reading authors like Dan Brown, the preface only adds to the story. If you're reading a classic, the novel usually begin with an essay by a renowned and celebrated author, editor, or literary figure even professors at times, to tell why the book has stood the test of time and why is the author or the book is so important to literature.\nPreface and forewards are what separate good books from terrible ones. This series introduces the reader to a fair amount of mythology, and begs the reader to ponder all of the happenings that escape out of sight. Morpheus, the mythological king of dreams, seems so very human, even in his coldness. There are multiple subplots that are masterfully woven.\nThere are, of course, other comic stories that are widely considered as deserving for consideration as literature. Fables, by Bill Willingham. Watchmen, by Alan Moore.\nComic book characters can be just as developed, and can do just as much to inform us about our selves, as regular book characters. We are all wounded like Batman. Plenty of us have a (perhaps profoundly selfish) thirst for revenge like the Punisher. On the Fourth of July we feel our hearts swell with the patriotism that Captain America embodies. We struggle to balance our lives like Spider-Man.\nYes, there are dumb comic books. But there is no shortage of dumb regular books either.\nMedium does not matter. Christ told his stories in parables, not regular books. Shakespeare wrote plays, not regular books. Comic books have simply had a shorter history than most other mediums.", "Yes, they are. Of course, as in any other form of art, the Sturgeon Law applies: 95% of anything is shit.\nAlso, to address what other answers have stated, you DO use your mind\u2019s eye when reading comics, that\u2019s how you know what happens beween one panel and the next, or what motion the characters are performing while delivering their dialogue.\nAlso, by reading comics, you learn to read all kind of subtleties which are impossible to convey on text only books. The already cited Watchmen is a prime example of that but there are thousands of others.", "\u201cJust as beneficial\u201d? One might need to define \u201cbeneficial\u201d in this context, but in general I believe the answer would be yes, with just two qualifying statements.\nQuality is important. I realize that separating excellent/good books and comic books from mediocre/poor books and comics is a subjective exercise, but some books might be more \u201cbeneficial\u201d (whatever is meant by that) than certain comic books while other comic books might be more beneficial than some books.\nBooks can cultivate one skill better than comic books: developing the reader\u2019s imaginative mind\u2019s eye. In comics, the visuals are there: no need for a reader to imagine (through the impact of the words on the page) in their minds what characters, places, etc. might look like.\nBut given the first qualifier and recognizing the second, I still think that comic books and books can engender equal benefits in all other circumstances.", "Watchmen is a graphic novel \u2014 a book-length comic book with ambitions above its station\u2014starring a ragbag of bizarre, damaged, retired superheroes: the paunchy, melancholic Nite Owl; the raving doomsayer Rorschach; the blue, glowing, near-omnipotent, no-longer-human Doctor Manhattan. Though their heyday is past, these former crime-fighters are drawn back into action by the murder of a former teammate, The Comedian, which turns out to be the leading edge of a much wider, more disturbing conspiracy. Told with ruthless psychological realism, in fugal, overlapping plotlines and gorgeous, cinematic panels rich with repeating motifs, Watchmen is a heart-pounding, heartbreaking read and a watershed in the evolution of a young medium.\nLev Grossman\nThat\u2019s from Time Magazine\u2019s 100 Greatest Novels of All Time\nBut the short answer is yep."], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 11, 2020", "Apr 11, 2020"], "question_author": "Neda Ery\u0131lmaz", "view_list": [70, 22, 24, 31]}, "23": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What are the Sonographic principles and instrumentation best review books?", "topic_list": ["Book Reviews", "Book Recommendations", "Books"], "no_of_view": "148", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Khaled Kullab", "view_list": []}, "498": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Which one book is Better in Handbook of Mathematics by I.N Bronshtein Or Handbook of Mathematics For scientist and engineers?", "topic_list": ["Handbooks", "Engineering and Mathematics", "Math Book Recommendations", "Mathematics Books", "Engineers", "Scientists", "Book Recommendations", "Engineering", "Books", "Mathematics"], "no_of_view": "94", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Ritik Shukla", "view_list": []}, "84": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Adwitiya Dixit"], "question_title": "Is 'The Mother I Never Knew: Two Novellas' the best book of all time?", "topic_list": ["Novellas", "Novels", "Book Recommendations", "Books"], "no_of_view": "249", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["I'm pretty sure it's not. Common symptoms include the uncontrollable urge to acquire and hoard books, indiscriminate bookstore hopping, and delusions of authorship. The more severe forms of bibliomania may involve recurring incidents of bibliokleptomania (book theft) and/or lying about supposed ownership of titles.\nNo cure is known to exist, but treatment to alleviate symptoms requires frequent and regular use of Project Gutenberg\nto read online or to download free e-books.", "Tsundoku - a Japanese word used to describe a person who owns a lot of unread literature.
