Bernstein, unlike many Broadway composers, did his own orchestrations, and he was a master. So many influences \u2014 Mahler, Stravinsky, Shostakovich \u2014 but he was a genius so it was all Bernstein. Talent borrows, genius steals. The book and lyrics were a collaboration: Stephen Sondheim, Lillian Hellman, Richard Wilbur. It is the wittiest musical there is. But Voltaire\u2019s characters are two-dimensional stereotypes. This satire is picaresque but not too engaging, it is a polemic. Please click below:", "The 4 main takeaways are:\nInvest in revenue-generating assets - Robert defines assets simply as something you own that puts money in your pocket. This could be a rental property, a profitable side business or a stock. The main principle of the book is to collect many of these revenue-generating assets over time so that your income from these assets is eventually greater than all your expenses.\nYour profession is not your business - If you are trained as a lawyer and work as a lawyer, then your profession is a lawyer. But your business is still the assets you acquire over your lifetime.\nLeverage corporations for tax reasons - Robert recommends buying your assets under an incorporated company in order to limit your liability and leverage some tax preferences.\nInvest in yourself - Invest in both your skills and knowledge. These will serve you for life and will enable to make better investments and a bigger variety of investments over time.\nThe final point is perhaps the most important. Rich mindset = Believes that the lack of money is the root of all evil, takes and manages risks, have multiple streams of income (passive and active).\nKnow the difference between assets and liabilities.\n\u201cIt is not important how much money you make; it is how much money you keep.\u201d\nDo not depend only on a salaried job or a single income source; else you would continue working for someone for your entire life.\nSources of passive income: Business profits, Dividends from stocks, Interest payments as an investor, Rent, Royalties etc.\nLearn to minimise taxes\nMaking full use of your time; everyone has a fixed amount of time daily, do not let it go to waste on unproductive tasks.\nWork to learn, don\u2019t work solely for the money if possible. There were 21 short stories, and five novellas, but none came close to equalling the first book.\nThe last of them was The Haunted Man and the Ghost\u2019s Bargain, a rather cumbersome title that did not sell as well as earlier Christmas novellas, and therefore became the final one. It is not the worst of them. Actually the far more popular Cricket on the Hearth is much worse. Still it is not a work that will appear on many people\u2019s lists of best Dickens works.\nThe action deals with a chemistry teacher called Radlaw, who is gloomily preoccupied with his past life. He regrets his many losses, and wishes that he could have his memory expunged of them. As it turns out, he can.\nRadlaw speaks with a mysterious spirit who seems suspiciously like an adjunct of himself. (Towards the end, even Dickens suggests the possibility that the spirit might be a representation of Radlaw\u2019s bad side, with the kindly servant Milly representing all that is good.)\nThe spirit tells Radlaw that he can make the chemist forget his past, or at least cancel the remembrance of what he felt. Radlaw (with a few misgivings) agrees to this, but there is a catch. Not only does Radlaw lose his own remembrances. He has the gift or curse of causing everyone in contact with him to experience the same thing.\nHe soon realises that this is no good thing at all. Writers often talk about the importance of memory as a source of identity, or the place where we learn things, or see our place in the world or in history. Dickens is making a different point.\nFor Dickens, possessing memory is what gives people warmth as humans. If we lose the capacity to remember the joyful moments we had with others in past life, then why should we feel tolerant with them in the bad times, or forgiving of the wrong they do?\nIf a woman\u2019s looks fade, or a man\u2019s health causes him to stoop, perhaps they will think they made a bad deal in marrying that person if they cannot remember how nice it has been to live with that person for all these years. Our memories of others are what helps us to love them and accept them with all their faults.\nForgiveness is important too. When one of the characters insists that we should remember all the wrongs done to us so that we can forgive them, it seems like a shallow point. Nonetheless there is something in it. How does forgiveness have any power without a memory of the wrong? Why help a person who once hurt you if you have no memories of the times when they behaved better?\nThe story works well on this level and puts across some interesting ideas. The characters are amusing, though none of them are especially memorable. The main weakness in the story comes in the last section.\nWe are told that the good-hearted Milly has a similar supernatural ability to restore people\u2019s kindness and memory by way of her innate warmth, albeit unconsciously. I suppose Dickens needed a solution, but what is he trying to say here?\nIs he implying that if you are bad to people, they will become bad, and if you behave well to people, they will become good? This is not totally wrong of course, but life is not really that simple, as we know. I can\u2019t single-handedly improve the morals of other people by my treatment of them, though it may have some slight impact.\nIt does not help that Milly could give Esther Summerson lessons in how to humblebrag. Like Esther in Bleak House, Milly is always commenting with apparent astonishment on how much everyone seems to like her. Dickens never learnt to realise that praise for his heroines does not work very well when it is the heroine herself who is telling us how much people esteem her.\nOverall though The Haunted Man and the Ghost\u2019s Bargain is a decent and imaginative minor Dickens story that only occasionally overdoes the sentimentality."], "date_list": ["Apr 14, 2020"], "question_author": "Dane John Cobain", "view_list": [62]}, "569": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What were controversies about the book 'Deyal (\u09a6\u09c7\u09df\u09be\u09b2)' by Humayun Ahmed?", "topic_list": ["Humayun Ahmed", "Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman", "Bengali Literature", "Politics of Bangladesh", "History Books", "Book Reviews", "Controversies", "Bangladesh", "Literature", "Books"], "no_of_view": "361", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Md. Almost every App Stores in the Android device provide the Kindle App for Android, including Google Play Store. The Complete guide can be concluded as the following steps.\nStep 1 Launch Kindle App for Android and register it with your Amazon Kindle account.\nIf you don't have an Amazon account yet, just create a new Amazon account.\nStep 2 Purchase (free) Kindle books to an Android phone/tablet (Internet connection required).\nIf you don't have any Kindle book, you can find many free books or purchase some books on Amazon website. Download the free Kindle app.", "Yes.\nDownload the Kindle app.\nYou need to buy from the Amazon site though, and the book is sent to your device."], "date_list": ["Apr 18, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Musabbir Niloy", "view_list": [2, 3, 12, 9, 4, 1, 32]}, "412": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Maria Radu", "Shrestha Anupam"], "question_title": "Which protagonist of a novel do you have sympathy for?", "topic_list": ["Sympathies", "Protagonist", "Novel Writing", "Fiction", "Novels", "Literature", "Books"], "no_of_view": "784", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [4, 1], "ans_list": ["The first 50 pages, I thought Albert Camus' famous novel, The stranger, was actually a poor disguise for an insipid and quite frankly insulting philosophy about how we should react to societal norms and the moral dichotomy of black-and-white thinking that has always been so popular with wide audiences.\n\nThe protagonist, Mersault, was a pretentious and insensitive young man, whose sole purpose in life seemed to be narrating daily events with as much blandness as one can muster. Any other character in the book was, of course, presented through his eyes, so it's hard to tell if these people were really as flawed and pathetic as Mersault saw them. Here, though, I began to question my previous dislike.\n\nMersault's background characters were indeed sinister - a girlfriend obsessed with the idea of love, a neighbor who constantly mistreated his old dog, a violent and abusive friend who regularly beat his own girlfriend. However, Mersault never judges any of them, nor tries to stop the behaviour. He analyses and comforts each one, regardless of how \u2018badly' they behave. Mersault is quite indiferrent to strong human emotion, but that is exactly what makes him a truly impartial person and somehow, the personification of objective truth. People say that is what they want, but in all honesty, objective truth is cruel and more often than not, it deforms the people who try to attain it.\n\nMersault is not a sociopath, he does not desire to hurt anyone. In his best moments, Mersault shines with neutral kindness, the likes of which most of us only see in children - when his mean neighbor loses his dog and comes crying to the protagonist's door, Mersault promises to help him find his pet. No show of weakness is too uncomfortable for Mersault, a trait that eventually becomes his demise.\n\n\u201c Mother died today.\u201d\n\nThe opening line of the novel has often been translated wrongly, with the 1946 version using the word \u201cmum\". There is little to no warmth in how Mersault speaks of his mother, explaining that they had long since run out of things to say to each other. The tragedy of a mismatched family of strangers, a peculiar maternal bond that never materialised is more common than people think. Families are often made up of people who have nothing in common with each other. Perhaps this is where Mersault's indifference is first nurtured.\n\nThe protagonist fails to cry at his mother's funeral and this is to be his crime. Make no mistake, Mersault actually commits a crime in the novel, but his lawyer candidly explains that no one could convict a white man for killing an Arab in this little idylic French colony in Africa. The same society that willingly condones racism is less forgiving of \"strange\" outsiders who do not like and are not moved by the same things as them. This is the irony of the book which Mersault bears until the end. For his truth, his otherness, he dies and refuses to pretend, even for his own salvation, to shed a tear at something he deems factual.\n\nIn his last moments, Mersault deeply scares the Catholic priest who offers him absolution - \"I had only a little time left and I didn't want to waste it on God\".\n\nMersault is unique; he recognises the thousands of millions of people who died as nobodies, forgotten in the grandeur of the world, passive and unremarkable and swallowed by time. Human history is nothing but a farce, a power play, a passing fancy and Mersault does not care if he goes down in history as a ruthless psychopath as long as he is true to himself.\n\nMersault is not bad and he is not good, but even if people want to pretend that moral standards have evolved since the Middle Ages, grey is one hell of an uncomfortable colour.\n\nI myself have always desired to become a lawyer. I cannot help but sympathise with Mersault - if a person is different, reacts differently, does this mean he no longer deserves a place in society?\n\n\" I opened myself to the gentle indifference of the world.\"", "There are innumerable protagonists that I feel sympathy for.\nThe emotion of sympathy for a character is evoked by authors through various ways. Primarily, losing a loved one, facing a difficult situation in life, losing a battle etc. are scenarios in which I feel sympathetic towards the protagonist.\nHarry Potter, Kaladin(from the Stormlight Archive), Severus Snape, Peeta (from The Hunger Games) are some of the characters for whom I have felt sympathy."], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Shalini Mishra", "view_list": [286, 120]}, "695": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Patrick Bouchaud"], "question_title": "Are Irvin D. Yalom\u2019s books philosophically correct? Do they hold any value other than fiction?", "topic_list": ["Philosophy Books", "Philosophers", "Fiction", "Doctor of Philosophy Degrees", "Philosophy", "Books"], "no_of_view": "631", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [1], "ans_list": ["I read The Schopenhauer Cure, which I loved - being quite the Schopenhauerist character myself - and offered to my ex-wife - who is a practicing Child Psychologist - afterwards. She told me a year later that after reading this one she had bought (and read) the whole collection of books written by this author.\nTo me the value of this book was to illustrate the difference between the theory and reality of helping people. That there is no \u2018miracle\u2019 cure, or method. And how the sessions evolve, the process taking a life of its own, as well as the challenges faced by the therapist as to when and how to get involved, and when not.\nI think this is particularly relevant in this time, when people expect and demand a miracle cure to be available for every ailment, and choose life to be suspended until such time as the authorities deem suitable rather than to deal with the problems as they present themselves, together."], "date_list": ["Apr 11, 2020"], "question_author": "Roozbeh Brown", "view_list": [44]}, "571": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What is the difference between Amazon and Behemoth?", "topic_list": ["Online Selling", "eBooks", "Amazon.com (product)", "Amazon (company)", "Online Shopping", "E-Commerce", "Books"], "no_of_view": "492", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Chris Franco", "view_list": []}, "607": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 15, "name_list": ["Julie Brooks", "Brenda Mahler", "Steven Hutson", "Preethi Krishna", "Wendy Crow", "Anthony Adam", "Linn Dyer Pierce", "Rachael Saltzman", "Stephen Hunter", "L. I really enjoy online books. If you don\u2019t have an e-reader books can be read on a laptop or phone (if you are younger than me). I compiled this list. Maybe it will help.\nIt was originally posted on my blog I AM My Best! (dot) org\nLibrary On-line Lending\nMust libraries allow patrons to borrow books on-line. With a library card you can log-in and check out a book and then read it on your phone, tablet, Kindle, computer . . .\nSchool Lending Library\nI am most familiar with WestAda school district but imagine most schools have a similar system. Students can visit their school\u2019s website, enter the virtual library and use their school email to check out a book.\nOur district uses Sora\nas the book server. If you are not sure if it is available in your area, Google \u201cSora\u201d. There will be a button \u201cFind my school\u201d that will allow you to investigate the possibility\nLibrary of Congress\nAt read.gov/books\nhundreds of books for kids, teens and adults. Many also are read aloud.\nOpen Library\nThis is INCREDIBLE!\nUntil I started investigation, I did not realize this was available. I discovered after signing up for an account, some great books can be read immediately. There were even a couple of new releases that I have been wanting to read. I know what I will be doing later today.\nThis site continues to add books to the shelves through sponsors who purchase a text and make it available to others. A must see.\nLili\n(Idaho Residents)\nEver wonder where all that money goes from taxes? This is an excellent resource for reading, research and how-to manuals. Below is a list of some excellent resources.\nWorld Book Kids \u2014 Includes games, short articles at lower reading levels, science projects, maps, pictures, videos, and educational activities.\nWorld Book Student \u2014 Similar to above but for older students\nNovelist \u2014 Just what it says a source for novels\nEBSCO \u2014 Research sites. This is invaluable if you are seeking information on a particular topic. AND, they are all peer reviewed which mean there is no fear of fake news. This can even be used by college students for some serious research.\nChilton Library \u2014 If you need to repair a vehicle, just type in the make, model and year to access step-by-step repair procedures, diagrams for troubleshooting, maintenance data, photos, and illustration. It has many features for car enthusiasts.\nThere is more so check it out so explore the options.\nThis site, Home Page\n, is sponsored by Idaho Commission for libraries and funded by the State of Idaho. However, if Idaho sponsors an online library, I imagine other state have one available also. It\u2019s your turn to investigate.\nAmazon\nNo, I am not employed by Amazon, but I have experienced what they have to offer firsthand. Through their \u201cKindle Free Books\u201d a person can access many enjoyable texts.\nHowever, not everything my husband and I wanted to read was free so after a year of purchasing books for our e-reader, we joined \u201cKindle Unlimited\u201d and now have endless options at our fingertips \u2014 from home. There is a small, monthly subscription.\nFurthermore, readers may consider purchasing an e-reader. We have Kindles. They even sell children\u2019s Kindles that are in plastic cases and simplified for use.", "At least a thousand online vendors will be happy to take your money, all day long.", "Simple. Kindle. What are some of the best books on quantum chromodynamics I can read?", "topic_list": ["Quantum Chromodynamics", "Physics Book Recommendations", "Theoretical Physics", "Quantum Mechanics", "Reading", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Physics", "Personal Question"], "no_of_view": "604", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["Being just an enthusiast does not embolden one to venture into intricacies of quantum field theory.\nYou ask books on quantum field theory because quantum chromodynamics is a quantum field theory of the strong interactions. Even conceptually, it way much higher than basic concepts of quantum mechanics with which you seem to aware of. You must first train yourself with \u201cbasic\" quantum field theory like the relativistic Klein-Gordon equation, or the Dirac equation. Then theory of free fields, then interactions, then Feynman diagrams, then propagators, then gauge fields,etc.\nQuantum chromodynamics is the last destination in the sequence of quantum field theory and beginning of the Standard Model. In view of your being an enthusiast in quantum physics, I would not (as of now), recommend books on quantum chromodynamics since they deal with formidable mathematics and conceptual sophistication as strong interactions are non-Abelian gauge theories and introduce additional complications over the abelian U(1) quantum electrodynamics.\nMeanwhile, I request you to read a very fine book, \u201c Quantum field theory for the gifted amateur\u201d by Lancaster. It gently introduces quantum field from basics of quantum mechanics. Read it! Later you can go through Griffiths book \u201c Introduction to elementary particles\u201d, which will be helpful as it describes the strong interactions in broad outline."], "date_list": ["Apr 11, 2020"], "question_author": "Akshi Dashottar", "view_list": [23]}, "77": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 6, "name_list": ["Bernard Mendoza", "Herbert Avrilaksky", "BJ Chippindale", "Kevin Donohue", "George Urban Isaacs", "David Micah Ferola"], "question_title": "Is economics a science? Braille letters are much larger than normal printed letters, so Braille books are much larger. A Braille novel may require 2 or 3 volumes, compared to a paperback or hard cover book. Very expensive to publish.", "Have you contacted any Braille publishers about this?", "The issue is not writing a book. The issue is can you get that book published in braille format as the first, original edition. And the issue here is that publishing is a business with profit as the motive, even with charitable support. If you can overcome the hurdles there is nothing to stop you trying.", "That\u2019s not how it works. Or do we ask what it means to us? What it\u2019s value is for a person\u2019s life?\nThe best written fiction - one form of imaginative invention - can draw these levels of human experience together. It uses story - plot and character moving through imagined time and space - to do this. By doing so it creates a world of possible alternative meanings, apart from the daily world, we would otherwise not see.\nA particular story invention may not resonate with every person - if it doesn\u2019t, for that person the story will remain boring or dead. For the next reader, the story may resonate with life experiences. So the invented story will resonate and have meaning, possibly very deeply.\nThe story and the reader have to be in sync for meaning to manifest. The great authors are the ones who write of such universal experiences, so deeply felt and understood and so well expressed in language, that this deep connection with human meaning keeps happening repeatedly in readers of the books, even over centuries and across cultures.\nRead War And Peace or The Brother\u2019s Karamazov and ask the question of the books.", "Yes, read The Alchemist\nand tell me you can\u2019t apply anything to your life. I know this book gets a lot of slack and people say it isn\u2019t that insightful, but I think that if you come in with no expectations, it is an excellent read.", "A good fiction writer can teach a lot about human nature. The collection called The Great Books of the Western World contains many works of great fiction. Read the Iliad and the Oddessey.", "Of course. Remember, truth is stranger than fiction with fiction you\u2019re obliged to stick to possibilities. Truth isn\u2019t.", "Fiction is the telling of stories that are based on the life experiencing of the readers (On you, the reader). We learn firstly not via language but by observing and mirroring what we observe. If our observations lead to affirmation to praise, we will retain the experience as a positive one. Or if what we experience is pleasant in nature; as for example sweet taste, we again retain it as a memory that will build over a lifetime a more rounded understanding of both positive and negative experiences. Later, much later we learn to categories these experiences into loose \u2018kinds\u2019, and later again into linguistic categories; dog, cat tree, man, lover, murderer, etc.\nThis is where all literature, not just fiction has a part to play. Research has shown that when we mirror an activity, we not only do so in observation actual life experiences, but also in reading, watching a movie or video. That is why you may shed a tear as the hero suffers or the heroine is treated cruelly. Or you may be physically moved such that you squirm in your seat, you react viscerally, as if you where there yourself. Just by reading or seeing such events and situations affects each of us emotionally, such that we respond to fictional \u2018stories\u2019 psychically. We identify with heroes and heroines such that we \u2018feel\u2019 as they feel, psychically hurt or love as they do - in our imagination. We do this based on a lifetime of implicitly learning and remembering these \u2018kinds\u2019 of experiences, at a level that could be called subconscious, but this information is readily available to hand should we have a \u2018trigger\u2019 situation, be it in reality or in participating in a fictional story. We are able to empathise with another because in mirroring we \u2018take in\u2019 the experiences of others and these experiences have an emotional affect on us, such that we may \u2018feel\u2019 for another, be they real or fictional characters.\nFiction enables us to experience situations, events that we are never likely to be involved in first hand. We can range from love to murder and mayhem. Both of these subjects almost all humans find fascinating because in one form or another, we all seek love and affection and we call know that a day will come when we cease to exist, so all forms of experiences of love and death in all its manifestations both real and fictional affect us emotionally. In this manner we learn about the minds of killers, of victims, of lovers and cheats.\nSo through fictional stories we live viscerally, bodily as well as through the mind. We range over all the many possibilities that human have experienced or even just imagined, and we can do this because we share with writer, actors, scriptwriter etc, these human capacities that every human being experiences in one form or another. And it all began with observation!", "The best fiction is centered in reality. Study & practise pronunciation. Only when you are comfortable saying these words aloud are you confident of using them.\n2. Do the exercises without skipping anything. Do the revisions as well,\nNow, it takes a unique approach to teach words based on two principles.\nThe words are verbal symbols of ideas and\nThe more ideas you are familiar with, the more words you know.\nInstead of teaching you words after words, it introduces you to ideas first. Then, it brings into contact the words associated with those ideas. In this way, the words remain in your mind for a long time as the mind remembers the ideas and stories more than mere facts.\nThe book uses etymological approach to teach new words. Don\u2019t ignore it. This is the heart of building a wider vocabulary.\nNow, what is this approach? It's a divide-and-conquer approach. You dissect a word and see what it is made of. They are prefix, root, and suffix. You study about their origins, history, and like.\nRight, let\u2019s quickly see how we can learn few words by the above approach.\nintrovert - someone who wants to be alone and doesn\u2019t want to hang out.\nextrovert - someone who hangs around almost all the time and likes to be with people.\nambivert - someone who enjoys both spending time with others and sitting alone by himself.\nWhat do these three words have in common? How can you easily get the hang of these words so you\u2019ll remember and use it?\nIt depends on how you turn\nThe words ambivert, introvert, extrovert are all built on the Latin verb verto, to turn.\nIf you turn inward, introvert. Intro \u2014 inward + verto - to turn.\nIf you turn outward(extro-), extrovert.\nIf you turn both(ambi-) ways, ambivert.\nNow, take the prefix intro-. It\u2019s present in introduction, intra-national, intravenous, etc. So, even without understanding what these words mean, you can guess that they have to do something with inward, inner.\nTake the prefix ambi-. It\u2019s present in words like ambivalence, ambidextrous, amphibian, etc. Here, at least you can infer that these words have \u201cboth\u201d , \u201ceither\u201d aspect to them.\nCorrect usage of confusing words\nInterwoven into vocabulary chapters are other chapters on correct usage of common confusing words.\nIt also teaches you how to pronounce English words.\nBesides, it consists of a few tests to assess your level of vocabulary at each stage of the book. So, you have feedback on your learning to tell you if to review the past sessions or move on to next sessions.\nThe book is divided into a number of sessions designed around different ideas:\nPersonality Types\nDoctors\nPractitioners\nScience and Scientists\nLiars and Lying\nActions\nSpeech Habits\nEnemies\nFriends\nCommon Occurrences\nPersonal Characteristics\nAudience\nFor learners who know English well enough to read an English book. It's for anyone who's passionate about English language and want to widen their vocabulary. It's ideal for self-study.\nThe book is quite fun and witty. I absolutely loved studying it. The exercises are interesting, challenging, and very useful. I got confident about English language in general. It didn't just teach me new words but it taught me how to increase vocabulary myself. It gave me strategies.\nHow do you keep on building and reinforcing what you learnt?\nI found books by Erich Segal to be excellent. I was born in the late 80\u2019s and Ranju Hazarika was probably the only author I remember who was incredibly popular among the readers of that time and he was best known for his horror and thriller novels. I still recollect the first time when I read his novel I must've been about 7\u20138 year old and I came across this book at our home called \u201cAndha Ghatak\u201d with rather a scary picture of black cat on the cover and despite knowing that it was meant for adults I started reading it. The book depicts a horrifying account of a severed hand that goes around killing people , a story of vengeance . As I had finished reading few pages, his ingenious illustration of the story was sufficed to send shivers down my spine . I was obviously petrified and a bit perplexed considering whether or not I should be reading further. It gave me such a fright that I barely can stay alone in a room on my own let alone the time of power outage during night time. Meanwhile, I couldn't resist my temptation to read the later half and eventually plucked up my courage and manged to read the entire book. So that was that , if I have to choose any favorite Ranju Hazarika novel it is got to be \u201cAndha Ghatak\u201d. On a side note though I don't think the book is available now.", "When I was in school, I used to read books written by Ranju Hazarika. The films are highly condensed adaptations of the books.\nThe Order of the Phoenix (book 5) is the largest book. The Order of the Phoenix (film 5) is the shortest movie. Just imagine how much was removed!\nDirectors, of course, have a relatively free hand when making their films. They do things such as combine characters, remove characters, and have characters do things that other characters did. An example of the latter is in the Half-Blood Prince book, Tonks finds Harry on the train after Draco petrifies him, breaks his nose, and hides him underneath the invisibility cloak. In the film, Luna finds him.\nThey also add scenes that in their mind quickly frame a situation that is otherwise missing due to the removal of large parts of the book. A good example of this is the dancing scene in the Deathly Hallows between Harry and Hermione in the tent. This was used to show vulnerability and the strength of their relationship as a lot of their travels were not in the film. A bad example is the attack and burning down of the Burrow in the Half-Blood Prince film. It added nothing and was completely out of place.\nMy favourite book is The Deathly Hallows. I know it inside and out. This is due to an unplanned ripping of the audio CDs into my iTunes and hearing random chapters during shuffle play of my music over a long period of time. Because of this, the Deathly Hallows Parts 1 and 2 films are my least favourite. The unforgivable sins of these are that Harry did not fix his wand, when his wand is a major theme of the story; and the final confrontation between Harry and Voldemort was supposed to be fully witnessed by everyone in the Great Hall, but in the film it\u2019s the two of them alone outside and no one sees it happen. I wrote a trilogy where the first book came out in hardcover, didn\u2019t sell as well as the publisher expected (for several reasons, not all of them anything wrong with the book), so they cut costs by starting the second volume out in trade paperback, which flopped, so the third was a rack-sized paperback right from the start. If you want your set to match, you need to get the mass-market paperbacks; if you bought the hardcover, that\u2019s just too bad.\n(Be it noted this series was the last thing I wrote for that publisher \u2014 after they mishandled it so badly I was happy to go elsewhere.)", "Not sure if you\u2019re asking from a buyer\u2019s perspective or an author\u2019s, but it\u2019s very possible for a series to start releasing only in paperback and go to hardcover because of increased sales.", "Why not? There are at least two possible reasons: (1) You couldn\u2019t afford hardcovers at first, so you waited for the paperback, but now you can afford to transition to hardcovers. (That was the progression of my reading of Stephen King.) It's also help to develop a new ways of thinking a matter in different angles"], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Anu Sharma", "view_list": [16]}, "390": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Param Hegde", "Shreya Ghosh", "Ashish Batheja"], "question_title": "What are some key excerpt from the book Ikigai?", "topic_list": ["Book Excerpts", "Ikigai", "Book Summaries", "Japanese (language)", "Novels", "Books"], "no_of_view": "908", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [2, 1, 0], "ans_list": ["The book will help to understand what it takes to lead a healthy, happy life and gave tips to longevity.\nIn Japan, Okinawa island has highest centenarians in the world, 24.55 out of 100 people. Most of the people live 90 years, 100 years and above. Not only they enjoy longevity, they enjoy with vitality even in their 90\u2019s and they don\u2019t have any chronic illnesses. What are the secrets? How can we live long, healthy, happy life?\nThe book provides insights that can help look at our own life and develop some of these good habits. Here\u2019re the key insights I took away:\nDiet/Exercise\nMost of the centenarians consume less meat and processed foods. They drink alcohol in moderation. They eat wide variety of foods, especially vegetables. Variety seems to be the key. Many eat vegetables grown in their garden. They eat almost 206 different foods, including spices, on a regular basis. On an average, studies show, they ate 18 different foods each day. Also, they keep all the food that they consume in one plate which makes it visible of the amount of food they are consuming.\nStudies show, Okinawans eat five servings of fruits and vegetables every day, and at least seven types of fruits and vegetables are consumed on a daily basis!.\nThey eat less than 10 grams of salt per day. They rarely eat sugar and if they do, it\u2019s only cane sugar.\nMost of them eat only 80% stomach full. They stop eating when they feel like stomach is getting full. Never eat 100%, get up when you are 80% full.\nAlso, many practice intermittent fasting two days each week which helps to cleans digestive system and allows it to rest.\nOkinawan\u2019s diet is rich with antioxidants. Antioxidants help slowing down aging process by slowing the oxidation process in cells, neutralizing the free radicals that cause damage and accelerate aging. Be it green tea, or powerful Shikuwasa fruit (citrus fruit like Oranges but 40 times more rich in antioxidants). Choose food in your diet that has antioxidants.\nKeep yourself active. Only by staying active, you will live to 100 years. In Japan, one might be surprised to see how active people remain after they retire. Infact many Japanese people never really retire \u2013 they keep doing what they love for as long as their health allows. Something we all should do.\nTo keep ourselves active, It doesn\u2019t require extensive strenuous exercises; all that is needed is gentle movements throughout the day. Most of them do daily chores, taking walks, working in their vegetable garden etc. Low intensity exercises which allows people to keep moving, but they do it throughout the day.\nA lot of sitting will age you. If you sit for more than 30mins, metabolism slows down by 90%! Read that again. That\u2019s huge. Sitting longer could cause obesity, high blood pressure, imbalanced eating, cardiovascular disease and even some kinds of cancer. Keep moving. Don\u2019t sit at one place for more than 30 mins.\nDo basic exercises in the morning. It is common practice in Japan since World WarII, more so in Okinawa, to do Radio taiso exercises at 6am in groups for about five to ten minutes. These might look like stupid exercises like raising arms above head and turning in circles etc. One of the few times we raise our hands above our heads is when reaching for something in a cupboard or closet, while our ancestors were raising hands all the time gathering things from trees. It is more important than we think. Do these basic exercises.\nSecret to keeping body young is to keep mind active. Mental neurons start aging while we are in our 20\u2019s. Only way to keep this process to slow down is to exercise mental muscles. Get yourself involved in any intellectual activity, playing games, develop curiosity, learning something new, dealing with new situations, interacting with other people, having more positive outlook etc.\nDevelop some habits: Walk to work. Just walk at least 20 mins a day, use feet instead of elevator, participate in social leisure activities (instead of TV or phone), replace junk food with fruits, get right amount of sleep (8 hours), Play with children and pets, Join a sports team etc. There is a saying \u2018keep your fingers active\u2019. If you keep your fingers working, you will cross 100.\nMost of the Japanese get their regular health check up to identify and prevent diseases. It is done through integrated health care system. It is important and get your checkups done regularly.\nManaging Stress/Emotional well being\nStress is one of the chief factors that cause us to age. So many people age prematurely. Stress weakens the cell structures known as telomeres which affects cellular regeneration and how our cells age. When we are under stress, neurons would activate the pituitary and adrenal glands to produce necessary hormones to prepare ourselves for the danger so that we can take action. That\u2019s why little bit of stress is actually good, but repeated stress will make us age prematurely as cells degenerate.\nLearn to manage your stress and worries. Develop stoic attitude \u2013 serenity in the face of a setback can help keep you young as it lowers stress levels. Achieve mindfulness to see yourself and focusing on the self, noticing our responses consciously.\nMany centenarians faced challenges and obstacles and most of them faced them with a positive attitude. People who face challenges/problems, face it with a positive attitude and with a high degree of emotional awareness are already on their way towards longevity. Develop resilience, not only persevere but also choose what is important.\nSleep for 7 to 9 hours, ideal is 8 hours, because sleeping is a great anti-aging tool. Did you know what is model\u2019s best-kept secret? Before the photo shoot day, she would sleep for 9 to 10 hours. Sleeping well produces a hormone called \u201cmelatonin\u201d which produces glow under the skin, wrinkle free. Melatonin is a powerful antioxidant produced by pineal gland. It has many other benefits - Strengthens immune system, Contains element that protects against cancer, Promotes natural production of insulin, Slows the onset of Alzeimer\u2019s disease, Prevents osteoporosis and prevents heart disease. So sleep well everyday atleast for 8 hours.\nCommunity and Social Life\nOne thing that amazed me while reading the book is how much community and active social life has influence on longevity and well being, Japanese culture develops inherent feeling of connectedness among its people. This is called Moai. Japanese form a group of people and build a community to do an activity together, meetings, dinners, games, hobbies they have in common etc. They celebrate birthdays, sing Karaoke\u2019s in the night, dance to the joy, and share their feelings with one another. Even the elders dance to the tunes, participate in games. This develops sense of bonding with broad circle of friends and develops good family relations.\nThey also pool in amount of money monthly and utilize this for these social activities. If there is some amount left out, one person who is in need (because the crops were not good and he is in financial trouble) will get the money as advance which he can pay later. This gives a sense of security because they are being cared in tough times and has influence on their life expectancy.\nThey named the town \u201cVillage of Longevity\u201d which tells me that there is something to assert and give confidence to the people who stay there that they will live longer. It is a sort of affirmation. At 90, they say you are a child and at 100 you are an adult. Affirming someone that they will live longer could become a reality.\nMany believe that food doesn\u2019t help to live longer. Secret is smiling and having a good time with others.\nIKIGAI / Sense of Purpose\nKey thing all centenarians have in common is their Ikigai. The Japanese word Ikigai is nothing but one\u2019s deep sense of purpose for each and every day living. It is that thing for which you wake up looking forward to every morning. It is the thing that drives you in flow. It is the intersection of what you love to do, what the world needs, what you are good at, and what you can be paid for. Clearly defined ikigai brings satisfaction, happiness and meaning to our lives.\nIn Japanese culture, there are lots of examples of artisans who are so many experts in what they do. Someone is so good at finer details that he was irreplaceable at Toyota. Someone is so good in cooking skills that he has mastered the art of cooking salmon for 80 years. They produce outcome which is world class and extremely good. There is simplicity in what they do and do in harmony with nature. They are so much involved in that activity and work in a flow. That\u2019s their ikigai.\nMost of the places where people live the longest and have centenarians are islands - be in Japan, Greece, or Costa Rica. In these islands resources are scarce and communities have to help each other. For many, helping each other is the strong ikigai, which is strong enough to keep them alive.\nHow to find what is one\u2019s ikigai, the true sense of purpose. One needs to find out the activities that make him flow. If an activity is so easy, it will make you bored. If an activity is so hard that you will exhaust yourself and quit. Those are two extremes. If an activity that is bit harder than you could easily do it, however you enjoy doing it immensely, you can do it wholeheartedly that you become one with that activity, and you lose sense of time and completely immerse in the activity, that state is called \u201cFlow\u201d. Whatever interests you and makes you do something in that kind of state could help you find what your real purpose is and your ikigai.\nAs author Viktor frankl told in the book \u201cMan\u2019s search for meaning\u2019, during second world war, in concentration camps the survivors were one who wanted to accomplish something outside the camp and who felt strong need to get out alive. Someone who has goal to achieve and strongly persevere to do so. They survived and lived longer. He who has a \u201cwhy\u201d to live can almost bear with almost any \u201chow\u201d.\nTo find our ikigai - List down all the actions that make you go in flow. Then check what these activities that drive you in flow have in common \u2013 are these activities that you do alone or in groups, why do they drive me into flow, Are these activities more to do with physical activities or more to do with thinking. With this kind of exercise, we may be able to find our Ikigai.\nSometimes, we don\u2019t really have the purpose. Or don\u2019t really know what that is. Or it is that, we have a purpose and we are already working on it, but just that we don\u2019t know about it. Book has an example of a mother who is been working on taking care of their kid \u2013 goes to depression having no meaningful purpose. When asked to visualize in her deathbed, what she did in her life, she actually felt so much she did and realized what she was doing was a great purpose in life. She was already doing it but didn\u2019t realize it. Take some time and put effort to find your purpose.\nIn summary, taking clues from centenarians, we can try to develop habits \u2013 what we eat, how we exercise, how we manage stress, how do we develop relationship and live in community and find out and live our IKIGAI, our sense of purpose. Surely, we can try to add little more years to our life and in the process, we can add little more life to our years as well.", "So I am finally done with reading Ikigai, the book is authored by Hector Garcia and Francesc Miralles. And here, in the next 2 minutes, I am going to share my take from this book.\nThis book covers various aspects of life that can help us achieve a long, fulfilling, and happy life.\nStarting with The word derives from iki, meaning life and gai, meaning the realization of hopes and expectations, it is more like the reason you want to get out of your bed each morning.\nLife is not a problem to be solved. Just remember to have something that keeps you busy doing what you love while being surrounded bu the people who love you\nSo here are my takeaways from Ikigai that are\nAlways try to find what you love doing and that will give you the purpose of this life. It is very important to keep on doing little things that add to the value of your life, making little progress and bringing beauty and helpfulness to others. Learn something new every day, play games, and interact with other people. A positive attitude & emotional awareness (ability to manage emotions) is essential for a good life.\n2. Taking it slow:\nStop being in a hurry and urgency every time in your life, walk slowly and you\u2019ll have a long way to go.\n3. Surround yourself with good friends, friends who uplift you.\n4. Work on your health:\nGet in shape for your next birthday, when you get older make it a daily habit of walking or exercising that will keep you going for a long time. Practice mindfulness through focusing on self and meditation.\n5. Reconnect with nature\n6. Thank people\nAround you, ancestors, and nature. Form close bonds within local communities. Play with children or pets.\n7. Do not fill your stomach when it comes to eating\nIn order to stay healthy always eat a little less than your hunger demands. Fill your belly to 80%\n8. Live in the moment\nStop regretting your past and fearing about your future, make most of today because that is all you have. Smile more. This moment exists only now and won\u2019t come again.\n9. Seven conditions for achieving flow ( Going with the flow is important for a healthy life )\ni) Knowing what to do\nii) Knowing how to do it\niii) Knowing how well you are doing\niv) Knowing where to go (where navigation is involved)\nv) Perceiving significant challenges\nvi) Perceiving significant skills\nvii) Being free from distractions\n10. Antifragility \u2014 things that get stronger when they are harmed\nHow to be antifragile:\n11. Follow your ikigai\nFind the passion which lies inside you which is your unique talent and work on it. It is your mission to find your ikigai.", "One of the key giveaways of Ikigai, the book, is making people aware that Happiness is in Purpose.\nWe try many things to achieve happiness, do many things on a hit and trial basis only to know the happiness we achieve doing any of it, is temporary.\nIkigai defines happiness as a state of mind when you are completely in present, the right now, not worrying about past and future, and lose a track of time in the task you are onto.\nIt says you can only achieve this state when you\u2019re in Flow. That is completely involved in what you\u2019re doing.\nHow to achieve flow?\nAnd knowing exactly the state of mind to achieve knowing exactly what to do, where you have to go, and not obsessing over the goals.\nWhen you\u2019re in flow, you\u2019ll be so much in present you won\u2019t ever worry about past or future.\nAfter all, its all about training your mind to stick to a certain mindset. (G11). How can I prepare for ABM? Is there any book I can start to read or such to prepare for my strand?", "topic_list": ["Accountancy, Business and Management", "Exam and Test Prep Book Recommendations", "Reading", "Exam and Test Preparation", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Exams and Tests", "Career Advice"], "no_of_view": "552", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Samantha Lhy Yun", "view_list": []}, "481": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Matthew Beck", "Nick McCormack"], "question_title": "What did you think of The Old Curiosity Shop by Charles Dickens?", "topic_list": ["Charles Dickens (author)", "British Literature", "Literary Fiction", "Curiosity", "Novels", "Writers and Authors", "Literature", "Shopping", "Reading", "Books", "Survey Question"], "no_of_view": "545", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Here is my Goodreads review of it:\nThe Old Curiosity Shop is the Dickens novel that is as notorious as it is famous. To say why is to reveal one of the story\u2019s biggest spoilers, so stop reading now if you do not wish to know the ending.\nThe ending is quite famous however, and many people will be familiar with it from repute, even if they have not read it. It is perhaps the most downbeat moment in all of Dickens, and he took care never to repeat it again.\nThere are elements of defeat in other Dickens novels, notably Great Expectations and Hard Times, but no Dickens novel is too tragic, not even The Old Curiosity Shop. Perhaps if Dickens had been writing for an audience today, which is more inured to books that end badly, his fiction would have taken a different turn, but he lived in an age where it was considered commercially necessary for books to have a happy ending.\nNonetheless, in The Old Curiosity Shop, Dickens kills off his heroine, Nell Trent, known as Little Nell. Yet she is not a morally ambiguous character. She is the personification of goodness. Indeed the modern reader is likely to be repelled by her one-dimensional purity and innocence, and will struggle to understand the appeal of the book.\nEven by the end of the nineteenth century, Oscar Wilde famously said that one would have to have a heart of stone not to laugh at Dickens\u2019 description of Nell\u2019s death. The morbid sentimentality employed by Dickens worked well in exploiting the emotions of an early Victorian audience, but this is less possible now.\nIt is difficult to separate fact from fiction. Did Dickens fans in New York City really shout to arriving sailors, \u201cIs Little Nell alive?\u201d If so, they must have anticipated that Dickens was likely to kill Nell off.\nOne person who did not predict that outcome was the Irish nationalist, Daniel O\u2019Connell. He was so upset by Nell\u2019s death that he is said to have thrown the book out of a train window, and complained that Dickens lacked the artistry to write a happy ending for Little Nell.\nO\u2019Connell is right here, but also unfair. It is unlikely that Dickens (or anyone) could have written an artistically satisfying conclusion to The Old Curiosity Shop in which Nell lived happily ever after. Her death seems the natural culmination of her life. She is a tragic figure, and one who finds respite in being with old men and walking around graves. Death seems to have her earmarked from an early stage.\nDickens may not have worked out the details of the plot, judging by some early uncertainty in the style of The Old Curiosity Shop. Master Humphrey disappears from the story after a few chapters, and no effective plot is ever worked out concerning Nell\u2019s brother, Frederick. Dick Swiveller seems to be set up as a feckless, untrustworthy individual, only to turn out as one of the book\u2019s heroes later on.\nNonetheless I can safely say that Dickens probably intended that Nell should die. The only boy who loves Nell is Kit, a likeable enough young man, but clearly not considered worthy of winning Nell\u2019s heart by Dickens. Instead Kit is to be married off to the irritating maidservant, Barbara, a weak and neurotic girl whose vapidity only serves to make Nell look better.\nIs there any way of liking Nell? She seems to be a fixed point of goodness, incapable of character development or fallibility, and this lifts her into being an ideal more than a person. Like Oliver Twist, she can move around the poor and disreputable parts of her world, but Dickens somehow believes that it is possible for them to stay pure.\nNell will not steal or lie to survive. She will radiate goodness until others help her. In the same way, Daniel Quilp, the malignant animalistic dwarf, is an embodiment of pure evil, and beyond any repentance.\nAn interesting perspective on Nell comes from Ingeborg Refling Hagen, the Norwegian author. Hagen is said to have buried a copy of The Old Curiosity Shop in her youth, stating that nobody deserved to read about Nell because nobody (except Hagen) could understand Nell\u2019s pain.\nPerhaps we do need to have shared Nell\u2019s experiences \u2013 her struggle with poverty, her anxiety over her weak grandfather, who steals money from her in order to gamble (another one of Dickens\u2019 weak-natured parental figures), and her loneliness and struggling. She has many friends and allies, but cannot receive their help for long before being driven on.\nIt may be hard to identify with Nell (unless we have had the life experience of Hagen), but it is possible to pity her. She is a young girl who has never had the chance to be a child. She has been forced to act as the responsible adult in her relationship with her grandfather, and she has been exposed to privations and dangers that no child should have to face. Her childhood has been stolen from her.\nOne of the more peculiar and insidious dangers comes from Quilp. It is not only that he has a financial hold on her grandfather. The dwarf has designs on Nell herself. I am not sure how repugnant this seemed to the original audience, but there is a distinct hint of paedophilia in Quilp\u2019s lust for Nell. It is clear that if Nell had lived a few more years, Quilp would have murdered his inexplicably clingy wife, and tried to wed Nell.\nThere are other dimensions to The Old Curiosity Shop. While it is not an allegory, it sometimes feels like one. Nell and her grandfather walk through hellish streets and out into the country, passing through unnamed towns and villages, and encountering people of varying levels of good and evil, before finding solace in the grave.\nA number of the people they meet on the way are displaced entertainers, a topical issue in Dickens\u2019 day, as many were forced on the road to carry out barely-legal shows. Codlin and Harris run a Punch and Judy show, but consider turning Nell in to get reward money. Mrs Jarley, the owner of a waxworks show, is kinder, but even she cannot protect Nell.\nThere is some interest in these scenes with Nell, but often the supporting characters steal the book. It is easier to care about Kit\u2019s adventures, especially when he is wrongly accused of theft, an elaborate frame-up by the corrupt solicitors, Sampson and Sally Brass.\nKit is ultimately saved when Dick Swiveller is able to bring information to light. Dostoevsky was clearly an avid reader of this book. He steals this scene in Crime and Punishment, and the death of a child at the end of The Brothers Karamazov has a similar sentimental feel to Nell\u2019s death.\nPerhaps the best characters are the unfortunately-named Dick Swiveller and The Marchioness. This is because they are essentially good-hearted, but have enough flaws to make them human. Dick is a chancer who runs up huge debts, and appears to be selfishly out for his own ends. However he ultimately shows a more worthy side after he is offered employment by the Brasses.\nThe Marchioness is a curious character. She is a servant of Sally Brass, and essentially a slave. Her origins are unknown. She does not even know her name or age. It is vaguely hinted that she might be a love child of Quilp and Sally Brass, a grotesque enough notion.\nHer tiny size is stressed, but though she seems to be a child, Dickens (just about) steers clear of the question of whether the love affair between Dick and her is as questionable as Quilp\u2019s attraction to Nell. Their relationship does stay Platonic until the end, when we are told that she looks about 19.\nNowadays, readers might also shift uncomfortably in the scenes involving the sad schoolmaster who seems a little too attached to one of the schoolboys, and later Nell. Sadly we no longer live in an innocent age where we can read these things in a relaxed manner.\nThe Marchioness is a typically timid heroine, as is often the case in Dickens, but she shows some sly qualities. She listens at keyholes, and she steals keys. These activities are not done from malice, but as a matter of self-preservation. She is kept starved, and she is locked downstairs most of the time, causing her fears that she will be forgotten if there is a fire.\nIn the end, this enigmatic little waif proves to be the saviour of Dick and Kit. She nurses Dick when he is ill, and provides the information that prevents Kit from being deported. Such little character portraits show us that Dickens was often better with his supporting characters than he was with his main characters, who are often a little bland.\nThe Old Curiosity Shop has dated less well than some Dickens novels, but there is still much to enjoy in it. The story, allowing for a few teething problems, is more coherent and focused than any of Dickens\u2019 earlier books, and there is a variety of tone and incident to keep the reader\u2019s interest.", "Like a lot of Victorian literature mawkish and melodramatic."], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Dane John Cobain", "view_list": [25, 6]}, "622": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 8, "name_list": ["Dharani Sathwik Ram", "Pradeep Pal", "Sumit Pal (\u09b8\u09c1\u09ae\u09bf\u09a4 \u09aa\u09be\u09b2)", "Ashis Mitra", "Anonymous", "Subhasis Dutta Roy", "Kevin Correa", "Pankaj Kumar Sinha"], "question_title": "What is the retiring room at railway stations, and how can a passenger book it?", "topic_list": ["Railway Stations in India", "Railway Retiring Rooms", "Railway Stations", "Passenger Trains", "Railroad Routes", "Railway Systems", "Indian Railways Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC)", "Trains", "Indian Railways", "Books"], "no_of_view": "1,907", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 1, 2, 2, 0, 19, 1, 0], "ans_list": ["A2A.\nRetiring rooms are available at major railway stations that provide accommodation for passengers who have a valid ticket of a journey for a maximum duration of 48 hours. You can book these rooms online and offline.\nThe offline booking procedure is easy. I will narrate my personal experience where I have booked retiring rooms offline. You just need the ticket for your journey(actually the PNR number on it) and an identity card. You need to enquire about the vacancies available in the dormitory/retiring rooms firstly. If there are any, you can complete all the formalities like filling up some forms with information you already know(stuff like Your Name, Age, Gender, Destination, etc.) and pay to the officer concerned. You will be allotted a retiring room/dormitory bed with AC/Non-AC facility of your choice.\nThe online procedure is also easy and this is similar to that of booking a railway ticket on the IRCTC website. Here, we use the IRCTC tourism website. Railways Tourism, Retiring Rooms, Holidays Customized Tours, LTC Tours, Maharajas, Mahaparinirvan\n. The following screenshots give you a basic idea about the booking procedure.\nChoose the room of your choice among the various vacant rooms and then you are almost done.\nA summary of the booking details will be displayed under this tab. The payment is in the next tab. Online payment is the only option available. There is no such option as\u2026 book now, pay later after you reach the railway station.\nThe confirmation tab gives you the whole summary along with a printable ticket which gives you access to the room.\nDue to the latest fatal epidemic, the railway stations are shut down. So, currently online and offline bookings for the retiring rooms are closed temporarily.\nAll the screenshots are from the Indian Railways Tourism website.\nHope this helps. Thanks for reading my answer.", "Rooms available at railway station for short stay with common bathroom are railway Dorms they are cheaper and Retiring Rooms are the rooms which are available on Railway Stations with separate bathroom and many facilities they are available in AC and Non AC combination.\nPassenger can book it from Minimum 12 Hrs to Maximum 48 Hrs. before and after journey, Please go to below link to check price and list of railway stations having retiring rooms, contact no. of stations retiring rooms and the process of booking retiring rooms.\nRailway Retiring Room\nNote:- 1. Retiring rooms are available for only confirmed and RAC ticket holders.\n2.Retiring rooms can be booked through online only.\n3. ID proof is must.\n4.Retiring room is available only for the passengers having name in journey ticket.", "Retiring rooms are spaces provided inside railway stations where one can spend the night in. It is usually meant for passengers who are travelling in trains or will be travelling in one. This facility is available in all major railway stations.\nThere are two ways for booking a retiring room, online process and offline process. The procedure for booking retiring rooms online is as follows:\nVisit the official website of IRCTC Tourism at Railways Tourism, Retiring Rooms, Holidays Customized Tours, LTC Tours, Maharajas, Mahaparinirvan\nOn the home page, click on \u201cRetiring Room\u201d tab.\nHere, you have to enter your PNR and the dates of choice based on the PNR. You also have to select the type of rooms (AC or Non-AC)\nAfter selection of rooms, perform the necessary payment of rooms (usually 500 for AC. May vary)\nAfter the booking is done, the passenger will get a confirmation message.\nThe process for booking retiring rooms offline is as follows:\nVisit the railway station nearest to your residence having a Retiring Room with online booking facility.\nThe Retiring Room Booking Facility at railway stations is situated inside or next to CTI office, Enquiry Counter of Current Booking Counter. It is managed by On-duty TE of the railway station.\nGive your ticket PNR and the status of your booking.", "I never booked retiring rooms or dormitories online. For those persons who don\u2019t want to book online, there are two ways -\nIf you want to book at the time of arriving, go to enquiry counter. If the room is available, railway personnel will book it for you.\nFor more surety, it is better to book advance. Suppose you live in city A, and want to book a retiring room in city B, then -\nGo to the retiring room booking counter of city A station.\nSay the details to booking clerk about the destination station, duration of staying, and type of room you want. The clerk will check it online through computer.\nIf all matches well, he/she will say yes to you. Then you show him EPIC/AADHAR/PASSPORT/PAN/LICENSE - for photo and details verification. He will enter all details.\nThen pay to him by cash the rent.\nHe/she will give you the retiring room/dormitory booking ticket.\nWhen you will reach at station B, show that booking ticket to enquiry counter.\nThe station B clerk will check it by computer. If all match, he/she will give you the permission to go to that retiring room/dormitory.\nI am using this method since 2017, always pre-book such tickets from Sealdah Station.", "Retiring rooms are NOT for filth like you.", "After arriving at a station and before starting another journey sometimes passenger has to stay. So for providing some relief in between continuous journey railways arrange facility of some well-equipped rooms at big stations with a minimum charge. These rooms are called as retiring rooms.\nThese rooms are available as AC or Non AC, single bed, double beds, dormitories in different stations.\nA passenger can book Railway retiring room for a minimum period of 3 hours and a maximum up to 48 hours.\nBooking can be done online and offline. For online booking, you have to open the ITCTC tourism website. Search for retiring rooms. Enter your PNR number. Books your rooms. After booking, you will receive a message.\nFor offline you have to go to your nearest railway station where online retiring rooms booking facilities available. There you give your booking details to on duty booking staff. They will book your retiring rooms.\nHere are some samples pictures of Railway retiring rooms in different railway stations.\nImages source Google.\nSubhasis.", "Normally railway stations have what is called a waiting room , where passengers waiting for a train can wash up and avail toilet facilities. Will you write one (including stats and alignment) for a famous character (e.g., Indiana Jones)?\nI don\u2019t do full sheets, but\u2026\nEd Han's answer to If the Avengers were in DND, what would their stats be?\nEd Han's answer to What classes and levels would the Fellowship of the Ring be in 5th edition Dungeons and Dragons?\nEd Han's answer to How would you build Daryl Dixon as a D&D 5E PC?\nEd Han's answer to What stat block would Lord Voldemort have in D&D 5E?\nEd Han's answer to How would you stat out the alien predators from Predator for Dungeons and Dragons 5th Edition?\nEd Han's answer to How would you stat out the Xenomorphs from Aliens for Dungeons and Dragons 5th Edition?\nEd Han's answer to What DnD class would you say Robin Hood belongs to?\nAnd o yeah\u2026\nStat This!", "Well I\u2019ll do one that I like more. I\u2019ll take you from first level to fourth level.\nYennefer of Yenneberg (from the Witcher)\nFirst - pick the half elf race (technically yennefer is a quarter elf but as that is not an option use half elf) you get +2 to charisma and +1 to two different stats in this case I used intelligence and constitution\nfor skill versatility pick investigation and performance\ninvestigation because yennefer is extremely good at finding and researching what she wants even if it isn\u2019t always successful or safe\nperformance because she is very good at pretending and putting on a mask that very few can see through\nyou get to choose one language at this point - she speaks elder in the Witcher to cast spells. The dnd equivalent would be deep speech in my opinion but abyssal and Slyvan both have arguments here do what makes the most sense for your campaign. She gets elvish and common as racial traits\nother racial traits to make note of is she has advantage against being charmed and magic can\u2019t put her to sleep\nAnd dark vision of 60ft\nNow for Class\npick sorcerer - they call her sorceress in the Witcher and then pick wild magic (controlling chaos)\nnow things to note\nmain ability: charisma\nsaving throws: charisma and constitution\nhit die: 1d6 per level - so at level 1 it\u2019s 1d6 at level 4 it\u2019s 4d6\nArmor: none (this will come into play in her spells so hold on)\nWeapons: Daggers, Slings, Light crossbows, quarter staffs, darts\nTools: none\nSkills: Pick deception and persuasion\nWild Surge - Starting when you choose this origin at 1st level, your spellcasting can unleash surges of untamed magic. Once per turn, the DM can have you roll a d20 immediately after you cast a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher. If you roll a 1, roll on the Wild Magic Surge table to create a magical effect. If that effect is a spell, it is too wild to be affected by your Metamagic, and if it normally requires concentration, it doesn\u2019t require concentration in this case; the spell lasts for its full duration.\nTides of Chaos: Starting at 1st level, you can manipulate the forces of chance and chaos to gain advantage on one attack roll, ability check, or saving throw. Once you do so, you must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.\nAny time before you regain the use of this feature, the DM can have you roll on the Wild Magic Surge table immediately after you cast a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher. You then regain the use of this feature.\nAt Level One\nCantrips:\nFire Bolt\nFrostbite\nMinor Illusion\nLight\nSpells:\nBurning Hands\nMage Armor\nAbility Scores:\nTo make her AL legal use point buy\nnow she already has +1 to Intelligence and Constitution and +2 to Charisma\nSo use\n7 points to get 14 in your charisma - your +2 brings that to 16\n9 points to get 15 in your constitution- +1 brings you to 16\n4 points to Dexterity to make it 12\n3 points to Intelligence to make it 11 and your +1 makes it 12\n2 points to Wisdom and Strength bringing both to 10\nthis way you have no negative modifiers\nso your stats will be (I\u2019ll do them stat (modifier) so it\u2019s easier to see)\nStr 10 (+0)\nDex 12 (+1)\nCon 16 (+3)\nInt 12 (+1)\nWis 10 (+0)\nCha 16 (+3)\nNow for your background pick Sage - because it fits in her pursuit of power and knowledge but also fulfills her ability to serve as an advisor to royal courts\nthis gets you two more languages\nI chose celestial and slyvan as yennefer would learn the rare languages\nThis gets you proficiency in Arcana and History as well\nnow characteristics in AL you can use your own which is nice and still have your character be legal\nAlignment: Chaotic Neutral - she tends toward self preservation and the ends justify the means but she also has tried to take the power of a Djinn under this ends justify the means mentality so\nIdeals: she is driven by the pursuit of power and control in an effort to remain self sufficient and independent\nBonds: Yennefer gave up her ability to have a child in order to he beautiful and powerful but this wasn\u2019t enough for her she wants power, beauty and a family. She wants the best of both worlds for herself\nFlaws: Yennefer struggles in controlling her emotions and because of this has a tendency to slip up and her chaotic magic slips out of her control\nSo at level 1 your sheet will look something like\nYennefer - half elf sorcerer1\nproficiency bonus +2\nSpeed 30ft\ninitiative +1\nArmor Class 11 (14 with mage armor cast - 13 plus dex mod)\nHit points 9/9\nSpell Modifier: +3\nSpell Attack: +5\nSaving throw DC: 13\nAt level 1 you get 2 spell slots - as a suggestion of combat is imminent cast Mage Armor right away and save your second one for burning hands but mostly use firebolt\nStats\nStr 10 (+0)\nDex 12 (+1)\nCon 16 (+3)\nInt 12 (+1)\nWis 10 (+0)\nCha 16 (+3)\nSaving Throws\nStr +0\nDex +1\nCon +5\nInt +1\nWis +0\nCha +5\nSenses\nPassive Perception 10\nPassive Investigation 13\nPassive Insight 10\nSkills (any you aren\u2019t proficient is is just your base modifier - I\u2019m only going to put the ones you\u2019d be proficient in)\nArcana +3\nDeception +5\nHistory +3\nInvestigation +3\nPerformance +5\nPersuasion +5\nActions (ie spells and attacks)\nFire Bolt - 120 ft range - +5 to hit - 1d10\nCrossbow - 80/320 (at disadvantage at 320ft) +3 to hit - 1d8+1\nDagger - 20/60 (disadvantage at 60ft) - 1d4+1\nFrostbite - 13 Con - 60ft - 1d6\nBurning Hands - 13 Dex - Self - 3d6\nnow that is just level one.\nAt level 2 add\nYou now have 16 hit points And 2d6 hit dice\nFont of Magic - these are sorcery points you get 2 at this point that you can use to turn into one extra spell slot but use them for metamagic at higher levels\nAdd the spell chaos bolt\nChaos Bolt - +5 to hit - 120 ft - 2d8 (see damage chart on this for more information)\nYou have 3 spell slots instead of 2 and 4 if you use your sorcery points\nAt level 3\n23 hit points, 3d6 hit dice\n4 1st level spell slots and 2 2nd level spell slots\n3 sorcery points\nyou get metamagic take\nEmpowered Spell and Quickened Spell\nEmpowered Spell\nWhen you roll damage for a spell, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage dice up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one). You must use the new rolls.\nYou can use Empowered Spell even if you have already used a different Metamagic option during the casting of the spell.\nQuickened Spell\nWhen you cast a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the casting time to 1 bonus action for this casting.\nTake the spell mind spike\nMind Spike - 13 Wis - 60ft - 3d8\nAt 4th Level you have\n30 hit points, 4d6 hit dice\neverything from the above level stays unless you take the ability score improvement then see below.\n4 1st level spots, 3 2nd level spots and 4 sorcery points\nEmpowered spell goes from 3 dice to 4\nYou get a new cantrip I\u2019d take Acid Splash\nAcid Splash 13 dex -60ft- 1d6 damage\nfor your new spell take Scorching Ray\nScorching Ray - +5 -120ft - 2d6 damage\nso now you have 5 cantrips and 5 spells\nand a choice to make feat or ability score improvement if you take a feat do spell sniper sorcerer, bard, warlock. Your spell save dc and attack rolls as well as skills stay the same when you do this vs the ability score but you gain an extra cantrip.\nWhen you cast a spell that requires you to make an attack roll, the spell's range is doubled.\nYour ranged spell attacks ignore half cover and three-quarters cover.\nYou learn one cantrip that requires an attack roll. Choose the cantrip from the bard, sorcerer, or warlock spell list. Your spellcasting ability for this cantrip is Charisma. And take Eldritch Blast - +5 to hit, 240 ft (with the feat) 1d10 damage\nthe feat doesn\u2019t change any of your to hits or saving throws so the only thing that changes are those things mentioned in these bullet points\nIf you decide on the ability score improvement put both of your points into Charisma bringing your stats up.
