A band of primitive freedom fighters overcome an occupying force with superior technology and firepower.\nThe Silmarillion \u2014 The Napoleonic Wars(?)\u2026 This is a stretch; the analogy is to one invincible commander who is finally toppled in the very end, never to come back; it would put England into the role of he Elves.\nConan == Ancient Greece\u2019s \u201cheroic\u201d age (cf. Illiad/Odyssey)", "It\u2019s usually a mix of several periods but the most prominent in those you mention is, by far, the Late Middle Ages. That is 1200s\u20131500 AD.\nSometimes they have a lot from early Renaissance but they usually do not have gunpowder since they have magic and dragons instead.\nConan and Lord of The Rings are supposed to take place in some distant prehistoric period. But they have technology of the Late Middle Ages and the excuse for that is the Atlantis myth that is a strong influence in both universes. We see that in the prolong of Conan.\nBut also Numenor that made the great kingdoms of Men in Tolkien\u2019s Middle Earth was a great island in the West, greatly advanced that was destroyed much like Atlantis.\nA highly advanced civilisation that was closing to the age of renaissance but collapsed. It\u2019s a popular myth in fantasy. There are genres that include gunpower and steam engines(steampunk, for example) but they are distinctly different from the poppular epic fantasy in question.\nWhy do I say Late Middle Ages? Let\u2019s start with Conan. The first movie borrowed costumes from the movie about Alexander Nevsky, a historical drama about events that took place in 1200s.\nConan\u2019s main antagonist in the movie, Tulsa Doom features the iconic helmet.\nThe movie has a mix of Valkyrie like characters, teutonic like armour, Mongol like people and names\u2026all fighting together. Pretty much what happened in the 1200s in Eastern Europe with the Mongol invasion.\nLord of the Rings also shares this trope. The evil hordes of the East invade the West. The armies also have weapons of the period. Even if you check the poor orcs at the battle of Pelenno,outside Mins Tirith, they have a variety of weapons that were common in late middle ages to face the charge of the Rohirrim:\nBut it\u2019s even more obvious when you look at the armour of an Uruk hai pikeman(pretty much like the Swiss) or the kinda similar armour of Minas Tirith soldiers.\nThey even have crossbows which is typical of the period.\nAnd of course trebuchets in Minas Tirith. These machines were used in Europe mostly in 1200\u20131500 AD.\nAlso, the castles themselves seem quite of that time. Before the middle ages the Romans would use a lot of bricks, that we don\u2019t see often in epic fantasy. And after the middle ages, walls would be lower and thicker,star shaped forts etc.\nThe most obvious example of the resemblance between epic fantasy and late middle ages is Game of Thrones(ASOIAF). Not only the weapons, armors, castles and the political system is similar but the society and the events are based on Europe of the late middle ages. The main story is based on the War of the Roses that took place in England 1455\u20131487 AD. We have a bank in Braavos, a city that resembles Italian cities of the period(especially Venice) and around 1400 we get the first banks\u2026in Italy. The Red Wedding incident is inspired by a similar incident that took place in the 1400s, in Scotland.\nAlso, ships are interesting. War galleys with oars were still in use in late Middle ages but gradually became less and less prominent. We get to see that in epic fantasy too. Sometimes they have oars, sometimes not. But they still do not have cannons so they\u2019re not yet Renaissance ships.", "If I had to pick an era when the genre shifted from rarity to industry it would probably be the late '70s to mid-80s, with the trifecta of Eddings, Brooks, and the morass of D&D novels swamping the shelves."], "date_list": ["Feb 24, 2018", "Feb 24, 2018", "Feb 24, 2018"], "question_author": "Zenon Kogut", "view_list": [331, 0, 15]}, "735": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Scott Dowell"], "question_title": "What do you think of Matthew Tindal's \"Christianity As Old As Creation\"?", "topic_list": ["Deism", "Book Reviews", "Christianity", "Books", "Religion", "Survey Question"], "no_of_view": "813", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["Sounds like to me he was just a author of books and opinions he wrote Christianity is not old as time really its not that that old Christianity is man made religion.now the disciples called them selves Christians,all the mean is Christ like. they want to be like Christ in his ways like jesus told them to be.man added the anity part on the end of the word Christian to make it a religion.the word Christianity isn't even in the holy bible."], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Anonymous", "view_list": [32]}, "568": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Anonymous", "Angela Daniel", "Robert Cottrell"], "question_title": "What is your own playbook on how to handle grief?", "topic_list": ["Grief Recovery", "Grief", "Broken Hearts", "Loss, Grief, Bereavement and Mourning", "Death and Dying", "Understanding Emotions", "Emotions", "Books", "Life Advice", "Survey Question"], "no_of_view": "640", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1], "ans_list": ["after 3 years you start to feel better, though you never stop grieving; it comes in waves.", "Stuff it in until you can tough it out", "Grief is a very unique process for each person. The best written and engaging works in the last 50 years.\nAugust 1914 - Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn - I rarely read or recommend fictional works in the study of history, but there is a perspective in this work that is vital to the understanding of the Russian war effort and under the spell of Solzhenitsyn\u2019s writing, it is compelling like few other works about the war. I would rank it above All Quiet on the Western Front - Erich Maria Remarque in that respect.\nThe First World War - John Keegan - Keegan works are all very well written and from a perspective that is inherently instructional. Hebrew in particular, does not translate as well into, say English as it does into Syrian/Aramaic or Arabic, whereas Greek too has its peculiarities.\nWhy is the Bible censored?\nNot sure what you mean by this vague, poorly phrased question, Miracle Achebe, but if by censored you mean edited, then yes, text is usually edited before publication, to ensure there are no errors (not always successfully - some years ago I found five printing errors in a very popular evangelical Bible) and that the text is properly laid out.\nIf by \u201ccensored\" you mean cut stuff out, then most modern Bible omit certain verses, due their later provenance or indicate that they are not to be found in the earliest manuscripts. That is not censoring, it is simply ensuring that the Bible you are reading is true to the more accurate Bible manuscripts. A passage that falls into this category in Mark 16:9\u201320. Without asking your printer, you don\u2019t have any way of knowing which of these signatures they\u2019ll be printing.\nWhat I do is a near-final layout of the book to get to the \u201cnatural\u201d page count. Then, I provide that number to the printer with my other requirements (paper stock, etc.) to find out the signature count. This then lets me know if I happen to be right on target or not (usually not). If I\u2019m just a little over a signature, I\u2019ll work on the page layout to get it down to fit. If I\u2019m short, then I\u2019ll see if I can easily stretch out the layout to make it fit. If this isn\u2019t feasible for some reason, or is only partially feasible, then I just add the few necessary blank pages at the end to fill out the signature.\nThese necessary adjustments are why you sometimes see a half-title page at the start of a book before the full-title page. Or perhaps the start of sections in the book will be their own section-title pages. There are all sorts of \u201ctricks\u201d for filling out a book a few extra pages to fit a signature (and likewise for reducing a book).\nThanks for the A2A \u2014 I hope this helps!\n[Answered: How many signatures should a book have?]"], "date_list": ["Apr 11, 2020"], "question_author": "Faruque Hossain Piyada", "view_list": [21]}, "34": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Momina Ali", "Azizashameera Alih"], "question_title": "What is the most influential book?", "topic_list": ["Influential", "Influence", "Book Recommendations", "Books"], "no_of_view": "1,738", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Al-chemist by Paulo Coelho (in my opinion), because I have read a very small number of books.", "The Republic by Plato is one of the most influential book. There are so many exciting discoveries from the book that help us in 2020.", "The story is an allegorical prophecy inside a moral lesson.\nCompare the 3 days inside the whale with the three days between the Crucifixion and Resurrection.\nThere is an underlying message to the entire story \u2014 do not run away from your responsibilities.", "Dr.David Jeremiah has an excellent comment on this:\nIn the seventeenth verse of Jonah, chapter one, the scene changes from a ship to a fish\u2014a great fish prepared by the Lord for a specific purpose. It is quite evident that the Lord is not finished dealing with his servant. The Lord prepared a fish to swallow him up.\nThere is no story in all the Bible that has caused so much derision, mockery, and blundering exegesis as the story of Jonah and the whale. As someone said, it might appear that the whale swallowed up the commentators as well as the prophet. In many areas of biblical study, secular research often brings historical data alongside the Scriptures to shed modern light on ancient events. While we don\u2019t wait for this evidence before we believe the Bible (we believe the Bible because it is the Word of God), discoveries often marvelously confirm that which many felt to be fanciful or mythical. The biblical story of a fish swallowing a man is that kind of event. Our own research in biblical or non-biblical books will give us pages of detail about actual cases of fish large enough to swallow humans, and of humans who were swallowed by fish and lived to tell about it!\nConsider the 100-foot-long sulphur bottom whale caught off Cape Cod in 1935, with a mouth 12 feet wide, and multiple stomach compartments large enough for several men. This mammal is know to be able to disgorge offending stomach contents just as Jonah was disgorged by his great fish.\nRecords exist of an English sailor who fell overboard in the English Channel, was swallowed by a monstrous whale shark, and was found alive when the shark was caught 48 hours later. There was a similar experience of another sailor on a whaling ship near the Falkland Islands who was swallowed by a giant whale but found alive when the whale was harpooned and cut open a number of hours later.\nInteresting as these stories are, they really are not the point. We do not need the records of natural man to prove to us that a sovereign God can create, and direct, the elements of His creation to accomplish His purposes. If we do not believe that God could, and did, prepare a giant fish to discipline a prophet, then we will have trouble believing as well that a dead man named Jesus of Nazareth came back to life. Don\u2019t forget\u2014it is the three days of Jonah in the belly of a great fish that Jesus used to predict His own resurrection after three days. Jesus said it, we believe it, and that settles it.\nJeremiah, D. (1998). The runaway prophet: jonah (Study guide) (pp. 34\u201335). Nashville, TN: Thomas Nelson Publishers.", "We are not told. It could have been a whale or a giant shark. The classification of mammals and fish did not come until hundreds of years later.", "The Bible does not tell us the type of fish Jonah found himself in, it just says that he found himself inside a large fish. .\u2014Jon 1:17\u20132:10\n.\nBut there is evidence that the seaport of Joppa anciently was a headquarters for whalers. On the other hand, it is possible that the great white shark was the fish that swallowed Jonah. One of these that was caught in 1939 contained two whole 2-m-long (6 ft) sharks in its stomach\u2014each about the size of a man. And the great white sharks have roamed all the seas, i", "The whale shark can be up to 70 feet long And is found in the Mediterranean Sea", "The Bible does not say except it was a great fish", "The great fish in the story of Jonah represents the god of the Ninevites, Dagon. This would be particularly relevant to early hearers of the story because they would know instantly that in Jonah\u2019s rebellion against God, and in his contempt for the Ninevites, he is swallowed up by their fish-god as a form of admonishment.\nThe book of Jonah is a comedy of ironies and a testimony to God\u2019s ability to get an important message to desperate people, even when using a reluctant prophet. Jonah sat on a nearby hill for days waiting for God to destroy the Ninevites, but He did not.\nThere God provided plant which gave Jonah shade. Then God provided a worm to destroy the plant, at which point Jonah says to God, \u201cIt would be better for me to die than put up with this.\u201d\n\u201cIs it right for you to be this angry about the plant?\u201d Replied God.\n\u201cIt is,\u201d Said Jonah, \u201cI\u2019m angry enough to want to die.\u201d\nGod concludes the story by saying, \u201cYou have been concerned about this plant, though you did not tend it or make it grow. It sprang up overnight and died overnight. And should I not have concern for the great city of Nineveh, in which there are more than a hundred and twenty thousand people who cannot tell their right hand from their left\u2014and also many animals?\u201d\n(Dagon is also thought to be one of the gods of the Philistines, Syrians, Amorites, Egyptians, and generally part of the bronze age pantheon of Mesopotamia and Canaan.)", "It is now common knowledge that no fish or shark would eat a man whole, so the modern assumption is that it was some species of whale. Robert Cushman Murphy, a scientist at the American Museum of Natural History and extremely knowledgeable about whales, said a man could be swallowed whole by a sperm whale, but that no man could survive in a whale any longer than if he were held under water. This is just one reason the Book of Jonah is now widely regarded as having been written as a novel with a theological purpose.\nWhich brings us to a more modern legend sometimes used to support the veracity of the Book of Jonah. This tells of a crewman named Bartley from the Star of the East who, in 1891, supposedly spent fifteen hours in a whale but was cut out alive. The Australian Geographic\ndebunked this story:\nHistorians have since concluded that the Star of the East was not a whaler, and there was no James Bartley on its crew manifest, while scientists confirm it is not possible to survive for 15 hours in the stomach of a sperm whale. For nearly 100 years the media largely swallowed this whale of a story without once trying to interview or find a picture of Bartley. It\u2019s a great example of never letting the facts get in the way of a good story.", "The great fish was Almighty God incarnate in fish flesh form. Jonah was the Holy Spirit God incarnate in human flesh form.\nWe know this because of what is told to us in the OT canon Book of Tobit. Some ancient manuscripts tells us a DOG followed Tobias and the archangel Raphael whilst other ancient manuscripts tell us the LORD followed them.\nThe Hebrew word for fish is DAG, pronounced DOG, GOD spelled in reverse. The Hebrew word for dove is JONAH(yownah).", "Jonah and Leedsichthys problematicus.\nMatthew Murdock\nThe book of Jonah talks about a \u2018great fish\u2019 that was large enough to swallow a man alive. Many have claimed that no whale or fish could ever swallow a man. These critics, however, are unaware of the fossil evidence of \u2018great fish\u2019 in countries all around the world. About ten years ago I visited the Ann Arbor Museum of Natural History in Michigan. I recall staring in amazement as I stood next to a skull of an extinct fish named Dunkleosteus terrelli (figure 1). The skull itself was about 1 m high, but the largest skull found was 1.2 m high. I thought to myself that if the skull was this big, then its body length must be incredible. Some quick research indicated that this armored fish may have reached a length of almost 5 m. If it were not for the glass separating us, I could have easily climbed into its mouth.\nWorld\u2019s biggest fish fossil found; but largely ignored\nThe fossil bones of a giant fish named \u2018Leedsichthys problematicus\u2019 (figure 2) provide support for the reliability of the book of Jonah. \u2018L. problematicus\u2019 was named after an English farmer, Alfred Leeds, who discovered the first fossils of this species in the late 1800s. The name \u2018problematicus\u2019 refers to the problem paleontologists encountered trying to classify this new fish. Leeds sold this skeleton to the Hunterian Museum (Glasgow University) way back in 1915, but few have ever heard of this discovery. Oddly enough, work on reconstructing it began only about five years ago. This fish, alleged to be 155 million years old, was an astonishing 15 m long (>50 feet). But a new specimen of the same species found recently surpasses this, reaching a length of about 30 m!\nThis is about the length of 3 school buses and is twice the size of a whale shark (14 m), or about the size of a blue whale, making it the largest fish ever discovered. Unlike Dunkleosteus, Leedsichthys would not have torn its prey apart with its teeth. In fact it didn\u2019t have teeth on its jaws; it used thousands of gill rakers with needle-like teeth to filter plankton and small fish from the water. This fish was large enough to swallow a man whole.\nHow did Jonah survive inside the creature? Is it possible for Jonah to have remained undigested? Some sharks are able to control their digestive systems, and could keep from digesting a swallowed object for several days. Because of this, undigested food is commonly found inside shark stomachs during dissection.\nThe whale shark can turn its stomach inside out and bring up its contents in a process called gastric eversion. The whale shark may not have been the only \u2018fish\u2019with this ability, and Jonah\u2019s body could have been easily \u2018spat out\u2019 upon dry land. Conclusion We must recognize that it is not possible to know with certainty what species of fish swallowed Jonah; the Bible does not tell us. But having found fossil evidence of some of these giants helps support biblical accuracy.\nEndnotes:\n1 Dunkleosteusis named after Dr David Dunkle, one of the first men to study this creature. The name Dunkleosteus literally means \u2018Dunkle\u2019s bones\u2019.\n2 The whale shark is not a whale at all, but a member of the shark family.", "It is interesting to note that the Greek New Testament uses the word \u201cwhale,\u201d while the Hebrew book of Jonah says that \u201cthe Lord had prepared a great fish.\u201d (Jonah 1:17.)\nThe fact that the animal was \u201cprepared\u201d could indicate that it was not a conventional animal, and that it was easily capable of swallowing a man whole. In addition, there exists a more recently documented case of a man who was actually swallowed by a whale and lived to tell about it.\nIn 1891, a whaling crew operating off the Falkland Islands was beset with difficulties. A whale, which emerged when a harpoon sunk into its flesh, turned on the small boat and capsized it. Three of the men who were overboard were unable to make it back to the mother vessel.\nLater that evening, the dying whale surfaced and was rigged to the side of the whaling ship. When the crew began the task of butchering it, one of the three missing men, James Bartley, was found inside the whale\u2019s stomach. He had survived in his mammalian undersea prison for 15 hours! The acidity of the whale\u2019s stomach had permanently bleached his skin and removed his hair, and he was almost blind. Unable to continue his chosen trade, Bartley turned to shoe making and remained a cobbler the rest of his life.\nThe seemingly impossible story of Jonah becomes more believeable when viewed in relationship to the equally fantastic\ufeff\u2014but true\ufeff\u2014modern event. And as for the historicity of the prophet Jonah, son of Amittai, he is known to have lived in the days of Jeroboam II. (See 2 Kgs. 14:25.)", "What was the great fish in the book of Jonah?\nA fairy tale fish.", "Jonah 1:17\n17 Now the LORD had prepared a great fish to swallow Jonah. Ford, The Dragon Waiting. Richard III battling the Byzantine Empire in a world where magic exists, and Julian the Apostate won his campaign against Christianity.", "Several alternative history novels come to mind. Over the years my favorite series has been the Emberverse books by S. M. Stirling, which I\u2019m not altogether sure qualifies as an alternate history: On a certain date in 1998, all manner of high-energy technologies, including gunpowder and electricity, simply stop working. Most of the world\u2019s population dies, and the survivors prove to be endlessly inventive in forging after-Change societies. But it\u2019s definitely more of a fantasy series than an alternate history.\nThen there are a bunch of science fiction stories that were written in a future that has now come and gone. For example, The Door into Summer by Robert Heinlein was written in 1957 but was set in 1970 and 2000, so the events described in that book have now become a kind of \u201calternate future.\u201d The same thing is also somewhat true of the Star Trek franchise, with its ruinous Eugenics Wars in the 1990s.\nA couple of other series I\u2019ve liked immensely but which aren\u2019t quite a straight alternate history would be The Tales of Alvin Maker by Orson Scott Card, and the Worldwar Series by Harry Turtledove. Alvin Maker is set in early 19th Century America, but one where magic is a very real force; and the Worldwar books start off with World War II being interrupted by an invasion of lizard people from another planet.\nOne book that looks like a more standard alternate history is The Yiddish Policeman\u2019s Union by Michael Chabon. It\u2019s set in a world where the Jews lost the 1948 war and were forcibly expelled from Palestine; they have instead created a Jewish state on Sitka Island in Alaska. It\u2019s an interesting premise but unfortunately Chabon does very little with it; instead he gives us a murder mystery (and a very good one, I hasten to add) that could have been set anywhere. The setting is wasted, almost irrelevant to the story.\nProbably the best \u201cpure\u201d alternate history series that I have read was Turtledove\u2019s Southern Victory series in which the South does indeed win the Civil War. The series goes on and on, unevenly, up through a parallel World War II; The South goes on to lose World War I but keeps its independence, and the most fascinating part of the books is the rise of Jake Featherston, an angry but charismatic Southerner who becomes dictator of the South as an obvious parallel to Adolf Hitler. For some reason I could always picture Sean Penn in the role perfectly.\nStand-alone alternate history books I\u2019ve loved:\nIf the South Had Won the Civil War by MacKinlay Cantor. M\u00f8rch"], "question_title": "What are one or two key differences between late 20th century writers and their predecessors earlier in this century?", "topic_list": ["Centuries", "20th Century", "21st Century", "Similarities and Differences", "Writers and Authors", "Literature", "World History", "Reading", "Writing", "Books", "History"], "no_of_view": "8,782", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 4], "ans_list": ["To answer this question, we need to look beyond the U.S.\nUlysses by James Joyce was published in 1922.\nTo The Lighthouse by Virginia Woolfe was published in 1927.\nThese books and their later novels laid out stream of consciousness writing, invented after the trauma of WWI and the discovery and mapping of the unconscious mind by Blueler, Freud, Jung and Adler.\nJohn Steinbeck\u2019s Grapes of Wrath, published in 1939, was about the traumatic social and economic disruption of the Great Depression. Steinbeck permanently changed American English in fiction.\nJoyce and Wolfe both died in 1941 during WWII. They and Steinbeck experienced two world wars, and the Great Depression for ten years of the period between the wars. Henry Miller and Anais Nin likewise.\nThose experiences might have something to do with the depth of their writing which I have yet to see in any current American author. And though Fitzgerald lived through WWI and the Great Depression, I can\u2019t find that experience in his books.\nIan McKewan, Louise Erdrich and Kashuo Ishiguro are in the ball park of profound writers.\nFor me, those writers since 1960 who come the closest to pre-WWII writers in depth of perception, the craft of writing, and new invention in the novel form are: Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Isabelle Allende in South America, with the invention of \u201cmagical realism,\u201d Carlos Fuentes in Mexico with his experimental fiction structures, and Jose Gironella in Spain, who wrote his trilogy about the Spanish Civil War, which is considered one of the greatest European novels of the 20th century.\nAll of these writers took part in historic social and political shifts in their countries, including civil wars and in at least one instance a military coup that destroyed democracy. That may have had something to do with the deep humanity in their writing.", "Thank you for the A2A. This is a fascinating question, as evidenced by the responses so far, most of which focus on thematic differences rather than literary movements or styles, and with which I quite concur, especially John Rodriquez and Henry Martin. However, in his brief answer Audun Morch nails the main differences between the first and second halves of the 20th century as the foundational shift between modernism and postmodernism which occurred during WWII. The first sub-movements in postmodernism flowered with the Beats: Ginsberg, Snyder, Burroughs, Kerouac, et al. and the rise of magical realism with Borges, Marquez, Allende, Llosa and others.\nBut come the end of the 20th century we see the rise of post-postmodernism, in effect a reaction to postmodernism even as that movement was a reaction to modernism. Also termed metamodernism, this emergent movement encompasses critical theory, philosophy, literature, art, and architecture. Because we are in the early stages of this movement it is rather hard to define as yet, but in simple (way too simple) terms we see the 20th century in two halves, modernism (which began in the late 19th century) and postmodernism, with an emergent shift to metamodernism.", "Hi, Julian. There\u2019s no way I could improve on (or even compete with) the erudite answers that your question has attracted from Henry, John and Thomas hereabouts.\nAll I was going to suggest, anyway, was that you dive into Fitzgerald as typical of the earlier generation and, for comparison, Donna Tartt perhaps. I still think such an exercise, though time consuming, would actually be time well spent.\nBest wishes. bm.", "The main difference between early and later 20th century writers? Simple - it\u2019s the cultural shift that allowed most of art to get away with exploring darker, deeper themes.\nBasically, the way I see it is this: After WWI and WWII, people had been through so much shit that a little risque art did not bother them. Artists, and writers especially, started exploring darker themes in the human psyche. There were movements to explore the darkness, and there were movements that attempted to get away from the darkness while still addressing some serious issues. Take surrealism. Whimsical on the surface, profound and eye opening between the lines. Beatniks - same. Getting away from the shit the world had seen and experiences, while reaching deep down to lay the psyche and the messed-up human nature for the world to see.\nMagical realism - ditto.\nThe one I don\u2019t get is the rise in escapism and romance. Formulaic, superficial stuff.", "The style of writing changes significantly over time. The use of language as well as the display of setting changes as each generation of writers comes along and leaves their literary footprint. \u201cDetective\u201d stories of the nineteen-teens are very different in styles format the Ellery Queen and Kinsey Millhone Alphabet Series.", "Comparative literature seems to have accepted pluralism and ascendant cultures. Globalization was both an enabler and a subject. Feminism and sci-fi both went mainstream and split into subcategories. Reviews of the previous century were nostalgic for the simplicity of themes before climate change, posthumanism, ethics of technology, or the most recent conflicts. Media included self-published ebooks and blogs, sometimes translated by machine. Besides tropes, authors subverted trendy memes. Now the planet seems to be in sync and taking a breather to reflect.", "There are more post-colonial writers of note getting attention now, writing in the language of the old colonial master.\nOtherwise not enough time has gone by for there to be a difference. Do not copy any text out of the old novel.\nInstead, make any improvements the paperback novel needs, throw in your own modern conceptions & research, and use your own sparkling prose instead of the original author\u2019s plodding stuff. So at bed-time when they were little, I made it my practice to read them one story in English and another in German (not necessarily in that order). I picked up a good deal of (polite!) colloquial German myself that way\u2014and indeed, now they are grown up, both kids are fully bilingual.\nLGHH", "I recommend learning a language in any way that you like. I tell people to talk to people because someone learning English in my city has over 100,000 people who will help learn English. Read comics, children\u2019s books, anything you think you are interested in or you think can help you. Read signs on the street, signs in the subway. Talk to children, who are very good teachers.", "I don\u2019t recommend children books. They have lots of words that you will never use. Better read books created specially for learning the language.", "This idea is very intelligent and creative of you - the head of my college English Department did it to learn German, but using an adult novel.\nIf you\u2019re learning Spanish - try a famous Spanish children\u2019s book, Platero Y Yo - Platero and I.\nIt\u2019s by Juan Ramon Jimenez, about a donkey named Platero. It\u2019s been translated into English.\nIf you get copies in both languages you will be able to go back and forth. Keep a Spanish grammar book handy to look up verb forms, etc. And a dictionary. Jimenez was a great poet, so the language is really beautiful to read even in English.\nAlso, I believe Cornelia Funke\u2019s books were in German first - they would be very good to learn German.\nThis is a VERY good way to learn a language as long as you pick more complicated books - authors who have real vocabulary. Once you have vocabulary and basic grammar, you could move on to expanding your knowledge by doing it with an adult novel.", "The best children\u2019s books are a good read for adults too, so they\u2019re ideal (if you have access to the right ones). You need to be able to get them in translation too though so that you don\u2019t waste most of your time looking up dictionaries. It isn\u2019t a bad idea to work with books that you enjoyed as a child and would like to read again. However, if your idea is to work with lots of simpler picture books with only a line of text per page, it\u2019s unlikely that you\u2019ll be able to get translations of them, so you\u2019ll just end up having to look up dictionaries a lot, and that eats up a lot of time. That\u2019s why your starting point should be to use the graded texts in a language course as your introduction to reading the language, and all of those should have translations with them if the course is properly designed. If translations are absent, get a better course. By the end of the course you\u2019ll still be a long way from being able to read proper text at any speed, but a well-chosen children\u2019s book will give you a slightly gentler introduction to that than adult books, but the difference isn\u2019t as great as you might expect, so the right adult book can be fine. Autobiographies can make good reading material because they tend to cover a wide range of topics before they specialise later, and when they do specialise, you want that anyway because you\u2019re reading about someone you\u2019re interested in because of that specialisation.", "On the contrary, it can be very useful. HE OWNED A LARGE EMPIRE COVERING THE AREAS OF CENTRAL INDIA ETC.,,HE IS NOT MENTIONED IN OUR HISTORY BOOKS BECAUSE INFORMATIONS ABOUT HIM WERE NOT CLEAR.\nTHE HATHIGIMPHA INSCRIPTIONS WERE THE ONLY SOURCES OF INFORMATION ABOUT THE KALINGA KING KHARAVELA. HE WAS APPOINTED AS THE HEIR-APPARENT PRINCE OR YUVARAJA AT THE AGE OF 16 AND REMAINED IN OFFICE FOR ABOUT 9 YEARS . HE WAS CROWNED AS THE KING AT THE AGE OF 24 YEARS.\nDIFFERENT SCHOLARS INTERPRETS DIFFERENTLY AS THE HATHIGUMPHA INSCRIPTIONS WERE WAS DAMAGED WHICH DESCRIBED HIS REIGN IN YEAR WISE.\nEMPIRE OF KHARAVELA:\nHIS EMPIRE INCLUDED THE PRESENT DAY PUTAK AND CUTTAK DISTRICTS OF ODISHA AND MAY HAVE INCLUDED VISHAKAPATNAM AND GANJAM DISTRICTS. ACCORDING TO DIETMAR ROTHERMUND HIS EMPIRE HAVE INCLUDED THE LARGE PARTS OF EAST AND CENTRAL INDIA.\nSO, AS THE HISTORIC SOURCES ABOUT KHARAVELA WAS NOT CLEAR AND HE IS NOT MENTIONED IN OUR HISTORY BOOKS . .\nMAURYAN EMPIRE:\nTHE MAURYAN EMPIRE EXTENDED FROM HIMALAYAS IN THE NORTH TO MYSORE IN SOUTH,HINDU KUSH IN THE NORTH-WEST TO BRAHMAPUTRA IN THE EAST. By means of an outside agency, usually supernatural, the hero is shown the error of his ways and begins to appreciate his life and the people around him.\nThere are one or two differences in The Chimes. For example, the hero is not following an evil philosophy of life built up by himself, but is rather a working man whose misanthropic and self-hating views are taken from people in authority who despise the poor.\nThe political economist Alderman Cute sneers at Trotty, the elderly ticket-porter for eating food and wishing to allow his daughter Meg to marry her fianc\u00e9, Richard. Cute feels that they hardly have a right to live at all, let alone get married in destitution.\nThese views are backed by the local MP Sir Joseph Bowley, a supposed philanthropist who takes Trotty to task for having debts, an easy complaint to be made by a powerful man who can easily afford to pay his own debts.\nInstead it is left to Trotty and Meg to show real charity when they dissuade the poor countryman Will Fern from seeking help, accompanied by his small niece. They realise that Cute will have Fern imprisoned, so they give shelter to the uncle and niece for one night. As ever it is the poor who prove more charitable than those who have the money to give.\nNonetheless the dubious opinions of Cute and Bowley have infected Trotty\u2019s mind and prevent him from enjoying what he has. He is drawn to the church by the chimes of the bells, and there he encounters spirits and goblins.\nLike Scrooge, Trotty is shown an alternative bleaker future that may happen if he gives in to despair Meg and Richard defer marriage until it is too late, and the broken Richard becomes an alcoholic. Fern is arrested and his niece turns to prostitution. Meg has a child by Richard, but is ready to kill herself and her child when the dream ends.\nWhat is curious about the ending is that there is no clear action that takes place that will prevent the events happening in the future. In A Christmas Carol, Scrooge has the option of reformation. Here the only difference is that Meg and Richard decide to marry sooner rather than later, and we hope that they can avoid a bad fate, but there is no Deux ex machina to rescue them from poverty.\nAs with other Christmas stories, Dickens throws in a moral message. He deplores the conditions of poverty that force people to lead terrible lives, and the self-serving callous philosophies developed by the ruling class to justify these iniquities.\nThe Chimes is not one of Dickens\u2019 best works, but it is readable, and it has a good heart. Many of the ideas were explored better in A Christmas Carol, but every story by Dickens brings some new ideas and is of some interest, and this is no exception."], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Dane John Cobain", "view_list": [30]}, "646": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Michael Willhoite", "Jay Robert Baer", "Sue Sanders"], "question_title": "Is it right that fictional characters should have their own Wikipedia pages?", "topic_list": ["Wikipedia Policies and Guidelines", "Wikipedia Editing", "Wikipedia Community", "Wikipedia", "Fiction", "Fictional Characters", "Books"], "no_of_view": "442", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1], "ans_list": ["In the case of Sherlock Holmes, why not!?", "Such a ridiculous question", "Is it right that fictional characters should have their own Wikipedia pages?\nYou ask \u201cis it right\u201d. That depends on the person and his or her attitude toward such simplistic discussions. Up for argument might be Scarlett O\u2019Hara, featured in Wikipedia\u2019s site Scarlett O'Hara - Wikipedia\n. I can add Jiminy Cricket here: jiminy cricket - Google Search\nand TV personalities like The Cisco Kid (TV series) - Wikipedia\n.\nI don\u2019t know what your defense is if you don\u2019t feel it \u201cright\u201d that these personalities are presented on an information-based website as flesh and blood beings. To many thousands of people, these are characters that became embedded into our psyche, that are as flesh and blood real (even Jiminy Cricket) as much as our own parents and best friends were. These entities LIVE, like today\u2019s versions of the same have definite lives of their own to bond with their fans\u2019.\nTake a test for yourself. pain,rebirth,dieseas,death,hatred.we can get freedom by following ancient ways of getting moksha.\nI would recommend you to read Gyaneshwari written by god dnyaneshwar for the true knowledge of god.", "First of all, let's see what do we mean by mythology. Mythology is derived from the Greek words, Mythos (that which is not necessarily logical or true) and Logos (that which is logical). So, we can say that Mythology is a logical explanation to that which may not appear logical to an outsider.\nNow, the reason mythological texts are important is because it gives us a sneak-peek into the cultural history of the society. It tells us how our ancestors viewed society, how certain practices - which may not make sense now - came into being an integral part of our culture, how the society unites under the common belief system. It is a historical record for the society.\nIt is however very important that you remove any filters before reading such a text. You must realize that these texts have been written down thousands of years ago. Our understanding of the society changes every year as we grow, so do not judge the texts too hard. Also majority of the so called mythological texts around the world have been translated by outsiders. I am not against this, as it shows that outsiders are interested in your culture, but at the same time, it is true that they do not have the in-depth knowledge and understanding of these text as an insider, who has literally lived them. This has evidently led to lot of incorrect conclusions and misunderstanding during the translation which has led to disastrous outcomes.\nComing to our own Indian texts. I am going to explain the importance (of the Hindu texts as I do not see myself worthy to comment on other Indian texts )from an Indian point of view and not an outsider. But before that we need to understand what our texts are really about.\nLet's check the classification for the Hindu texts first. It would not be wrong to claim that India is a treasure-house of literature. I will try covering all types of texts - spiritual, religious, literature etc, but may still miss some. Do comment if I go wrong or miss something.\nThe Hindu texts can be widely divided as being sacred and secular. Hindus have six main classes of sacred scriptures - (i) Srutis (ii) Smritis (iii) Itihasa (iv) Puranas (v) Agamas and (vi) Darshanas. There are also four secular scriptures - (i) Subhashitas (ii) Kavyas (iii)Natakas and (iv) Alankaras.\nI have tried to provide the classifications, divisions and short commentary on the Hindu texts to keep the answer short. Please let me know in the comments if you need this in details.\nSacred Scriptures -\nI have tried my best to give you a quick glimpse into the vast stores of texts that our ancestors left for us. Some of the above referred texts may be seen as mythology, but for us it is the collective wisdom of our ancestors. There is boundless knowledge and wisdom trapped in those works. Only those who seek the knowledge within, with faith in them can unravel the mysteries.\nIf we discard them as mere mythology, we also deny the knowledge in them. The idea and knowledge within is same for the atheist and a believer. The believer acknowledges the wisdom while an atheist may discard it because the text talks in term of a supreme power.", "Yes, we should definitely read mythological texts. Because it can show the fact of life and we should learn to read this Tv shows are not life's fact. We need to read this because we need to change our mentality about abroad is not our culture. Which is shown on television that is not the fact that is only for entertaining us. When we read this book then we can know about our own culture and could behave like a civilised person. And more things we can learn from mythological texts. So we should read this and follow it with the service of our parents.", "At the outset let me state that there is no mythological texts. The Puranas and Itihasas are not any mythology of magic or history of kings, queens, helmsmen. Puranas, Upanishads and Itihasas are technical commentaries on the Vedas. These commentaries are written by ancient intellectuals in the form of anecdotes, metaphors and other short stories mainly to educate the masses for easy understanding of the abstract Tatwams of the Vedas.\nTherefore when we read these texts we start learning about various values, wisdom, life, science, process of cleansing our mind and intellect and finally to realise the Supreme Being within ourselves.", "This is basic, just when you born, you must call, aai, or mamma,\nThen your progess starts.\nDont know you believe in purana,\nBut it is stated that, first life started in water, before 15000 years,\nand before 150 years, the evolution study by Dorvin, also conform it.", "Because it leads towards the door of spirituality.\nand a better question would be why should be inclined towards spirituality?\nIncase that's your query let me know.", "Just to understand all of them are not mythological stories , some of which are genuine.", "One chapter from my book that will be helpful:\n\u201cWe observe that in history, everything from social issues, political situations, and economic status is covered. History is factual and based on a firm foundation of proof. Even when different historians have distinct opinions about debatable points, history is orderly and objective. Myths, on the other hand, are seldom factual. These are mostly restatements of legends. Many of them relate only to a certain culture and many stories around the same myth are usually in circulation in different societies and countries. Similarities between myths, such as the ones around the great flood, show that they also highlight problems that different cultures faced in daily life. As such, myths are not only subjective stories in the words or imaginations of individuals but are also mere embroidered refinements of facts. Therefore, though myths may not be historically accurate, they are nevertheless a part of history.\nI, however, strongly believe that both the Ramayana and the Mahabharata are historically real and that the stories are woven around Lord Rama or Krishna took place, though these may have been distorted somewhat to suit the imagination of the storyteller. It is quite possible that the bridge to Lanka was in fact actually built by an army of Vanaras for Lord Rama; the Pandavas and Kauravas do exist, and if that is so, then the story of Rama and Ravana, the demon king\u2019s fight is also real as is the account of the dispute between two branches of the same family. And as far as the weapons are concerned, these might be the highly developed technologies and may have been interpreted as some kind of divine weapons by the simple people of that time. That is why; events of the Ramayana and the Mahabharata appear highly exaggerated as works of fiction.\nTherefore, we don\u2019t know how much of the stories are true and how much of them are false.\nHowever, millions of Hindus including me believe these stories and follow the ideals shown by Lord Rama and Lord Krishna. Such a belief has created the common Indian values which have been instrumental in keeping Indian society united and grounded. They are the roots of our customs and our traditions,\u201d concluded the Professor.\n\u201cIf you agree to the story of the existence of the lost city of Atlantis, then you must also acknowledge the lost city of Dwarka,\u201d Major Aarti said. \u201cOr if you believe in the existence of\nNoah, then you must agree to the existence of Manu and the Matsya Avatar, the incarnation of Lord Vishnu.\u201d\n\u201cIn my opinion, we should be giving importance to the object or the essence and not to the subject. The events described in the epics should not be taken literally but should be interpreted in the form of symbols or metaphors. One should try to look beyond the words and try to read between the lines,\u201d Professor Gaekwad clarified.\n\u201cBut what is the authenticity of those facts? How can one prove that they happened?\u201d Brandon queried.\n\u201cWhen it comes to testing the authenticity of events, one should read the Vaimanika Shastra, a Sanskrit text on aerospace technology that claims that the aerial vehicles described in the Puranic texts are real. This is one of the many texts out there that support the actual occurrence of events.\u201d\n\u201cWhy do you believe that Pythagoras\u2019 theorem is true? Or why do you believe that the sum of the three interior angles of a triangle is 180 degrees? Because we can very well prove them. If we cannot prove them, we treat them as myths. Similarly, we can prove that the Mahabharata events were factual using a set of archaeological and logical evidence. For instance, Krishna\u2019s legendary city of Dwarka mentioned in the Mahabharata has been discovered beneath the Gulf of Cambay in the Arabian Sea. The ruins are the same as the description provided in the epic. The hints of ancient flying aircraft called Vimanas in the Mahabharata have been discovered at several places across the globe,\u201d said the Professor.\nFor more please read the book \u201cSignboard at Dholavira\u201d\nFollow me on: Nishith S. Parikh (@nishithparikh) \u2022 Instagram photos and videos", "Read Hindu scriptures to get an insight into how the world was like in those days, what divine is, what are the possibilities of human and divine, what an individual can do within the world he lives in, and the best reason of all - there are really good stories in there which you won't find from current generation of authors.", "To know ourselves.", "How to be a selfless Devotee (like Prahalad, Hunuman etc).\nUnderstand Dharma and Adharma (Example - Mahabharat)\nHow to do service to people (from Famous Kings or Lakshmana to Rama etc).\nUnderstand life beyond material benefits(What is Atma?) .\nKarmic cycle.", "Every action every text every thought is only a step towards knowing ourself, to wake up from the dream", "Because it is written by Atma Jnanis who will say how to live our life in the hardest of the situations", "Its mythology for others and puranas for us. It is basis of culture. It depicts how people lived in a dharmic way. What really differs us indians (particularly, hindus) from other cultures? How unique is our culture ? what is the psyche of our society ? This is all we get to know from these puranas or other texts. If we dont read them, others will read it for us in a way that is suitable to them and try manipulating our culture, our ancient value systems or even worse, debate us into silence and shame. It is still going on in the society. People like zakir naik and other evangelists try to win over us by twisting what is being said in our scriptures.\nSo do we not have any responsiblity for preserving our culture and passing on successfully to the next generations? Is this what we are going to reward to those valiant and warriors of the past who fought for the sake of our culture and motherland. you decide.", "Although the term \u201cmythology\u201d has stuck to them, the Ramayana and the Mahabharata are also Itihasas, part histories. One should read them for the same reasons as westerners read Iliad, Odyssey and such. It\u2019s your heritage. These epics are unsurpassed works of poetic beauty, and they elucidate dharma, dharma sookshma and describe human beings as they should or as they are. They are classics as stood the test of time, and one can relate to them no matter one\u2019s place, time and context of life are like. You look up to them not only for aesthetic beauty and pleasure, but also for guidance in your life. You understand people and situations better. You can judge people better. You can defend and protect yourself better. They help you in all this, and much more.\n-Vasu-", "When mythology man? What is your black hole, fermions, quantum field and gravitation, of science etc. means they scientist going from outside, that\u2019s from creation to core. Religions coming from core to creation. Science going from creation to core. That\u2019s all.\nnext veda upanishad and puranas highest science. Hebrew bible is highest science. Where as Quran, Christian bible, Jainism, lord Buddha throw his lotus sutta, Sikhism is unscientific. More over the science pulled according to dogma of theist. So these are fakes. The closer we get to the truth the stranger it gets till eventually mythology starts looking like autobiography.", "Good question. If you are interested in understanding evolution of a culture and preserving and promoting that meaningfully for the benefit of posterity mythology serves the purpose of good foundation.\nScience has its roots in mythology: for example you may be familiar with Adi and Sesha, Adi-sesha, Anantha-sesha as mythological serpents in Hindu mythology. Serpent is symbol of material-energy and energy is always on the move-infinity, celebrated as Pi day. For purposes of the calculation of the value of Pi NASA uses its own standard and India which gave numbers 1 to 9 through Sunya calculated value of pi as Anantha to nine decimal points: 3.141592653, Here Adi is Sesha and Sesha becomes Adi in cyclical time Krit, Treta, Dwapara and Kali.\nAnanta-sayana - infinite bed- what is that? Vishnu sleeps on Ananta-sayana? What does it mean - dynamic, ever expanding space Viswa and nothing in the state of rest. We have not taught our younger generations about these. That is history. We are hopeful of inquisitive students like you\u2026", "American Independence, French revolution etc. happened few hundred years ago is not mythological but history.\nSimilarly Mahabharata, Ramayana, are older History and not mythology. A.C. Bhakthivedanta Swami Prabhupada\nDefine\nMythology (from the Greek\n\u03bc\u1fe6\u03b8\u03bf\u03c2 (mythos), meaning a narrative, and logos, meaning speech or argument) refers to a body of stories that attempt to explain the origins and fundamental values of a given culture\nand the nature of the universe and humanity. In modern usage, the term can also mean stories that a particular culture believes to be true and that use the supernatural to interpret natural events. Ancient myths are generally founded by imagination and intuition rather than objective evidence. Myths identify and help explain human propensities and natural phenomena with the actions and attributes of gods in a primordial past.", "I suppose that by mythological texts you mean the puranas.\nOut of many mythological scriptures, there are 18 maha-puranas (great ancient texts) and 18 upa-puranas (sub texts)[1] , which are believed to be compiled by the great sage Vyasa himself.\nThat's good enough reason for you to read the mythological texts.\nAnd secondly, because you are interested in Indian mythology.\nFootnotes\n[1] Puranas - Wikipedia", "I don't know about any other mythology than Hindu mythology. So i will tell few things i learnt from our Hindu mythological texts.\nWe get to know about our culture and traditions. It is all well preserved in them.\nPersonality development. It has helped me to turn myself into a good human being. It tells you what to do and what not to, what's right what's wrong, everything.\nPerfect Idols. There are so many characters you can idolize. Ram, Laxman, Krishna all are perfect examples of an ideal personality to idolize and to improvise yourself.\nAt last i will say that Hinduism was never a religion. If you study these ancient texts you will come to know that Hinduism is all about scientific and spiritual way of Living Life.", "Because there are many factors in our society which are based on such mythological texts. \u0a2e\u0a28\u0a41\u0a71\u0a16 \u0a15\u0a26\u0a47 \u0a30\u0a71\u0a1c \u0a28\u0a39\u0a40\u0a02 \u0a38\u0a15\u0a26\u0a3e\u0964 \u0a30\u0a39\u0a3e\u0a09\u0964\n(\u0a39\u0a47 \u0a2d\u0a3e\u0a08! \u0a26\u0a41\u0a28\u0a40\u0a06 \u0a35\u0a3f\u0a1a) \u0a35\u0a71\u0a21\u0a47 \u0a35\u0a71\u0a21\u0a47 \u0a30\u0a3e\u0a1c\u0a47 \u0a39\u0a28, \u0a35\u0a71\u0a21\u0a47 \u0a35\u0a71\u0a21\u0a47 \u0a1c\u0a3c\u0a3f\u0a2e\u0a40\u0a26\u0a3e\u0a30 \u0a39\u0a28, (\u0a2e\u0a3e\u0a07\u0a06 \u0a35\u0a32\u0a4b\u0a02) \u0a09\u0a39\u0a28\u0a3e\u0a02 \u0a26\u0a40 \u0a24\u0a4d\u0a30\u0a3f\u0a38\u0a3c\u0a28\u0a3e \u0a15\u0a26\u0a47 \u0a2d\u0a40 \u0a28\u0a39\u0a40\u0a02 \u0a2e\u0a41\u0a71\u0a15\u0a26\u0a40 \u0a09\u0a39 \u0a2e\u0a3e\u0a07\u0a06 \u0a26\u0a47 \u0a15\u0a4c\u0a24\u0a15\u0a3e\u0a02 \u0a35\u0a3f\u0a1a \u0a2e\u0a38\u0a24 \u0a30\u0a39\u0a3f\u0a70\u0a26\u0a47 \u0a39\u0a28, \u0a2e\u0a3e\u0a07\u0a06 \u0a28\u0a3e\u0a32 \u0a1a\u0a70\u0a2c\u0a5c\u0a47 \u0a30\u0a39\u0a3f\u0a70\u0a26\u0a47 \u0a39\u0a28\u0964 (\u0a2e\u0a3e\u0a07\u0a06 \u0a24\u0a4b\u0a02 \u0a2c\u0a3f\u0a28\u0a3e) \u0a39\u0a4b\u0a30 \u0a15\u0a41\u0a1d \u0a09\u0a39\u0a28\u0a3e\u0a02 \u0a28\u0a42\u0a70 \u0a05\u0a71\u0a16\u0a40\u0a02 \u0a26\u0a3f\u0a71\u0a38\u0a26\u0a3e \u0a39\u0a40 \u0a28\u0a39\u0a40\u0a02\u0964\u0a67\u0964\n\u0a39\u0a47 \u0a2d\u0a3e\u0a08! \u0a1c\u0a47\u0a39\u0a5c\u0a3e \u0a2e\u0a28\u0a41\u0a71\u0a16 \u0a39\u0a30 \u0a30\u0a4b\u0a1c\u0a3c \u0a38\u0a41\u0a06\u0a26\u0a32\u0a47 \u0a16\u0a3e\u0a23\u0a47 \u0a16\u0a3e\u0a02\u0a26\u0a3e \u0a30\u0a39\u0a3f\u0a70\u0a26\u0a3e \u0a39\u0a48, \u0a09\u0a38 \u0a26\u0a40 (\u0a38\u0a41\u0a06\u0a26\u0a32\u0a47 \u0a16\u0a3e\u0a23\u0a3f\u0a06\u0a02 \u0a26\u0a40) \u0a2d\u0a41\u0a71\u0a16 \u0a15\u0a26\u0a47 \u0a28\u0a39\u0a40\u0a02 \u0a2e\u0a41\u0a71\u0a15\u0a26\u0a40\u0964 (\u0a38\u0a41\u0a06\u0a26\u0a32\u0a47 \u0a16\u0a3e\u0a23\u0a3f\u0a06\u0a02 \u0a26\u0a40 \u0a16\u0a3c\u0a3e\u0a24\u0a30) \u0a09\u0a39 \u0a2e\u0a28\u0a41\u0a71\u0a16 \u0a15\u0a41\u0a71\u0a24\u0a47 \u0a35\u0a3e\u0a02\u0a17 \u0a26\u0a4c\u0a5c-\u0a2d\u0a71\u0a1c \u0a15\u0a30\u0a26\u0a3e \u0a30\u0a39\u0a3f\u0a70\u0a26\u0a3e \u0a39\u0a48, \u0a1a\u0a3e\u0a30\u0a47 \u0a2a\u0a3e\u0a38\u0a47 \u0a2d\u0a3e\u0a32\u0a26\u0a3e \u0a2b\u0a3f\u0a30\u0a26\u0a3e \u0a39\u0a48\u0964\u0a68\u0964\n\u0a39\u0a47 \u0a2d\u0a3e\u0a08! \u0a15\u0a3e\u0a2e-\u0a35\u0a71\u0a38 \u0a39\u0a4b\u0a0f \u0a35\u0a3f\u0a38\u0a3c\u0a08 \u0a2e\u0a28\u0a41\u0a71\u0a16 \u0a26\u0a40\u0a06\u0a02 \u0a2d\u0a3e\u0a35\u0a47\u0a02 \u0a15\u0a3f\u0a24\u0a28\u0a40\u0a06\u0a02 \u0a39\u0a40 \u0a07\u0a38\u0a24\u0a4d\u0a30\u0a40\u0a06\u0a02 \u0a39\u0a4b\u0a23, \u0a2a\u0a30\u0a3e\u0a0f \u0a18\u0a30 \u0a35\u0a32 \u0a09\u0a38 \u0a26\u0a40 \u0a2e\u0a70\u0a26\u0a40 \u0a28\u0a3f\u0a17\u0a3e\u0a39 \u0a2b\u0a3f\u0a30 \u0a2d\u0a40 \u0a28\u0a39\u0a40\u0a02 \u0a2a\u0a1b\u0a41\u0a24\u0a3e\u0a02\u0a26\u0a3e (\u0a2d\u0a40) \u0a39\u0a48\u0964 \u0a38\u0a4b, \u0a07\u0a38 \u0a15\u0a3e\u0a2e-\u0a35\u0a3e\u0a38\u0a28\u0a3e \u0a35\u0a3f\u0a1a \u0a05\u0a24\u0a47 \u0a2a\u0a1b\u0a41\u0a24\u0a3e\u0a35\u0a47 \u0a35\u0a3f\u0a1a \u0a09\u0a38 \u0a26\u0a3e \u0a06\u0a24\u0a2e\u0a15 \u0a1c\u0a40\u0a35\u0a28 \u0a38\u0a41\u0a71\u0a15\u0a26\u0a3e All inspired by God. So in Genesis ch. 1\u201320 you not only have literally how the earth and universe was started, you see the fall of man, some judgment and how they were scattered all over the earth. The Old Testament also shows how the nation of Israel was created, and that God chose them as his special people. There were Judges, then kings, a lot of history with some interesting characters along the way. Some books get into a lot of chronology, I suggest skipping them. In fact after reading Genesis 1\u201320 or so you may as well move on to the New Testament and read the Gospel of John, Acts, and Romans. This will show you how Jesus gave himself in our place and how you can get saved.\nThen you will find many letters to the churches by Paul, God\u2019s apostle to the Gentiles. Peter, James, and John also have some letters as well, Jude, etc. Revelation is complex, and ties in with the book of Daniel, giving many end-time prophecies. That is a short overview. Blessings as you read. Always ask God to help you understand what you reading.\nHow to Read the Bible: The Beginner's Guide to Reading the Bible", "There are two divisions of the Bible: the Old Testament (written from about 1450\u2013400 B.C.). and the New Testament (written from about A.D. 50\u2013100).\nA single basic thread runs through both testaments: God provides a Savior. In the Old Testament, we trace the physical ancestry of the Savior (the purpose for all the genealogies), from the first man, Adam, through his son, Seth\u2026then through Noah, Shem\u2026Abraham\u2026Isaac\u2026Jacob (Israel)\u2026David, etc.\nThen in the New Testament, the first four books (\u201cgospels\u201d) record the arrival of this Savior, His 3-year earthly ministry, His sacrificial death, resurrection, then return to Heaven, to rule as King of kings and Lord of lords. The next book, \u201cActs,\u201d is also history\u2014but, of the church\u2019s beginning and spread throughout the Roman Empire as more and more are saved \u201cby grace through faith\u201d in this Savior. The rest of the New Testament consists of letters written by Jesus\u2019 Apostles and prophets mostly to churches to instruct and encourage them (and us) to be faithful to Jesus, our Savior, all our lives. The last book contains prophecies that ultimately speak of Jesus\u2019 future return to raise all from the dead, pass judgment on everyone, eternally reward those made righteous through faith in the Savior, and eternally punish those who remained unforgiven of their sins.", "I would suggest reading the book of Luke, and perhaps Acts. The gospel of John is also easy reading.\nFor teaching I would suggest the book of Galatians (which is a letter to the church that was in Galatia) and or the 1st letter written by John (1 John).\nRemember when you are reading that those of us who believe consider that the texts you are reading are considered to be inspired by the Spirit of God.\nAlso consider that although the narratives appear to be very simple and easy, they are also very deep and profound, and every little bit rewards deep study and understanding. An old saying is that the texts are both shallow enough for a child to wade in and deep enough to drown an Elephant.\nLast but not least it is also good practice to approach the Bible while holding the hand of God so to speak. Reading the Bible is as much about self investigation and communion with the will of God as it is about anything else. If we approach the text with the ears of our heart open then we might hear our Father showing us which way He wants us to go.", "I suggest studying prophecy. Those concepts exist based on individual or group perspective. A magical practitioner does not see the world in concepts of good and evil, but in constructive and destructive - forces which are two sides of the same coin. Construction is needed for growth, but without destruction there would be no place for new things to be constructed. So when you use the term grey witch, I assume you want to be a practitioner who walks both the light and the dark paths\u2026essentially that is every witch - or at least it should be, in my opinion.\nAs to how you start practicing magick, I would suggest you begin with a thorough study of the Four Elements (don\u2019t worry about the 5th element of spirit at the moment), Astrology and Numerology before you start dealing with any type of spellwork. "question_title": "Was ancient Egypt a dictatorship were most people where illiterate & incest was common that they were only progressive in medicine & engineering, can u recommend a book about their other aspects of life?", "topic_list": ["Ancient Egypt", "Ancient Civilizations", "Ancient History", "Adult Question", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "History"], "no_of_view": "102", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [1], "ans_list": ["Was ancient Egypt a dictatorship were most people where illiterate & incest was common that they were only progressive in medicine & engineering, can u recommend a book about their other aspects of life?\nYou have bundled several questions together here.\nIt is well known that Egypt was a theocracy: the Pharaoh was worshiped as the incarnation of a god.\nLiteracy was simply a job requirement, meaningless to people who did not have that job.\n\u201cProgressive\u201d had no particular meaning. Everybody invented things as they needed them and there was no big deal. For instance Egyptian surveyors were marking farms after every flood season for thousands of years, but it took a Greek tourist to study their methods and invent plane geometry. What books should I read?", "topic_list": ["Ethics", "Philosophy", "Reading", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Personal Question"], "no_of_view": "568", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Nigel Warburton writes a good series of books which summarize the main ideas of the prominent philosophers throughout history. They are easy to read and understand, while also thorough and accurate.\nAnother book I like is \u201cThe Big Questions of Philosophy\u201d by David K. Johnson. He walks you through the techniques of studying philosophy and how to think about it using a scientific approach. He covers many of the important topics in science and philosophy.\nAnother good book to start with is \u201cPhilosophy: Who Need It\u201d by Any Rand. This book rejects conventional wisdom and critiques some of the big philosophers, using a rational perspective.\nI also really like The Moral Landscape by Sam Harris. It\u2019s a very thought-provoking book I\u2019ve read several times. He gets a few things wrong, most notably his views on free will. However he is a great thinker and debater.\nI started out where you are, teaching myself philosophy and applied ethics over the years, just reading various authors and case studies. As a general rule, I like to think in terms of First Principles. This means that you understand the rules and laws of nature, physics, biology, math, etc. For example, Newton\u2019s Laws of Motion, Aristotle\u2019s Laws of Thought, the Laws of Thermodynamics, etc., provide you with a solid foundation. Just like having a set of LEGO blocks of knowledge, you can use these First Principles to build your understanding of the world. If your building blocks are flawed, missing, skewed, or broken, your ability to accurately view and comprehend the world is limited. Seek to understand these basic rules of truth, and you\u2019ll equip yourself with the tools to make sense of the world.", "\u201cPhilosophy of Religion and Ethics\u201d is on the examination syllabus in the UK, so might be a good introduction\u2026I\u2019m sure some good introductory books are mentioned in the study guide you can pick up cheaply on Ebay (but if overseas, Amazon might be a better bet because of p&p).\nYoutube has quite a few videos on the subject: I always find \u201ccrashcourse\u201d excellent."], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Baffour Owusu-Ansah", "view_list": [23, 13]}, "718": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What did you think of Family Chronicle by Charles Reznikoff?", "topic_list": ["Book Reviews", "Diaries and Journals", "Novels", "Reading", "Family Relationships and Dynamics", "Book Recommendations", "Family", "Books", "History", "Psychology of Everyday Life", "Survey Question"], "no_of_view": "230", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Dane John Cobain", "view_list": []}, "81": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Bruce Tindall"], "question_title": "In the book Eat, Pray, Love. notes that the great Sufi poet Rumi once advised his students to write down three things the wanted in life. A series of events follows that tragically affects all their lives. For advanced teen readers, especially girls.\nBefore We Were Yours\nby Lisa Wingate\nBased in truth, this novel tells a story of survivors from Tennessee orphanage that abused children and parents in the mid-twentieth century. Many teens, especially girls, will enjoy this engrossing tale of children fighting cruel adults to save themselves.\nNeopolitan Novels by Elena Ferrante\nThree novels follow the lives of two girls born into poverty in mid-twentieth century Naples and on into their adult lives. Advanced teen readers who enjoyed Little House on the Prairie, The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants, and/or Little Women as younger readers will enjoy these books.\nNever Let Me Go by Kazuo Ishiguro\nThe narrator, Kathy, looks back at her childhood in a \"special\" English boarding school. The reader and the narrator discover together what that \"special\" means: basically a farm for growing humans as organ donors. Teen girls with a taste for dystopia and fine literature will enjoy this book.\nOrphan Train\nby Christina Baker Kline\nKline juxtaposes the life of an orphaned girl in the early twentieth century with a girl in our modern-day foster care system in this work of historically-based fiction. For teen girls of all ages.\nThe Heretic's Daughter\nby Kathleen Kent\nBased on the true story of one of the first women to be hanged as a witch during the Salem witch trials, the story is narrated from the perspective of the woman's daughter. I just want to emphasize one point and give you a reason for it. Rachel Caine, a highly experienced writer, said, to start as close as possible to a point of interest. Another commenter gave you a variety of ways but started with being in the middle of some sort of action. Really, someone with a vast readership waiting anxiously for their next novel to come out could probably get away with starting any way they wanted. A beginning novelist who wishes to see large scale professional publication someday has some difficult gatekeepers to deal with. If that is what you would like, then someday when your manuscript is as perfect as you can make it, you\u2019re going to start submitting it to agents. That agent or a first reader who works for them is going to have a great pile of manuscripts, or more likely first chapters to read. They are going to spend very little time on each one. You have to catch their attention very early in that read, preferably on page one. If things don\u2019t really start happening until page fifteen, you run the risk of them never seeing the potential of the story. With YA it is even true from a marketing aspect, since that audience , when encountering a new author/series may have little patience with pages of world building with little or no story or anything else that doesn\u2019t get them involved in the characters and the conflict very early. It is something to think about.", "Start any novel with an explosion, conflict, fear. My 4th novel starts with a plane crash.\nAs I wrote to someone else today, no one is paying to watch you warm up.", "First you need to learn how to write. Then you know you\u2019ll need to learn how to write young adult fiction and as we were studying learn how to write the third person POV. Go for it. Write the best you can and finish what you start. Ernest Hemingway.", "You can start absolutely anywhere that you can make not just interesting, but genuinely involving. There are no rules about how to start, but start as close as you can to a point of interest."], "date_list": ["Apr 15, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Ari Elise", "view_list": [39, 112, 24, 68, 27]}, "531": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Where can I get a copy of Wildlife Wealth of India by T. It can be thought to be a major reform in Hinduism to make it more people centric and simpler, which stress on humility and equality of all. It was a liberal movement with no or simple rituals and more community centric. The prayers are mostly in local languages even if derived from bhagawat Purana.\nSignificantly, at the same time many saints also migrated to India from Iran with their version of liberal Islam, but the philosophy same as Indians. Indians, regardless of religion, celebrate both Vaishnava and Sufi saints. Significantly, in Panjab, Sikhs were also busy in their version of liberalism.\nMany believe that this revolution was a new lease of life for India and Indian culture.\nBy the way, words like As someone has already said, personal taste is not part of the diagnostic criteria.\nI\u2019m a fan of both fiction and non-fiction\u2026 with the exception of anything to do with sexual/romantic intimacy. I don\u2019t get it, I don\u2019t like it, and I skip quickly by it with fast forward given the opportunity.\nAs to not liking fiction or whatever\u2026 we who are on the spectrum, often have special interests\u2026 and if fiction is not one, then something else probably will be.", "Aspies have a variety of film and book tastes, just like allistics. I have a bookcase of fiction, and a bookcase of non-fiction. I read and write both fiction and non-fiction. I love to follow the wandering paths of vivid imagination while being almost obsessed with information research.\nThe allistics I have known throughout my life have often loved one or the other, so leaning only one way or the other isn\u2019t typically a trait of any one neurotype.\nI\u2019d say I\u2019m 50/50 in my interests and passions.", "A lot of Aspies don't get fiction, possibly because it seems (in written or film form) to be about social stuff we find difficult. I'm an Aspie who loves written fiction because slowing things down and making them directly explicit in words makes them more available to me, and I like words, but I'm certainly not \"most Aspies\". This implies that liking written or film fiction is orthogonal to having Asperger's, that is, neutral to it: there are probably more absolute \"fiction-haters\" with AS than in the general population, but there are also quite a few people with AS who like to read.", "You can have asperges even if you hate those two things", "I have Asperger\u2019s and despise fiction.", "Yes. Yes, they are all cliched - or to use another word, they\u2019re derivative, meaning they pull from an already successful author\u2019s book structure.\nAs someone who was a bookseller for years, I can say this is the reason: the publishers want an automatic audience for automatic profit. So they prefer something derivative, similar to an already successful author\u2019s writing.\nWhich means it\u2019s difficult to sell them anything really new. They also prefer a series - consider what\u2019s happened to YA fantasy since the Potter books. Think of the Star Wars franchise - after Timothy Zahn\u2019s fine initial trilogy, everything has been handed out to a series of authors - some much better than others. Publishers used to ignore YA as a money market, but no longer.\nIt\u2019s about more guaranteed profit. Sadly it\u2019s the same with adult fiction - most of it is derivative, little of it is original.\nIf you want a really first rate YA author, read Madeleine L\u2019Engle\u2019s YA books, starting with Meet the Austins, a series that concludes with Ring of Endless Light, which in my opinion is better than Wrinke in Time and one of the finest books I\u2019ve ever read. Adults need to read it.\nAnd the separate series that begins with Arm of the Starfish. She has other individual titles as well. Iron Man is my personal favorite.
