Stewart Hearl", "Jay Robert Baer", "Francisco Ojeda", "Brendan McNally", "Brad Chisholm", "Skip Press", "Quora User"], "question_title": "How do I write a book? I am a seasoned chef and have thousands of tested recipes and pictures. How do I get it published?", "topic_list": ["Book Writing Advice", "Book Writing", "Writing Books", "Chefs", "Book Publishing", "Publishing", "Writers and Authors", "Writing Advice", "Writing", "Books"], "no_of_view": "606", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["First, you have to write the book. To submit it to a publisher, it should be in electronic format, i.e. a word doc or a PDF file. As far as how to write a cook book goes, I am not an expert. I suggest that you visit a book store and look at some cook books for formatting options. Usually, there is a description of the dish, a recipe for it and a color photo. These are all sorted by various methods. Meat dishes, fish dishes, pastas, desserts, etc.\nCook books usually sell well.\nGood luck!", "Learn how to write a cookbook and when it\u2019s done and concern yourself with getting it published. You can either find an agent that will bring it to a publisher or you can self publish which is a whole different subject altogether.", "Read plenty of cooking books. Separate them between what you like and do not, then which were best sellers or well-rated. Then, contact the publisher of the books.", "Okay, to start, understand that the world is already full of cookbooks and recipes. It\u2019s really a question of who are you and what can you add to the conversation. Can you add a different perspective? Can you tell unique stories about food and cooking and people? A cookbook is really a book about YOU!\nYou have to make yourself into a Brand. You probably already are, though maybe you just haven\u2019t recognized it. Begin by embarking on an open conversation with the world about food. Start a blog. Build up a readership. In publishing, this is called a \u201cfootprint,\u201d and these days it is all important.\nIf you do this, the next steps will become very obvious.\nGood luck!", "Dear \u2018Seasoned\u2019 Chef.\nYou need a point of focus. Let me give you a couple of examples that are really tightly focused, in addition to being great. Most of these are not new, but most are still in print.\nThe New Cook by Donna Hay. It is very good and helpful and the dishes are interesting. I\u2019ve given away quite a few copies.\nThe Art of Living According to Joe Beef: A Cookbook of Sorts\nYou read Joe Beef like you read a great novel, over and over. And once in a while you stop and cook. These guys are the Hitchikers\u2019 Guide to the Galaxy of chefs.\nA Cowboy in the Kitchen \u2014 Grady Spears\nBefore the Obama recession he had a restaurant in Beverly Hills near our house. We went there often and I still make many of these dishes and he has great stories.\nNew Moroccan \u2014 Mourad Lahlou\nThis book is really beautiful and interesting. The guy has one restaurant in San Francisco but he put his heart and soul into it.\nCuisine Minceur - Michel Gu\u00e9rard\u2019s magnum opus. Yeah it\u2019s from the 70s but it is not out of date in the least. I don\u2019t know if it\u2019s in print, but it\u2019s worth finding. Gu\u00e9rard has technique out the wazoo. If you are hunting Roger Verg\u00e9\u2019s Cuisine of the South of France is in the same series.\nReves d\u2019epices & poivres & piments from Fauchon. The store is not in Manhattan anymore, sadly. Worth it for the photography and ideas.\nI\u2019m assuming you have the big name books, Bourdain, French Laundry, Roubichon,\nObviously the standard of production for photography and design is over the moon these days so think hard about finding your niche, your voice, whether it\u2019s a 50\u2019s diner sensibility or a food truck or somewhere in Brazil.\nIf I were you I\u2019d go as narrow as possible, I\u2019d go to one village in Burgundy, talk to the chefs AND the grandmothers of the chefs and the farmers that grow the vegetables and raise the stock. The vineyards, what they call in wine a \u2018vertical\u2019 tasting. Something like that I would buy.\nNow, once you\u2019ve done all that, you make a book proposal including sample chapters, design, photography, your bio, analysis of the market (do we really need ANOTHER book on guacamole?). It has to convey your unique story.\nGood luck.", "You need to work with a writer - and I\u2019ve always wanted to have a cookbook in my credits, so I\u2019m not alone in finding such a project attractive.\nThat said, cookbooks sell like crazy, even if you self-publish.\nThere are many companies who publsh a lot of cookbooks, such as Ten Speed Press in California.\nThe catch on a cookbook is coming up with something different, or a new twist on something tried and true - hope you have that. A bit of fame helps.", "Are you interested in a publisher producing your book or are you self publishing? If you want a publisher, you'll have to pitch a literary agent your book in a proposal letter (some publishers don't require an agent but most do). You don't have to have the whole book already written but it has to be structured enough that they understand what your book would be like. Also, it is good to have a hook of some kind. There are a lot of recipe books out there, what makes yours different? Why should someone pick your book off the shelf? These are important questions to ask yourself as you start writing.\nIf you're self publishing, you'll need software to format your text and pictures. There are free and paid options for this. This allows you can put your book together how you see fit. But you still should have a hook or a concept that ties your recipes together that makes people want to buy it.\nAs far as the actual writing goes, after you've figured out the hook and the structure, set little deadlines for yourself to get the book written and formatted in a timely manner. As someone whose written a lot, I know it can feel overwhelming when you start a new project but taking it little bits at a time will keep you sane."], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", 9) use 1*9 = 9 digits.\n2-digit pages (10 - 99) use 2 * 90 = 180 digits\n3-digit pages (100 - 999) use 3 * 900 = 2,700 digits.\nTherefore, number of digits available for 4-digit pages:\n6,973 - (9 + 180 + 2,700) = 4,084\nTherefore, number of 4-digit pages in book = 4,084/4 = 1,021.\nTherefore, number of pages in the book:\n9 + 90 + 900 + 1,021\n= 2,020.\nGood luck!"], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Samir Daadouch", "view_list": [8, 22]}, "2": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Eric Life-Putnam", "Steffen H\u00e4user", "C.E. At around ten years of age, in a small Scottish library, I was caught by the head librarian with my face buried in a Zane Grey novel. There ensued the following brief dialogue:\nLibrarian: \u201cYoung man, what do you think you are you doing with that book?\u201d\nMe: (to the tall, slender, rod of the elderly librarian) \u201cI was smelling the book, Miss!\u201d\nLibrarian: \u201cThen, you must leave the library at once! Here, books are for reading, not sniffing! If you want to sniff books, go home and \u2018sniff\u2019 somebody else\u2019s!\u201d\nI was summarily evicted. But I still will not buy a book to this day without sniffing it first. The older books, 1860 upwards \u2014 a sober, rich, inviting, woodsy smell rises to greet from the pages; 1940 and upwards \u2014 a thinner, more light-hearted, still friendly smell wafts gently up into the nostrils: 1990 and upwards: a thin-boned, laboratorial and antiseptic smell charges up the nasal tunnel, attacking the sleepy adenoids, on its way to offend the olfactory senses! Tolkien (author)", "Tolkien's Middle-earth (creative franchise)", "The Lord of the Rings (creative franchise)", "Novels", "Books"], "no_of_view": "19,534", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 5, 2, 20, 1, 9], "ans_list": ["By the time the story takes place, very few. The city was constantly evacuated, most of the elderly, women and children went to the mountains. When Pippin arrives with Gandalf already it lacked half the men that could have dwelt at ease there, and others left afterwards. There were probably no more than 20,000.\nThis is as nothing compared to what the City could accommodate.\nWhen reinforcements of 3000 men enter through the gate, people were waiting for ten times this, implying that the City could accommodate tens of thousands of soldiers in addition to local defenders. That is just soldiers, not civilians.\nMinas Tirith was very big, very very big. The Minas Tirith of the film, although tall, it\u2019smuch smaller, the original of the book was vaster and more splendid than anything that Pippin had dreamed. The Ring of Isengard was a mile in diameter (2 sq km), Minas Tirith was greater and stronger than Isengard. It could be two or three miles long in its seven levels built at great heights that were tapering.\nAn city of great proportions, the largest among Men of Third Age would accommodate at least 100,000. In addition, in the Pelennor fields there were many orchards, townlands and homesteads, although most of the people lived within the city.\nThe townlands were rich, with wide tilth and many orchards, and homesteads there were with oast and garner, fold and byre, and many rills rippling through the green from the highlands down to Anduin. Yet the herdsmen and husbandmen that dwelt there were not many, and the most part of the people of Gondor lived in the seven circles of the City, or in the high vales of the mountain-borders, in Lossarnach, or further south in fair Lebennin with its five swift streams.\nAnd in the south there was the port of Harlond.\nThere Anduin, going in a wide knee about the hills of Emyn Arnen in South Ithilien, bent sharply west, and the out-wall rose upon its very brink; and beneath it lay the quays and landings of the Harlond for craft that came upstream from the southern fiefs.\nAlthough not necessarily in Minas Tirith, these points were adjacent and integrated with the City.", "It wasn\u2019t specified plus the majority of the women, children and elderly were evacuated before Pipin and Gandalf appeared, save ofcourse to the healers. Bergil was one of the few children that were left inside Minas Tirith, during the siedge.\nHowever Pipin sees visible signs of long time decreasing population.", "Tolkien never said, and it would be hard to tell, as the majority of the non-fighting population was evacuated when Gandalf and Pippin arrived. Possibly at its height it was as populous as Rome, but Gondor had been in decline for many years.", "Impossible to say. Tolkien never gave any indication of any populations. The only possible clue is by looking at army sizes.\nDuring the chapter The Last Debate, we are given the following facts:\nOnly 4,000 Riders of Rohan are left out of the 6,000 Theoden led to battle the previous day: a 33% casualty rate in a single day\u2019s battle. (Casualties include wounded as well as killed). \u00c9omer agrees to lead 1,000 of them himself with Aragorn to the Black Gate, and send the other 3,000 north to defend the West Road.\nAragorn has 2,000 men from southern Gondor available out of the troops who sailed up the Anduin with him in the Corsair ships.\nThere are 3,500 soldiers of Gondor available under the leadership of Prince Imrahil (who is standing in for Steward Faramir) \u2014 these are the people who defended Minas Tirith during the siege. If we assume they also suffered 33% casualties during the battle, then Minas Tirith started out with 5,200 defenders.\nFinally, there are 500 horsemen including the Rangers of the North and the Knights of Dol Amroth\nTotal army under Aragorn, \u00c9omer and Imrahil: 7,000 (1,000 Rohirrim, 6,000 Gondorians).\nThere are 4,000 soldiers of Gondor marching up from the south as reinforcements, plus an unspecified number coming by ship. Aragorn states that once they have arrived, Minas Tirith will be better defended than it was before the siege began even after his army has departed.\nIn other words, Minas Tirith was initially defended by around 5,000 or 6,000 troops before the reinforcements under Th\u00e9oden and Aragorn arrived.\nHowever, we also have to consider that these troops include the reinforcements from southern Gondor who arrived before the siege. We are given a detailed breakdown of these (because Pippin watched them arrive) and there were just under 3,000 of them. That means that the regular garrison of Minas Tirith was probably about 3,000 men.\nSome of those 3,000 were full-time professional soldiers: the Guards of the Citadel (Beregond was in the Third Company) and presumably the Rangers of Ithilien. However, I assume most of the troops were relatively recently recruited, after Sauron\u2019s first attack on Osgiliath, and Minas Tirith was a city mobilised for war. In other words, 3,000 men represents the city\u2019s maximum effort in terms of armed men, not its normal peacetime garrison.\nWhat does that say about the total population?\nDuring the First World War, France and Germany mobilised 20% or more of their entire population into the armed services. If 3,000 men is 20% of the population of Minas Tirith (which would mean virtually every able-bodied man between the ages of 16 and 40), then the city\u2019s total population would be 15,000.\nHowever, it would be very difficult to sustain such a high percentage of the people under arms without modern agricultural and transport methods, at least for more than a few weeks before they had to go back to their farms. If Minas Tirith mobilised a more reasonable 10%, then its population would be 30,000. If they only managed 5% under arms, then the city would have had 60,000 people.\nNote that this would be both the population of the city itself within the walls plus, presumably, those living in the farming settlements within the Pelennor.\nSo, as a rough estimate, the population of Minas Tirith and its immediate surrounding hinterland was in the region of 15,000 to 60,000 people.\nTo put that into context, in the year 1000 CE (during the late Anglo-Saxon period in England) these were the 25 largest cities in Europe:\nConstantinople (Byzantine Empire): 150,000\nC\u00f3rdoba (Islamic Spain): 110,000\nPalermo (Sicily): 60,000\nSeville (Islamic Spain): 52,000\nSalerno (Italy): 50,000\nVenice (Italy): 50,000\nKiev (Rus\u2019): 45,000\nThessaloniki (Byzantine Empire): 45,000\nRegensburg (Holy Roman Empire): 40,000\nToledo (Islamic Spain): 37,000\nAmalfi (Italy): 35,000\nRome (Italy): 35,000\nMilan (Italy): 35,000\nMainz (Holy Roman Empire): 30,000\nNaples (Italy): 30,000\nSpeyer (Holy Roman Empire): 25,000\nLaon (France): 25,000\nCologne (Holy Roman Empire): 21,000\nParis (France): 20,000\nRouen (Normandy/France): 20,000\nTrier (Holy Roman Empire): 20,000\nLondon (England) 20,000\nWorms (Holy Roman Empire): 20,000\nMetz (Holy Roman Empire): 16,000\nGenoa (Italy): 15,000\nSo a Minas Tirith of that size would fit comfortably in the top 25 cities of early mediaeval Europe, but it wouldn\u2019t be the biggest. We do know, however, that it was in decline, and the population in 3019 of the Third Age was significantly less than it had been in the days of Gondor\u2019s glory.", "It\u2019s never stated clearly so one can only guess. If you guess 2500 it\u2019s as good a guess as 10,000.", "Okay. At the time of Pippin arriving the city had been emptied of women, children and elderly. Just soldiers and healers and caterers left. When Legolas and Gimli walk around the city they can see many places that clearly have not been inhabited for an extended period. So the population is less than it could be even when everyone is home. The layout of the city is in seven concentric circles. So let's estimate. The lowest circle might have say 500 people. The next one 450, the next one 400 and so on, 350, 300, 250, 200. This makes 2250. Then there are the townlands around the city, within the Rammas Echor which is where most people live. There are numerous references in classical literature: see Gates of horn and ivory - Wikipedia\n. There is a famous passage in Book 11 of Ovid\u2019s Metamorphoses about the House of Sleep.\nThe earliest work on dream interpretation, in Greek, I can find is the Oneirocritica of Artemidorus. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oneirocritica\n. Unlike Freud, it does not advance a psychological theory as the basis of dreams, which was Freud\u2019s remarkable insight. They have over 60,000 books from authors like Shakespeare, Edgar Allan Poe, Jane Austen, and Robert Louis Stevenson. There are some audio books available as well.\nBut if you really want audiobooks, your best bet is the free public domain audiobooks\nat Librivox. Yes, I helped there too. They have almost 14,000 works. Not everything is a book there. They also put together collections of poetry and short stories. These books are mostly older, non-copyrighted works as well.\nNew stuff is available if the author releases it into the public domain. Several popular authors do. One of my favorites is Cory Doctorow\n, the author of Down and Out in the Magic Kingdom\n. Books like this can be harder to find unless you know exactly what you want. But just say once again the meaning and the scriptures are the same", "I almost passed on this question, but given the answers I am seeing here I think this deserves a more serious consideration than is being given by many of the Quora contributors so far.\nFoundationally, the Bible comes to us from two sources: a Hebrew text called the \u201cMasoretic text,\u201d and a Greek text called \u201cNovum Testamentum Graece,\u201d which is a critical text assembled from the many sources of Greek writing we have to validate the text of the NT. The Masoretic Text is the oldest complete text of the Old Testament which s available to us, but we can have confidence that this text is substantially the same text, for example, that was used in Judaism at least 300 years before the birth of Christ as the scraps of tests of Jewish Scripture we have archeologically match the Masoretic Text quite well.\nEvery Bible you read today effectively uses these source texts to make their translations. It is a made-up story that somehow the Bible you have in English or German or Chinese or Hindi is somehow a shadow of the original text because it comes to you through a strange game of \u201ctelephone\u201d in which the original text is translated into language 1, then language 2, then language 3, and so forth until it comes to you in modern form in a modern language.\nWhat is, I think, confusing for most people, is that, especially in English, there is a ridiculous number of variant translations. The last time I checked I think there were 80 distinct translations into English. Rather than investigate all the reasons for all the various committees and motives to put the Bible into English, let\u2019s think about only one of the reasons: theories of translation.\nWherever anything is translated from one language to another, the translator has to make a choice: will I attempt to translate all the words as strictly as possible, or will I attempt to translate the meaning of the words and phrases as accurately as possible? The former philosophy of translation is called \u201cword for word\u201d translation, the latter is called \u201cdynamic\u201d translation.\nIt\u2019s completely true that there are very avid defenders of both ends of the spectrum for philosophy, but it is also true that the many translations you can find of the Bible exist on a spectrum from wooden/literal (where every word is slavishly translated) to paraphrase/dynamic (in which almost no word is translated exactly and the translator has taken liberty with the text to insert his own impressions and thoughts into the text).\nThe most sadly-untrue thing I have read in the competing answers to this question is the idea that somehow Protestants rewrite the Bible when they disagree with it. Suffice it to say that the Catholic church hardly has one translation which they use without any alternatives, and those Bible also run the gamut from hyper-literal to paraphrase.\nHope this helps.", "It is not rewritten except for versions that are written to deceive us.\nVersions like the free ISR are continuously updated as new information is validated and are continually scrutinised by experts, world wide.", "They are not being rewritten as in changed each year. Oh, it\u2019s not that kind of article? Well, what kind of artlcle is it? Does it have a point? Surely it has a point of some kind. State the point you are going to make.", "\u201cIt was a dark and stormy night.\u201d\nIsn\u2019t that the universal good opening?\nOr maybe outline your article, figure out what approach you\u2019re going to take, research it to see where the facts lead you, see if there are any personal stories that help to humanize the subject (and figure out how you\u2019re going to use them in your article), and then figure out - taking into account your own personal writing style and that of the publication(s) you\u2019re hoping to sell the piece to - how you want it to open.\nI don\u2019t mean to sound snarky - but I can\u2019t tell you how to open your article because I don\u2019t know your writing style or how you plan to write the piece. A human interest piece will be completely different from a scientific look, and that in turn will be different from a historical perspective.\nSorry\u2026you\u2019re going to have to figure this one out on your own.\n(Source: Snoopy-Writer - H.W. \u201cBuzz\u201d Bernard\n)"], "date_list": ["Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Safwan Serajum", "view_list": [9, 18, 2, 25, 13, 111]}, "637": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 8, "name_list": ["Sue Sanders", "Alexander M Boast", "Mike Sweeney", "S Millward", "Philip Brian Hall", "Timothy Ellis", "Sandra Jackson-Opoku", "James H. Jenkins"], "question_title": "How does it feel when on the first draft of your novel manuscript you write over 80K words, and on the first revision after that the word count drops to less than 70K?", "topic_list": ["Novelists", "Fiction Writing", "Novel Writing", "Creative Writing", "Novels", "Writers and Authors", "Writing Advice", "Writing", "Emotions", "Books"], "no_of_view": "2,286", "create_time": "Apr 11, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 1, 0, 0, 1, 2, 1, 2], "ans_list": ["How does it feel when on the first draft of your novel manuscript you write over 80K words, and on the first revision after that the word count drops to less than 70K?\nTo begin, trying to gear your story to a specific word count might make you feel an undue obligation that could interfere with your writing style and so on.\nJust write the story. Period. Get a beta reader for opinions on the storyline, characters, your writing style, other important characteristics. Give strong consideration to the beta reader\u2019s opinions.\nThen, if you\u2019re absolutely stuck with giving a set word count, begin the process of either carving away unnecessary words and phrases, sometimes entire paragraphs - or adding in more narrative, description, dialogue. The latter is usually easier, but either way, it\u2019s not that hard to edit your word count.\nOften, it\u2019s a back and forth process to get that count within an \u201cacceptable\u201d range. That\u2019s why I\u2019d go with independent publishing which is much more lenient on such things.", "With the greatest respect to you and my fellow writers.\nFuck wordcount!\nYeah, I said it,\nI didn\u2019t just say it, I made a dank meme to better support the statement:\nCreative writing MAs and constant comparisons to other writers lead to an unhealthy obsession over the amount of words in a story, rather than the quality of the words and the story itself.\nI was at a writing course on Halloween and a woman who had been judging me for playing guitar and talking to the other writers instead of writing said:\n\u201cOh, I\u2019m so upset, I\u2019ve only done 48,000 words and I really wanted to do 50000\u201d.\nFuck right off love.\nAnything above 0 is good. 1 or more is excellent. More than that? Pat yourself on the back.\nI write ghost stories, and do you know what ghost stories are?\nShort, they hit you like trains.\nI\u2019m currently writing a trilogy of novels I think will be between 120 and 180k words. I don\u2019t give a shit if 40,000 words is only \u201cnovella\u201d length if I can tell the story in that amount of words I will.\nIn case you want a less incendiary answer, I cut nearly 10k from my Masters dissertation - felt great.\nGot a commendation :)", "I\u2019d feel good.\nI\u2019ve never managed to cut out more than 5K during the revision process.", "I\u2019d be happy. That\u2019s a good result!\nI like short books. So do lots of others, it turns out.", "You have two problems:\nThings you put in that should have been left out. The manuscript requires editing. You probably set off on ideas that came to nothing or leads that led nowhere. Take them out.\nThings you left out that should have been put in. As the plot develops, you realise you needed to foreshadow certain things but didn\u2019t, or to explain in more detail things that you passed over too briefly. Go back and put them in.\nAs I remember, The Prophets of Baal was originally about 180,000 words. I let the manuscript lie for a while, and when I went back to it, I realised I\u2019d left significant parts of the story in my head. So I wrote them in.\nThen the manuscript was about 210,000 words and I realised I\u2019d included detail that I found fascinating but the reader might well not, and which slowed down the plot in too many places. So I cut drastically and the book ended up in the region of 162,000 words.\nHow does this feel? As if I did what needed to be done. You have to be brutal. Just because you wrote these words doesn\u2019t make them brilliant. Is this sentence really needed? If not, cut it. (Or, if you can\u2019t bear that, get an editor to cut it for you!)", "I\u2019ve no idea how it feels.\nIt\u2019s never happened to me.\nI normally add in something between 2000 and 5000 words during the first editing pass.\nThe longer the book, the more I tend to add.", "That you probably should have cut that 10,000 words\u2026and might cut another 10K on the next revision. It\u2019s easier to overwrite and cut than it is to underwrite and add.", "That is why I write 100,000+ then cut it.\nIf it is good, leave it. If needed, you can cut down. I think it is easier to cut than to pad.\nLike making a film- you do not shoot 2 hours of film. You shoot 6+ hours, 3 takes for each scene, actors trying different choices, plus a mastershot, and inserts\u2026.then piece together the best parts for a work print."], "date_list": ["Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 14, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 11, 2020", "Apr 11, 2020", "Apr 11, 2020"], "question_author": "Christopher Mlalazi", "view_list": [257, 458, 52, 71, 412, 110, 242, 69]}, "710": {"no_of_follower": 0, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Shantanu Jha", "Girish Vidhani"], "question_title": "What are some great books you would recommend for college students?", "topic_list": ["College and University Students", "Reading", "Book Recommendations", "Books"], "no_of_view": "1,010", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [3, 0], "ans_list": ["This book will change the way you think about work. Bad ideas and characters?", "topic_list": ["Science Fiction Books", "Fiction Writing", "Writing Books", "Fiction", "Science Fiction (genre)", "Creative Writing", "Fictional Characters", "Writing Advice", "Writing", "Books"], "no_of_view": "2,288", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [2, 0, 2, 10, 1, 0], "ans_list": ["I made a mistake in my first book\u2026\nIn describing a couple of errors in thought that are common today, but my characters having them described by a survivor of our times, someone who saw the present day practices as ridiculous.\nIt was supposed to be a light moment focusing on the differences in how people brought up before/after the plague would have different perspectives.\nThe problem being that if the reader see issues as normal today\u2026 the reader will still see them as normal in an imaginary future and will be unable to see why the future characters would see the errors in thought we live in presently, as illogical.", "Perhaps the worse mistake is to make the science more important than the story.", "Do not explain things. \u201cHe reached into his pocket and brought out his personal communicator. It recognized him, and activated itself. First, he initiated a database search to find the person he needed to contact. Then he asked his communicator to set up a conference between himself and the other party.\u201d\nvs.\n\u201cHe pulled out his iPhone 10, did a Google search, and hit the \u2018call\u2019 button\u201d\nvs.\nHe pulled out his cellphone and called the person.\nA tendency to over-explain the technology of the future makes no sense. Those people live with it every day.\nIt is the bright-eyed female character who says, \u201cBut Dr. Whatever, I have no idea how a personal communicator works\u201d. This gives him the opening to give the long explanation above.\nGeorge O. Smith wrote of long-distance communicators of the future; they were massive satellites in orbit around the sun, which had gigantic vacuum tubes and delivered megawatts of signal. When Apollo was out at the moon, it was using a microwave antenna and a 5-watt transmitter. Smith knew just enough about radio to extrapolate from the thousands of watts we have in major radio stations (and which can only go a couple hundred miles at best) or powerful \u201cham radios\u201d that needed a thousand watts of power to talk a few thousand miles, and decided that intrasolar distances were so great that communication in the solar system required megawatts or gigawatts. If we were communicating with AM longwave (around a megahertz) in an atmosphere with a Heaviside Layer, then yes, more power would seem natural. But we still communicate and receive data from the Voyager probes, even though they have technically left the solar system entirely. Asimov\u2019s \u201cMultivac\u201d was a vacuum-tube computer that used a nearby river as a heatsink. It probably had a ten-thousandth of the computing capability of a low-end smartphone. Leave things as vague as you can get away with. You want the reader to be in your world; as such, said reader just has to accept that the world has new technology. Don\u2019t bother to explain it.\nScience fiction of the 1950s reads like a fantastic future cold war. Try not to make your fiction follow the boring us-vs-them model, especially if the differences are reflecting political bias. Look at Larry Niven\u2019s aliens. The Kzin are not Soviet Russia vs. the Terran Universe, I mean, the free West. That would be boring. His stories are not boring. Watch how backstory emerges in random sentences spread throughout the story. No infodumps. If you want us-vs-them, try The Mote in God\u2019s Eye and The Gripping Hand.\nIn my own stories (all I need is an agent, who will ideally find me a publisher) I like to start off with a few \u201caxioms\u201d, and using those axioms, develop new theorems that create the new universe. It\u2019s fun. But once I establish the axioms, I can\u2019t deviate from them. If I go back and redefine the axioms, I get a different story. Your axioms form the basis of a vector space.\nAnd, like any axiomatic system, it cannot be complete. The upending of the fundamental goal of mathematics, that everything can be proven if you just know enough, was upset in the mid-1930s by the likes of Goedel, Turing, Church, Post, and a host of others who proved that all mathematical systems are incomplete. Thus, dashing the hopes of those who thought that if you could just write a treaty in the first-order predicate calculus, you could always prove a violation or compliance. John Campbell wrote of giant airplanes with propeller blades measure hundreds to thousands of feet. He didn\u2019t take into account that a fraction of the distance out from the blades, the velocity of the blade would be supersonic. The blade would tear itself apart from the stresses. Don\u2019t focus on the technology, and don\u2019t try to supersize it. And note that if you were writing cellphones into your stories in the 1950s, the stories would have been absurd, because nobody could make a personal communicator with worldwide access that you could carry in your pocket. Don\u2019t be ridiculous! Why, the infrastructure alone would cost billions of dollars! (Oh, wait. It does. That didn\u2019t stop Verizon, T-Mobile, Sprint, and others from building multibillion-dollar infrastructures.)\nIt is far more interesting to study the impact of something new on society, usually by studying one to six people in that society.", "There\u2019s a lot of mistakes you can make, but most of them are general to writing, fiction, and genre writing.\nThe potholes of science fiction lie right in the name. It has science. And it has fiction about science, which usually implies world-building.\nI\u2019ll hit the science first. Not all of these are fatal problems; good books have been written that commit everything on this list (possibly all of them at once):\nGetting science wrong. Science fiction readers are an educated bunch and many of them are nerdy about science. They not only know how things work, they care. They\u2019ll forgive the necessary weasels; put in faster-than-light travel all you like because even though you can\u2019t science it, the story can really slow down without it. But they will not forgive basic mistakes, even if they don\u2019t impact the plot in any way.\nBeing unfamiliar with the field. Science marches on, and so does science fiction. Science fiction has a history, and it has fads. Few things (outside of bad science) annoy the science fiction reader more than an outsider to the field popping up with AI or human cloning or something and going on like it is the most amazing new idea ever.\nBeing too familiar with the field \u2014 or rather, the wrong part of the field. You can get away with cut-and-pasting the \u201cscience\u201d (hah!) of Star Wars and Star Trek, by which I mean inserting the words \u201ctransporter\u201d and \u201chyperspace\u201d and so on everywhere and think you are doing science fiction. You aren\u2019t, really. The core SF fans will hate it. Fortunately for you, there is a whole audience out there who doesn\u2019t know any better, either.\nThings go out of fashion in SF. Science marches on. You can get away with magic nanotech on the fringes but the core readership will point you at more recent writer with a more up-to-date understanding. And save your humid jungles of Venus for a consciously retro pastiche.\nWriting only for the core. What did I say above? Get everything right, be too familiar with what is being done and has been done, and you risk a book that the larger potential audience, that audience who saw Star Wars but has never picked up a book before will be unable to understand. Try not to hit them with the transuranics and the bussard ramscoops right there on the first page.\nUnless your name is James Tiptree. Tip, PKD, and several other writers past and present, could pull off the trick of dumping a reader in the middle of a world that seemed entirely beyond their comprehension and yet make them enjoy it. No, I don\u2019t know what the trick is. Go ask Alice.\nAnd that was a whole bunch of stuff. Sorry. The flip side is the world-building. Which might just be The Machine that Changes Everything, or it could be what society looks like in a hollowed-out asteroid on a transtellar journey five thousand years in the future.\nWorld-building is fun. Explaining your world to the reader is not.\nAnd here\u2019s my particular take. It can\u2019t be done perfectly. Sure, there are lists and lists about what you shouldn\u2019t do. Don\u2019t have a Watson, don\u2019t do Maid-and-Butler, avoid As You Know Bob, etc., etc. And then comes a Jack Vance who does a footnote longer than the page it started on.\nThere are ways of making the background slide into the reader\u2019s consciousness more smoothly. But when all is said and done, it will be awkward. Or it will be left out. Pretty much you are left with four options:\nJust don\u2019t explain. Pick a world which you don\u2019t have to describe. \u201cSociety fell and mumble mumble nanotechnology now it looks just like The Three Musketeers, only with laser swords. Or write a story in which the only science-fictional element is a flying car found in a garage and nobody ever figures out where it came from or how it flies.\nJust get it over with. As You Know Bob, or just hijack the narrative yourself, until the reader is up to speed. Try not to David Weber Orders a Pizza about it, but just grit teeth and get through it. The reader knows what you are up against and will permit it. Just keep it short and get it out of the way as soon as possible.\nDo a big Encyclopedia Galactica or an Obvious Watson but frost it up with added chocolate sprinkles so it is just amusing enough the reader will allow you to get away with it anyhow.\nDo all of the above. Hide as much of the world as you can, or at least delay how the Star Drive works until someone actually has to repair it. Figure out what actually matters to the plot and prioritize that. Don\u2019t explain because you know it, explain because the reader needs to know it.\nUse every trick to try to subtle it in. Get the reader involved in the struggle to defuse a bomb and they almost don\u2019t notice they got a pop quiz on the Island of Stability in the middle of it. Have a Watson who is competent and interesting and doesn\u2019t just sit there going, \u201cGosh, Holmes, so that\u2019s how robots work! I would have never imagined!\u201d\nAnd when there is something you can\u2019t get to elegantly, something the reader really does need to know and explaining it with a scene or dialog would slow down the action too much, then just do it. Be like a stage hand; just walk out there, prop the wall back up, then duck back out of sight. The audience will forgive you and, in a moment, will be absorbed in the action of the play once more.\nAnd can I mention I really hate the auto-list function? It makes it impossible to construct proper paragraphs.", "I think the biggest mistake in a science fiction novel is not adding dystopian elements. The two genres fit so well together! Of course, if you\u2019re just writing science fiction, I don\u2019t have any ideas for huge mistakes that are commonly made.", "There is only one important mistake, and that is making world-building and whiz more important than characters and plot.\nRead some Philip K. Dick. A terrible writer with HUGE IMPORTANT ideas and a sense of urgency. Granite and marble withstands the elements more than any other stone", "Weather", "Depending upon the material of the gravestones and the geography of where they are, weather plays a major part in the deterioration or lack thereof.", "Bhavin, it\u2019s simple enough. It is a matter of the stone available in any locale. Some stones weather and erode more quickly\u2014-or more slowly\u2014-than others.", "It probably depends on what stone was used, where it is (is it sheltered by a nearby tree or other buildings). And some graveatones might have been better kept and renovated.", "A number of factors contribute to this. Basic geology is a part of it: the material the gravestone in question was made from. A limestone slab would weather to the point of illegibility much faster than granite or marble, for instance, as sedimentary limestone is more vulnerable to the elements. Then, too, it can depend on the quality of the stone: higher quality limestone will withstand more.\nIt could be related to socio-economic factors. If the family of the deceased who paid for that headstone were wealthy enough to afford high quality material, they could also (presumably) afford higher quality carving. The letters will have been engraved much deeper, making it harder for the surface to weather down to their level. They may also have been picked out in paint or gold leaf, which would not only withstand the weathering better by itself but will also protect the stone it covers.\nThe nature of the grave site also plays it's part. A well tended grave is less likely to be attacked by climbing plants such as ivy which would damage the surface of the stone. If the area is sheltered - by other taller gravestones, a building or high wall, or by trees - then it naturally will suffer less from the effects of weathering than a more exposed stone.", "Depends on how much sun exposure the face of the tombstone gets."], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Bhavin Patel", "view_list": [8, 1, 18, 1, 20, 126, 17]}, "635": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What are some books about car and automobile comparisons?", "topic_list": ["Automotive Engineering", "Automotive Industry", "Book Recommendations", "Books", "Cars and Automobiles"], "no_of_view": "473", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Kathy Kang", "view_list": []}, "297": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Steven J. The last child of Ungoliant.\nShelob (and Ungoliant) were sentient, and LOOKED like spiders. But they shouldn\u2019t be understood as simply overgrown spiders. They were powerful, evil entities in their own right that happened to be in the form of a giant spider.\nI sometimes wonder if, rather than Ungoliant being in spider form, spiders themselves weren\u2019t created to resemble the form Ungoliant chose.", "Yes. But not necessarily so.\nShe is a spider, but some maintain that she was something else: an evil thing in spider-form, not a spider, but a being in the form of one.\nThere agelong she had dwelt, an evil thing in spider-form, even such as once of old had lived in the Land of the Elves in the West that is now under the Sea, such as Beren fought in the Mountains of Terror in Doriath, and so came to L\u00fathien upon the green sward amid the hemlocks in the moonlight long ago. How Shelob came there, flying from ruin, no tale tells, for out of the Dark Years few tales have come. But still she was there, who was there before Sauron, and before the first stone of Barad-dur; and she served none but herself, drinking the blood of Elves and Men, bloated and grown fat with endless brooding on her feasts, weaving webs of shadow; for all living things were her food, and her vomit darkness. Far and wide her lesser broods, bastards of the miserable mates, her own offspring, that she slew, spread from glen to glen, from the Ephel D\u00faath to the eastern hills, to Dol Guldur and the fastnesses of Mirkwood. But none could rival her, Shelob the Great, last child of Ungoliant to trouble the unhappy world.\nShelob is not naturally a spider; no spider has sting or a two cluster of many eyes instead of eight, also no spider is more protected from below than dragons. She also had more than one poison, one to kill and others to soften her victims.\n\u2018Garn!\u2019 said Shagrat. \u2018She\u2019s got more than one poison. Palacio\nIf you feel your faith in humanity plummeting, this book is a must-read. Yes! it\u2019s a must-read for anyone, it will make you laugh and cry. This story is a great and impactful read for kids and adults.\nFollowing the trials and tribulations of August Pullman, better known as Auggie \u2014 a teen with severe facial deformities (Treacher Collins syndrome, which has left his face disfigured.) \u2014 as he navigates middle school, this book is the antidote to the doldrums and nastiness of the world. It\u2019s like a warm slice of apple pie for a world-weary heart.\nHe\u2019s smart, funny, kind and brave, but his father says that having Auggie attend Beecher Prep would be like sending \u201ca lamb to the slaughter.\u201d Palacio divides the novel into eight parts, interspersing Auggie\u2019s first-person narrative with the voices of family members and classmates, wisely expanding the story beyond Auggie\u2019s viewpoint and demonstrating that Auggie\u2019s arrival at school doesn\u2019t test only him, it affects everyone in the community.\nThe class becomes split between Auggie's friends and the kids who bully him. Every character is written convincingly, and the sides they take earn either our empathy or judgment. Auggie may be finding his place in the world, but that world must find a way to make room for him, too.\nOne of my favourite quotes from the book is coined by Auggie\u2019s sister, Olivia \u201cIf they stare let them stare. Instead, the book helps me build up the ideas that I have such strong belief in.\nI guess I will not try to summarize the book too much here, as you can easily look it up on Google and find an amazing description of it. (By the way, it is 100% through Google). It is about a young boy called Dorian, who, much like the mythical character Narcissus, becomes encapsulated with his outstanding physical beauty. He falls into the cunning of one Lord Henry and is extremely jealous of a portrait of himself painted by an amazing artist and close friend Basil Hallworth. As he moves into his decline of beauty and advances in the pursuit of personal pleasure aided by Lord Henry, he finds that the portrait takes on ugliness, age, and physical wear, while he remains untouched throughout the years. Corrupt, he commits a series of despicable deeds without suffering any repercussions, at least physically, but the rest of his life begins to fall around him.\nIt has been an amazing experience and I would strongly recommend this book as a sort of experimental reading. It is quite old, and the writing style is marvellous. Frankl.\nI just finished reading it actually. This is a fairly old book, and I bought it for a long time, only I just read it. I am like that, my child, likes to look hungry at book discounts. Moreover, the E-book just click, but who knows when to read it \ud83d\ude48\nSo, this book is very neat in my opinion. Frankl was a psychiatrist who had been a Nazi prisoner in the Hitler era for three years.\nIn this book, he told his experience of describing the lives of prisoners in a concentration camp. I even shuddered while visualizing in my mind. Imagine how they worked in the cold snow, barefoot walking on ice because their shoes would no longer fit. In tattered clothes.\nHow do most of them wish it would be better to die than live in hell like that time. How can they guess the rest of their colleague's life and get used to seeing death every day. And live in the shadow of fear that they could have been sent to the gas chamber at any time to be destroyed.\nAccording to Frankl, the average surviving prisoners who have been moved from one camp to another are those who have lost all ethics for survival. From how honest or not, brutal to betray their own friends for survival.\nAnd Frankl found a way to survive differently, without losing his human side. Not survive in a physical sense, but survive psychologically. Find a way to be always optimistic even at the lowest point in life.\n\u201cSuffering really has no meaning, it is we who give meaning to suffering through the way we deal with it\u201d\nMany quotes that hit me, it's just that I will not write it here because it will be a very long writing.\nWhat I found from this book is that there is a greater meaning than happiness, which is the meaning of life itself.\nFor example, we consider happiness when we can find an extraordinary life partner. Or happy is when we can be accepted to work in the company that we have been dreaming of.\nBut it turns out that when our spouse turns out to have a lot of bad sides that are only seen lately, or it turns out co-workers or leaders in the company where we work is very annoying. Then the meaning of happiness can be changed from initial expectations, and result in deep disappointment. Though all returned how do we disclose it.\nThis is called stimulus-response. There are many things that we cannot change, but we can choose how we disclose them.\nJust as Frankl and the other prisoners felt, even in conditions that felt like hell, they tried to find and find a little happiness from a sense of humor and art.\n\u201cLikewise with suffering, He will fill man's soul and conscious mind, regardless of the size and size of suffering. The same applies to Donald Knuth\u2019s TeX system (1978?), although I personally have experienced odd end cases where its justification algorithms produced odd spacing in some rare paragraphs: text extending past the right margin. I gather SILE - What is SILE?\nis a modern revamp of TeX, using the same basic algorithms. A lesser known system was the Lout\nsystem created by Jeff Kingston of Sydney\u2019s Basser Dept of Computer Science.\nTeX I think made an attempt to avoid \u2018rivers\u2019: apparent runs of white space due to chance alignment of spaces through lines of text. That\u2019s something I don\u2019t believe troff (or its modern equivalent, GNU groff) attempted to address.\nFor myself, I\u2019m satisfied these days with the WYSIWYG results from LibreOffice, and many people are perfectly happy with Microsoft Word. Both systems provide plenty of control over most aspects of the typesetting required for books, including control of widows and orphans, drop caps for the 1st character of a chapter, and so on. (You do need to pay attention to such matters to produce a reasonably well typeset book.)\nIngram Spark have a useful summary page here What is Typesetting and Why Does it Matter?\nMore advanced typsetting features like letter pair kerning, avoidance of rivers, tracking control of inter-word spacing within a paragraph, are available I believe in higher end typesetting programs. My understanding, which may be wrong, is that these features however must be applied manually depending on the typeset result of each page. The consequence is that if you change the layout (such as if you produce different editions with different font or page sizes, or if you\u2019re producing an ebook edition in which the user can change the layout at their whim), that per-page manual assessment and adjustment needs to be done again, quite likely across the entire book.\nI don\u2019t know whether any programs attempt to build-in the automated application of such aesthetic typography adjustments. I suspect it may be considered more an art than a science. But I don\u2019t have personal experience with QuarkXpress or Adobe\u2019s InDesign and other packages. A simple comparison of some of these can be found via Google; such as this one: Best Desktop Publishing Software - A comparison | Pagination.com\nI\u2019ve left aside the entire topic of typeface designs, and especially the topic of optical scaling of fonts (as it used to be done before computers), vs the mathematical scaling of vector typefaces, which in contrast does not take account of the non linear perception of white space as a typeface is enlarged or reduced.\nSo you\u2019ve asked an interesting and big question!"], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Dex Jackson", "view_list": [308]}, "675": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Parama Devi"], "question_title": "In which book are all the stories of myth, god, demons, truth, devil, Kali, and Pari, like mentioned in the ASUR web series, written? All of them.", "Show me the books and I\u2019ll tell you for sure."], "date_list": ["Apr 12, 2020", "Apr 12, 2020"], "question_author": "Madison Daily", "view_list": [664, 27]}, "740": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Arush Sharma", "Nilkanth Patel"], "question_title": "Have you read the helicopter Money Concept?", "topic_list": ["Concepts", "Aviation", "Making Money Online", "Reading", "Finance", "Books", "Money", "Survey Question"], "no_of_view": "207", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["When someone hears the term helicopter money they'd probably get the image of the RBI/Federal Reserve dumping money out of helicopters. That's interesting, but what is a real meaning of helicopter money?\nThe term helicopter money came about because it represents the concept of the country\u2019s central bank creating free money and giving it directly to individuals and businesses. Currently in U.S., the Federal Reserve provides monetary stimulus by injecting reserves into the financial system with the goal financial institutions would lend us money out to businesses and the ultimate goal of creating spending. It appears that existing monetary policy has not worked very effectively in this economic recovery because financial institutions still have large cash balances in the federal reserve accounts and spending has remained muted by historical standards.\nThat is true. As a result the idea has been thrown out that the Federal Reserve should simply create cash deposited directly into individuals and businesses accounts with the belief that the money would be spent and help stimulate the economy.\nIt is the financial equivalent of the Federal Reserve dropping cash from a helicopter. Unfortunately, that may sound like a great concept, but it's not that simple. The Federal Reserve conducts their monetary policy by buying or selling US government securities. If they want to stimulate the economy their authority to buy US government securities and credit the reserve accounts of member financial institutions. That's what happened during their quantitative easing operations.\nThe Federal Reserve does not have the mechanism to deposit money directly into consumer business accounts and it's questionable if they have the authority to simply print money. Congress has the authority to pass legislation that would authorize the U.S. treasurer to issue checks or electronic deposits to individuals. This occurred during the last recession when congress authorized the US Treasury to send checks to qualifying individuals.\nThe problem is that this would balloon the deficit. The reason that proponents suggest helicopter money originating from the Federal Reserve is because creation of money by the Federal Reserve does not increase the deficit. As mentioned earlier how the federal reserve and get this money to individuals and businesses is not clear at all. And don't forget that giving free money is not actually free. Otherwise all countries would be doing this. All else being equal giving free money to individuals and businesses via the Federal Reserve printing money would ultimately lead to higher inflation.\nFixed income investors would demand a higher yield for bonds if they believe that inflation or debt problems would result and this would cause bond prices to fall. Higher bond yields would then drive borrowing costs up for individuals and businesses with the potential unintended consequence that they cut back on spending.\nThere are also two other risk to consider. First consumers might not spend the money, simply put into savings. As we saw with the temporary tax cut that occurred during the recession not all of that money was actually spent. Second this is something that has never been tried and it would be a giant economic laboratory experiment with actual results unknown.\nI would simply remind all that the age-old adage still applies. There is no free lunch.", "Yes. .What is helicopter Money ? how RBi may use this concept?"], "date_list": ["Apr 16, 2020", "Apr 15, 2020"], "question_author": "Shanigarapu Vamshi", "view_list": [19, 3]}, "62": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What is a Lexile level on a book?", "topic_list": ["Lexile Measure", "Writers and Authors", "Reading", "Writing", "Books", "Education"], "no_of_view": "245", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Tarun Dhingra (\u0924\u0930\u0941\u0923 \u0922\u0940\u0902\u0917\u0930\u093e)", "view_list": []}, "701": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "How do I submit a book to Oprah Book Club for review?", "topic_list": ["Book Clubs", "Oprah Winfrey (TV host, actor)", "Books"], "no_of_view": "212", "create_time": "Apr 12, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Smith Gilliam", "view_list": []}, "284": {"no_of_follower": 0, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Aditya", "Aman Parmar"], "question_title": "I\u2019m a young investor but now want to do trading. They aren\u2019t.", "Hi Mike -\nIt\u2019s a work of fiction. The original novel was written by H.G. Wells in 1896.\nIt was written at a time when interest against animal cruelty rose in Europe, as well as growing popularity of Charles Darwin\u2019s Evolution of the Species.\nThanks!\nD.-", "It was pure fiction . Enough said !", "Yes it is real ;the story is almost 200 years old ."], "date_list": ["Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Mike Evans", "view_list": [174, 192, 24, 14]}, "451": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Peter Badovinatz", "Sakiusa Turaganivalu", "Mike Sweeney"], "question_title": "Is there a good term for fiction that has history in it?", "topic_list": ["Fiction", "Writing", "Books"], "no_of_view": "1,026", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1], "ans_list": ["Is there a good term for fiction that has history in it?\nThe broadest term is simply \u201chistorical fiction.\u201d These can be essentially any genre of fiction but set \u2018in the past.\u2019 How far in the past? There isn\u2019t a rule, but roughly 50+ years, enough to clearly differentiate \u201cthe present\u201d from the period in which the novel takes place. But from that, you can have romances, thrillers, war stories, mysteries, etc. The expectation is that while the core story is fictional the setting is clearly recognizable for the period in which it\u2019s set, historical figures may appear and play greater or lesser roles and technology needs to hew to that available in that time period. A woman in a writer\u2019s workshop I\u2019ve attended is doing a novel in the years after the First Fleet\u2019s arrival in Australia. Historical and fictional characters interact. In such cases, while the author can invent events for the historical figures to participate in, where we have documentation about what they did these novels need to remain consistent. Captain Arthur Philip was governor in Australia from 1788\u20131792, and eventually died in Bath, England, in 1814. Historical fiction needs to hew to those, although it can certainly imagine what he may have done on the times we know he was somewhere, but have no record of precisely what he\u2019d done or encountered.\nIf you want to ignore fidelity to history, \u201cAlternate history\u201d is a common term for fiction novels that are based around actual historical events but posit some aspect of the actual historical record changed. For example, \u201cHow Few Remain,\u201d by Harry Turtledove, posits a series of events that allowed the South to achieve enough of a stalemate in the US Civil War to cement their independence to split the United States. A series of books, under the series title \u201cSouthern Victory,\u201d then follows this alternative timeline into the 20th Century. At the beginning, the major historical figures are all historical, e.g., Generals Robert E. Lee of the south and George McLellan of the north, President Abraham Lincoln and more. As the novels move in time more historical figures appear, such as George Patton.\nAlthough Turtledove wrote many alternate history novels and series with science fictional / fantastic events, \u201cHow Few Remain\u201d is purely based in a reimagined timeline. Thus, ensuing development of both the North American continent from 1863 as well as world history is affected, but it\u2019s all based in known science. For science fiction, his \u201cThe Guns of the South\u201d reimagines white supremacist South Africans time traveling back to the US Civil War to provide the south with AK47s. \u201cWorldwar\u201d imagines an alien invasion in the middle of World War II and how it affects the world. Both of these series again use historical settings and figures as they existed. Naturally, many other characters are fictional, especially many viewpoint characters. But that makes these books \u201cscience fiction + alternate history.\u201d\nIf you want to relatively accurate to history but mess around with something big, like the available technology, you can get \u201csteampunk\u201d, a sub-genre of science fiction, not historical fiction. These are set mainly in relatively accurate Victorian Era (late 18th Century) settings except for various sorts of advanced technology, e.g., airships, weaponry, aliens and other specific items. But clothing, mores, countries, etc., are distinctly to that era.\nThe other answer mentions Dan Brown\u2019s books, such as \u201cThe Da Vinci Code.\u201d This doesn\u2019t so much change history as it tries to reinterpret it by making assertions about key events that are unknown or are unconventional analysis. Brown\u2019s books then are more \u201cthrillers\u201d than alternate history (IMHO).\nThere are also many novels that don\u2019t change history but use realistic historical settings for a \u2018time travel\u2019 fictional story. A couple of examples are \u201cDoomsday Book\u201d by Connie Willis and \u201cTimeline\u201d by Michael Crichton. Both are built around time travellers from current times (20th, early 21st century) visiting England during the Black Death (1348\u20131352) to study it. Although various local events are affected, by and large there is no macro change to the historical timelines from the actions by the characters. Various historical figures of the time are referred to but generally don\u2019t play major parts. After all, not that many \u2018regular\u2019 people (that the time travellers\u2019 posed as) spent time hanging out with kings. These would both simply be \u201cscience fiction\u201d as they don\u2019t alter history, but the settings are realistic to the actual history of the period, at least so far as historians have been able to reconstruct it but the technology that sets it up, time travel, is beyond existing science so I don\u2019t consider these historical fiction.", "Yes", "(Details included in answer)\nNot historical fiction, but thrillers, mysteries, etc, taking place within a contemporary period but in which history plays an important part in the plot.\nDan Brown, say. Or something like the Samantha Sutton mysteries."], "date_list": ["Apr 19, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020", "Apr 13, 2020"], "question_author": "Mike Sweeney", "view_list": [32, 4, 25]}, "35": {"no_of_follower": 4, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Preethi Krishna", "Aarushi"], "question_title": "What young adult books can I read during a lockdown?", "topic_list": ["Young Adults", "Children's and Young Adult Books", "Reading", "Book Recommendations", "Books"], "no_of_view": "594", "create_time": "Apr 13, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 1], "ans_list": ["Chk out my site for young adult(ya) book recommendations\nhttps://www.meander23.com", "Hello there! You should be prepared to create awareness about your book.", "If you are publishing as an ebook, the results will be terrible. Ebooks are simply not well-suited for technical manuals. Tables, images, and diagrams just don\u2019t translate well to small, digital screens. The ebook readers simply do not handle these things properly. They are optimized for displaying narrative prose for storytelling, not technical layouts. This is why digital textbooks for schools have done fairly poorly in the market.\nIf you are going to use Print On Demand, as long the your PDF of your manual displays nicely, I think that should work. POD books are a little pricier than mass-printed books, but it also means you will not have to front the money to get your books printed.\nLooking back to ebook versions of technical manuals, it is simply that the current state of technology doesn\u2019t quite support that use. I think it is highly likely that in the near future with improvements to software and technology, that this will become a potential market. But there are a lot of differences between what 3b1b can do in an online video, and what a teacher can do in a classroom with a blackboard.\n3b1b uses animations, and this is a great source for visual insights. But you simply cannot replicate this on a blackboard or a textbook page. Some textbooks have QR codes or links that lead to a website with a cool animation or some interactive app. Myself, I plug my tablet into the projector to show the class gifs, Desmos, videos, etc. Sometimes I literally show 3b1b\u2019s videos in my classroom. But students tend to roll their eyes when the prof shows a video/animation in class, even one he made on his own (I\u2019ve done it myself). Either way, this is no substitute for the the fluid animations that online videos can include.\nYou can watch 3b1b at your own pace, and even rewind to catch tidbits you might\u2019ve missed. This is impossible in a physical classroom \u2014 the best you can do is ask the prof to repeat, but many students are embarrassed to do this, and certainly it comes at the cost of slowing the lecture down. And you definitely can\u2019t pause the prof for a lunch break.\nBy simply clicking a 3b1b video, you have already fully bought into the fact that you\u2019re about to learn something. This is totally different than dragging yourself out of bed for an 8:30am sixty-minute lecture on technical test material, even if the prof is a badass teaching robot who shows you cool animations and pictures. But technical material *is* important (see my next point).\n3b1b highlights concepts and visual understanding, and this is EXTREMELY important for learning math \u2014 it is sorely underrepresented in classrooms. But a university classroom must also focus on developing technical skills and preparing you for tests, and this material can be dry, even with the most exciting lecturer. As boring as they are, these technical skills are important things we try to teach you in university. If 3b1b showed you a beautiful animation involving determinants and told you \u201cthere\u2019s gonna be a test, and your job prospects depend on your performance\u201d, I\u2019m sure many students would be annoyed at the lack of technical detail he shows. It\u2019s like \u201cI know *what* a determinant is, but how do I calculate the determinant of this 5x5 matrix? How do I prove that a unitary matrix has determinant +/- 1?\u201d 3b1b videos are the benchmark for high level conceptual understanding, but low level technical stuff is not equally present in his videos. (Also, I don\u2019t mean that 3b1b CAN\u2019T or SHOULD include details, just that his \u201cessence of linear algebra\u201d series tends not to, and there are pros/cons to that.)\nWith 3b1b\u2019s videos, you don\u2019t have in-class opportunities to work on exercises with your peers, or to ask the lecturer to give you immediate feedback. I usually assign group work during my lectures: because I fully understand that if students wanted to watch someone talk for an hour, they might as well watch 3b1b because he is much better than me. I love what Sanderson is doing in his recent live stream videos \u2014 his questions are designed to get you thinking and playing (many profs design similar questions), and his polls get the audience engaged in the material. Profs also use polls \u2014 ever heard of an iClicker? Ever heard of people complaining about how much they hate iClickers? I use Kahoot in my university classroom, but students always think it\u2019s fun to crash my tablet with bots. See the contradiction there?\nI love 3b1b so much. Professors need to wake up and incorporate his methods into their classrooms. But there are pros/cons to physical delivery and online delivery, and each format has different goals. You should be aware of these differences.", "It's about the building of ideas. They want you to build skills so that you can move beyond introduction to linear algebra techniques. The video shows what is going on and the teacher is thinking that is what I said.\n(ad distance in x) so forth. They do this because you should be building off the abstract ideas of distance and the area of a parallelogram. By understanding this you can move on to 3d ( 3x3 matrices) and further.\nI suspect you are most likely used to the more graphical text books. Let's sum up math texts books and the disconnect with teachers. There are two kinds.\nOne is the text book written by a Mathematics major with a minimum M.S. degree. These books written for any math below calculus becomes harder for a Mathematics major to simplify. Where addition just is for others trigonometry just is for a Mathematics major. So those books don't always work as well as people would like for undergraduate Mathematics. Beyond calculus professors use the book less anyway.\nThe other book is the large publishing company. A pretty book made by writers with a graphic artists and Mathematics consultants. The books are prettier with mathematical visuals, but there is a disconnect between the Mathematics teacher and the book as the Mathematician was more of an editor. This leaves the teacher and book at a disadvantage.", "Textbook authors and math professors very often include that pictorial intuition into their explanation of the concept of a determinant. Take it slow.\nIf you feel that you are reading too slow compared to others, take it easy because the faster you read the less likely you are able to comprehend. Reading is a lifelong process, learning to read closely and slowly will help you become faster over time. The best readers are flexible-slowing down when needed. So be patient and start at a comfortable reading level.\n2. Choose the right time and place to read.\nIn order for you not to be distracted, first things first. If you have to do something or you have a difficult text to read for your homework it\u2019s probably the best to do it first and then find a quiet and comfortable place with good light, and your dictionaries and other materials nearby.\n3. Read books that interest you.\nYou might not want to read a book that you don\u2019t like. Being interested in a topic, will probably higher the chance for you to understand texts that would normally be too difficult. You are much more likely to commit to reading when it is an enjoyable and engaging experience.\n4. Use a dictionary sensibly.\nUsing a concise dictionary when reading can assist vocabulary acquisition. Relying on it may be a big help but sometimes it slows you down so try to avoid using it regularly and use it wisely. You can also understand a word by knowing its usage and by rephrasing the sentence. Try to guess the meaning of the word and with that you don\u2019t need to look anything up.\n5. Read with purpose.\nKnow your reasons for reading. The way you read a certain text or a book depends on your reason for reading it, that\u2019s why it is important to know your reading purpose. Reading a test question for an exam is different from how you read a novel for pleasure purposes.\n\u201cA reader lives a thousand lives before he dies, said Jojen. The man who never reads lives only once.\u201d \u2013 George R.R. Martin, A Dance with Dragons\n\u201cRead, read, read. Read everything \u2013 trash, classics, good and bad, and see how they do it. Just like a carpenter who works as an apprentice and studies the master. Read! You\u2019ll absorb it.\u201d \u2013 William Faulkner\n\u2014phoenix\u2014", "Reading builds the habit of reading.\nBut if you are having problems selecting the right books, I\u2019d say to write what you feel about a book when you read it, so you know what genres and authors work for you.
